PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I present the report of the committee entitled Women, elections and parliament. This report relates to a reference from the Senate proposing that the committee conduct an inquiry to discover the reasons for the gender imbalance in Australian parliaments, develop strategies for reducing the imbalance, and identify the aspects of parliamentary procedures and practices which impede the full participation of Australian women in Australian political life.

PARA.TAB: The report itself is short. It reflects the committee's conclusion that a conventional parliamentary committee inquiry would not be the best way for this committee to participate in a debate about ways to improve the representation of women in parliaments in Australia. The committee was assisted in reaching this conclusion by a paper prepared for it by Ms Consie Larmour of the social policy research group of the legislative research service of the Parliamentary Library. Ms Larmour's paper has been included as the appendix to our report.

The committee regards this paper as accurately stating the present situation with regard to the matters broached by the terms of reference for the inquiry. It is the intention of the committee to make the paper widely available and to invite comments on it from the community. This will assist the monitoring process which the committee recommends for itself in this report.

As regards the first of the proposed terms of reference, namely, the reasons for the gender imbalance, it was apparent to the committee from Ms Larmour's paper that existing research had already established the reasons for the imbalance of men and women in Australian parliaments. It was the same with the second proposed term of reference, which asked the committee to consider strategies for increasing the number and effectiveness of women in political and electoral processes. The goal of achieving equity in representation has been accepted by all Australia's political parties, although the International Parliamentary Union has endorsed parity of representation without recommending a specific date.

There is general agreement within Australia that women should have equal employment opportunities, including in politics, but that there should not be an imposition of quotas. The immediate issue which all parties would endorse is the view that women should not be disadvantaged as compared with men in obtaining endorsement for seats in parliament. The report and appendix describe current ideas and strategies for achieving this aim.

The committee felt that matters had moved beyond the point of proposing strategies; these had already been identified and were now being implemented as actual programs by the various parties. The committee has concluded that the most valuable role it can perform in the light of this ongoing activity is to monitor developments on behalf of the parliament so far as they relate to the electoral process. Accordingly, it recommends in the report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the Minister for Administrative Services authorise the committee under para (1) of its resolution of appointment to monitor developments in the area of the participation by women in the electoral process and to report on this matter from time to time.

PARA.TAB: The committee did not consider that it was authorised to conduct an inquiry on the third of the terms of reference. The report notes recent developments to introduce sitting hours for the Senate and the House which we see as being more conducive to family life than the traditional hours. However, matters of parliamentary procedure and practice are outside the scope of the authority conferred on the committee by the parliament and would be more appropriately undertaken by the respective procedure committees of the Senate and the House.

It is the intention of the committee to distribute the Parliamentary Research Service paper among community groups, inviting comments and responses from within these communities. To this end, the research service paper has been printed as part of the report that I have just tabled. Mr Speaker, I commend the report to the House.

Since I have a few moments to spare, I will take the opportunity to address the House on some of my personal views on this matter, as distinct from those in my capacity as the deputy chairman of the committee. The Liberal Party believes that, in every sense of the term, women must have a fair go in all aspects of Australian society. We must ensure that women are not placed at a disadvantage. One of the big issues, therefore, which all members of parliament and the community as a whole have to address is the identification of the fact that women have been placed at a disadvantage in the past in relation to accessing the political system. This does not mean that there have not been many outstanding women in Australian politics over many years, and it certainly does not mean that there is not a growing number of women in the Australian political process at the present time.

It is worth noting that there are 11 women Liberal federal members and senators at the present time. We have had a number of women both in the outer shadow ministry as well as in the shadow cabinet. There are, in fact, now over 30 Liberal women in state and territory parliaments. Three of the eight New South Wales Liberal women are ministers; two of the nine Victorian Liberal women are ministers; one of the five Western Australian Liberal women is a minister; and one of the eight South Australian Liberal women is also a minister. In the recent South Australian state election, five out of the six Liberal women candidates won seats, compared to one out of 10 Labor women; only two of the successful Liberals were considered to be in safe seats.

In looking at the historical view, it is interesting to note that the first woman to be elected to any Australian parliament was Edith Cowan from Western Australia in 1921. The first woman elected to the House of Representatives was Dame Enid Lyons from Tasmania in 1943; the first woman federal cabinet minister was Dame Enid Lyons. The first woman elected to state cabinet was Dame Florence Cardell-Oliver in Western Australia in 1947. The first woman elected as state president of a major political party, the Liberal Party, was Miss Joy Mein in Victoria in 1976. The year in which the first woman elected to each state parliament from non-Labor parties was: Western Australia, in 1921; New South Wales, in 1925; Queensland, in 1929; Victoria, in 1933; Tasmania, in 1955; and South Australia, in 1959.

It was under a Liberal government that the policy of opening the armed forces to women was achieved in 1941. The introduction of child endowment was established in the same year. The women's bureau to develop ideas and arguments for reform of women's employment was introduced in 1963. The lifting of the marriage ban in the Commonwealth Public Service, a most profound and vital reform, was introduced by a Liberal government in 1966. Perhaps the most significant reform of all was also introduced by a Liberal government in 1972, with the equal pay legislation.

The Child Care Act to assist non-profit organisations to establish and operate day care centres was introduced in 1972. The introduction of family allowance payments directed to the mother occurred during 1976-77. The national inquiry into the role of women, which led to the establishment of the National Women's Advisory Council, was introduced by the Fraser government. We also established the Human Rights Commission under Dame Roma Mitchell, the first chairman. We established the first Institute of Family Studies in 1980, and signed the Copenhagen Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women, which formed the basis of the Sex Discrimination Act of July 1980.

These are all fundamental and profound reforms introduced by the non-Labor parties into the federal parliament of this nation which have supported women, families and the overall principle that in this society women must be equal to men in all respects, especially in relation to their opportunities to access the political system.

One of the important things we need to note in the present environment, however, is the tendency for the government now to take the view that having women in parliament can be achieved only through quotas. We oppose the introduction of quotas because we fundamentally believe that the principle of a quota means that you often end up taking second best. This parliament and the people of Australia deserve the best at all times. We need to have women of outstanding quality standing for pre-selection and, in so doing, feeling that they have as good an opportunity as any man to seek the support of the preselectors and ultimately the support of the electors of those respective electorates. Then and only then will women be able to stand in this House and say, `We are here as your equals. We have been put here by the people of Australia on the basis of what we can contribute to the Australian political system and to our nation.'

It is for that reason that we do not support the introduction of quotas. But we certainly support the introduction of programs within political parties which will encourage women to stand for pre-selection, will encourage women to be trained and to be given every possible opportunity to feel that they can advance within the process, knowing that there are no bands, that there are no glass ceilings and that there are no constraints holding them back. It is only then that the women of Australia will be able to say of the Australian political system, `It is fair and under it we are equal in all respects.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters commissioned a paper from the social policy group of the Parliamentary Research Service of the Parliamentary Library. The committee has concluded that the most valuable role it can perform in light of that report is by way of ongoing activity to monitor developments on behalf of the parliament so far as they relate to the electoral process and how they affect women. It is the intention of the committee to distribute the Parliamentary Research Service paper inviting comments and responses from the community. These community responses will be collected and, where appropriate, reported to the parliament. After wide community consultation for its reference into equal opportunity and equal status for women in Australia, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—I was also a member of that committee—stated in its report Half way to equal, the Lavarch report of April 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee believes that it is incumbent on political parties to redress the gender imbalance where it currently exists so that it more accurately reflects the constituency.
Its recommendation was:

. . . that all political parties examine their selection procedures for systematic discrimination against women and develop appropriate affirmative action programs which give women equal opportunity to take a greater role in the political process.

Last Thursday, 2 June 1994, the Minister for Human Services and Health, the honourable member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), made her first speech in this place. I think it is worth quoting two parts of that speech because I think they summarise basically my view in relation to this matter. She quoted the political columnist Alan Ramsey, who said:

There are rarely any free kicks for women in politics. No matter how much or how little ability they might have, and whatever the expedient rhetoric of the time, men run politics and women get only what men will you them to have. Mostly they're manipulated, exploited and patronised.
The minister concluded her speech as follows:

PARA.TAB: My message to women is: do not wait to be asked; do not wait to be pressured into political life—put up your hand and demand that you participate. To quote a very feisty woman, Sarah Henderson, `All the strength you need is within you. Don't wait for a light to appear at the end of the tunnel. Stride down there and light the bloody thing yourself.'

SPEECH.PARA: The statistics, as revealed in our report at page 54, are appalling. The statistics on women in Australian parliaments as at 13 April 1994 are as follows: in the House of Representatives there are 15 out of 147, 10.2 per cent; and in the Senate, 17 out of 76, 22.37 per cent. In all the parliaments in Australia, women have 132 positions out of 841, 15.7 per cent; for lower houses, it is 81 out of 604, 13.41 per cent; and for upper houses, 51 out of 237, 21.52 per cent.

PARA.TAB: If we as a parliament are to retain any credibility in the community, we need to be representative of our constituency. We need more women in the parliament. We need more people from ethnic backgrounds in the parliament because they too are underrepresented; but it will not just happen. I am part of the Left in New South Wales. My seat in this parliament was obtained not because it was given to me but because I took it. And that is what women need to do—take their rightful place!

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Delegation to Syria, Lebanon, Tunisia and Morocco

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Syria, Lebanon, Tunisia and Morocco from 9 November to 3 December 1993. The delegation to both the Middle East and the Maghreb occurred at a very critical time in the conduct of the peace process. More recently, we have seen those agreements, which were of enormous historical significance, come to fruition: on Friday, 13 May, the last Israeli soldiers withdrew from Jericho; and on Wednesday, 18 May, the last Israeli soldiers withdrew from Gaza after 27 years of occupation which followed from the 1967 war.

PARA.TAB: It was a great privilege for the members of the delegation to represent the parliament at such a critical time. The issues that were addressed, the people we met, the places visited and the institutions observed were of enormous value to the delegation and, as a result, of enormous value to the parliament. I commend the report to all honourable members; in fact, I commend it to those people in the wider community who have any interest at all in the Middle East and the Mahgreb.
I offer a special thanks to the host governments and all of those outstanding people who represented them during our visits. Their hospitality was absolute.

I want to pay special tribute to the members of the delegation: the deputy leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), Senator Gerry Jones, Senator Baden Teague, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), and Mr Peter Stephens, the secretary, who has been kind enough to grace us with his presence in the advisers seat this morning. I thank Peter very much for the way in which he undertook the initial preparation and the way he facilitated and assisted all of the delegates and their spouses during that delegation. Had it not been for his professional competence and commitment, it could not have been as successful as it was. His follow-up was carried out in the same exemplary manner.

The delegation was particularly pleased, as I have also indicated, to have as a member Daryl Melham, who is the son of Lebanese parents. It was of great value not only because of his high standing within the Australian parliament but also because of his high standing in Lebanon. It provided a personal dimension to that deputation which could not possibly have occurred otherwise. Daryl was able to represent the Australian parliament at a conference in Lebanon during the visit of members of parliament of Lebanese descent to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the independence of Lebanon. As we were sure he would, and as was subsequently confirmed, he carried out that responsibility with great dignity.

I also want to thank you, Mr Speaker, and the former President of the Senate, Senator Kerry Sibraa, for the personal commitment which you both brought to this delegation. I was very conscious, as you know, of your intercession during the delegation's visit to ensure that the purposes of this parliament were fulfilled by it. I thank you and, of course, the former President of the Senate.

Among other things, the delegation visited Morocco. This was the first time a delegation from this parliament had visited Morocco and it was the first delegation of any kind to visit Morocco after the introduction of democratic elections, so that was particularly important. One particularly impressive element of the visit and the people we met and the discussions we had was the almost 1 1/2 hours we spent with Yasser Arafat, the Chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organisation, and a person I had identified, as would others, as being the personal symbol of the aspirations of the Palestinian people.
I commend the report. It is a report of substance and importance. I congratulate all those members of the delegation who contributed so magnificently.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trip undertaken by the delegation which was so ably led by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) covered an enormous area in the Middle East and North Africa. It is an area which we, as Australians, do not see much of primarily because it formed part of the old French empire or colonies and, as a consequence, the connections we had with it were almost wholly of our own making. Peter Stephens, as secretary of the delegation, played an enormous part in this area.

PARA.TAB: For my part, I was particularly keen and pleased to see the business opportunities in those areas, not only in Syria, which will be difficult, where we currently sell sheep, but also in Beirut where the reconstruction program is immense in every respect. I have not seen a city as devastated as that since Berlin. The rebuilding program, which will cost billions of Australian dollars over five to 10 years, presents enormous opportunities in communications, construction and general administration.

We moved on to Tunisia and, once again, saw a country with which Australia has very little contact and a small amount of trade. One Australian there is doing a very commendable job in agriculture and we ought to assist such people to pick up in the areas in which we can deliver considerable expertise, in particular, soil rejuvenation and management, and fencing and trees, to bring stability to the general landscape, which is certainly in need of it. Those areas of Tunisia which we visited where money has been invested in the rural sector, are very productive, but an enormous amount still needs to be done.

The same situation applied to Morocco, another country with which we have very little connection. But there are opportunities there in agriculture and in some of the manufacturing sectors to be taken up. I raise these matters because our representation in North Africa is run from Paris. It is quite a step to take in France, the associated EC countries and then go to North Africa, which is so much further down the line. In Morocco we are represented by the Canadian Embassy. As such, once again our connection is a step back from positive endorsement.

The Australian Trade Office in Paris seems to be doing a good job. The representative whom we met impressed me with his capacity to be able to get out and about and to put together a commercial program. But, if we are going to be fair dinkum about our investment and our involvement in North Africa, it would be necessary to have somebody based in Tunis or somewhere in that area to cement our relations. In itself, that will not help unless Australian business is prepared to make the extra effort to go into those areas. Business says that it will cost money, and certainly it will, but these businesses must be pushed along because there are millions of dollars in opportunities for us in those areas. I will not take up any more time of the House. I simply thank members of the committee and the secretary for their help.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is enormous goodwill towards Australia throughout the Middle East and the Maghreb. The sacrifice of young Australians in the liberation of the region in two world wars is remembered with affection and gratitude. The Australian government fully supports the Taif Accord signed between Lebanon and Syria at the conclusion of the civil war, which includes agreement on a framework for the withdrawal of Syrian forces from Lebanon and the extension of the Lebanese government's authority throughout Lebanon.

PARA.TAB: A major concern for the Lebanese government, expressed to the delegation on a number of occasions, is the continuing violence and security situation in southern Lebanon. There is an appreciation of Australia's even-handedness in the problems of the region and a special appreciation of our fulsome support for the relevant resolutions of the Security Council of the United Nations. All opportunities were taken to emphasise Australia's support for the peace process and the necessity for a just, lasting and honourable peace among all the people of the region.

Australia has made clear over several years that it opposes any activity in Lebanon by outside forces which compromises Lebanese sovereignty. In this connection Australia considers Israel should withdraw from Lebanon in compliance with UN Security Council resolution 425. The withdrawal of Syrian forces would also represent a major step towards full realisation of Lebanese sovereignty. As a result of the civil war the Australian Embassy in Beirut was closed in 1984. Lebanon is keen for Australia to reopen its embassy in Beirut as this would represent a vote of confidence in Lebanon's process of national reconciliation. This matter was raised repeatedly with the delegation.

Australia has advised the Lebanese government that it hopes conditions in Lebanon will soon permit an early resumption of resident representation. In the meantime, an Australian government office has been opened in the Mayflower hotel in Beirut to facilitate the provision of immigration and consular services to Australian and Lebanese citizens, and it has attracted a considerable number of clients. As far as the delegation is aware, the office has operated without any significant incidents since it opened. The delegation recommends that the Australian government give priority to re-establishing resident accreditation in Lebanon as soon as the security situation permits.

I was honoured to be part of the Australian parliament's delegation to the Middle East. It was particularly significant for me as both my parents were born in Lebanon. I was also delighted that I was able to represent the delegation and the Australian Parliament at the First Conference of Members of Parliament of Lebanese Descent on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of Lebanese independence which was held in Lebanon during the course of the delegation. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) ably led the delegation, and the delegation was well served by the secretary, Peter Stephens. I thank members of the delegation for their friendship. It was certainly enriched and enhanced during the visit. I commend the report to the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to the contributions already made by those members who were part of the delegation to the Middle East at the end of last year. I was one of those people privileged to be part of the delegation.

PARA.TAB: I would like to comment on a couple of issues. One that is of particular interest to me is the live sheep trade to the Middle East, and we had discussions in Syria relating to that issue. During discussions with the President of Syria he said they were certainly going to be looking at the protocol with regard to the entry of live sheep into Syria. I would ask that the department vigorously pursue that commitment given to us, and which is mentioned in the report.

I would also like to touch on the very valuable work done by ICARDA, the International Center for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas of the world. Australian farmers benefit greatly from the research that is done by ICARDA. It certainly impressed me, as someone from the land, that invaluable research is being done where all the wheats of the world originated from. We, as a nation, ought to make sure that we promote the work that is done there, particularly to our Australian wheat growers. I think they know very little of the work that is done on the exchange of genes in this very important area of the wheat industry.

I would like to touch very briefly on the situation in Lebanon. As we talk here today, it is rather distressing to see that troops are, once again, assembling on the border of Lebanon. It certainly disturbs me and it should disturb all Australians. In Beirut, we visited the Commonwealth war graves. It was particularly distressing to me and members of the delegation to see the desecration of the war graves in Lebanon. I hope that the recommendations in the report are carried out. We certainly look forward to the rebuilding of those war graves in Beirut. It is particularly significant that this report, which raises this issue, is presented today—D-day.

It was also very moving to be part of the Remembrance Day services that were held in Damascus while we were there. We met some Australian United Nations personnel at that ceremony. The work they do has not gone unnoticed by Australians, and particularly the Australian parliament. We ought to acknowledge the great work that these people do in the peacekeeping fields in what has been a very troubled part of the world.

People have already contacted my office in regard to trade opportunities that presented themselves to me and, indeed, to the delegation. I have written to Australian companies about the opportunities that exist.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Delegation to the 14th ASEAN AIPO Conference in Kuala Lumpur

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the 14th ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Organisation Conference, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, incorporating bilateral visits to the Republic of the Philippines and to Brunei Darussalam, 11 September to 1 October 1993. This report contains a detailed record of the delegation's bilateral visits to the Republic of the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei Darussalam. As I said in the preface to the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The visit by the Australian delegation to the AIPO conference and the bilateral visits to the Philippines and Brunei were among the most successful conducted by an Australian parliamentary delegation.

As everyone is aware, today is the 50th anniversary of the allied landing at Normandy. We are inevitably reminded at such a time of the strong ties of history which link us to Europe—ties of ancestry, culture and military sacrifice. But there is also an inevitability about the emergence of ties between Australia and Asia. Australian troops fought in Asia, as they did in Europe in defence of democracy in World War II; in the Malaya emergency; in confrontation in east Malaya; and in Vietnam. But there was in Asia the additional and direct need to protect our borders. There is no escaping the clear reality of geography.

PARA.TAB: During recent decades, the ties of trade between Australia and Asia have grown strongly. Over 60 per cent of our trade is now in the Asia-Pacific area. Eight of our 12 largest export markets and six of our major suppliers are located in that region. Two-way trade between Australia and the countries immediately to our north—the ASEAN nations—grew by 45 per cent between 1990 and 1992.

It is therefore essential that Australia participate fully in the affairs of the region. The ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Organisation, AIPO, provides an important avenue for us to develop our links with the ASEAN nations. There is no better means for promoting those links than regular face-to-face contact during which issues of mutual national interest can be discussed.

The bilateral dialogue session at the conference between the Australian delegation and representatives of each of the ASEAN nations covered a wide range of topics, including regional security, the development of APEC and the east Asian economic caucus, human rights, tourism and health issues. Importantly, the dialogue session was friendly as well as frank and I was struck by the goodwill that exists for Australia. It is something upon which we must continue to build.

There is no better way to demonstrate Australia's commitment to the region than by active participation in regional forums such as AIPO. AIPO is an important means of strengthening parliamentary institutions in the ASEAN countries. It is self-evident that it is in Australia's interests to support, through our continued participation, the excellent work of AIPO.

While in Malaysia for the AIPO conference, the delegation had a chance to undertake a number of bilateral meetings with Malaysian ministers and officials. We had a lengthy and very cordial meeting with the President of the Malaysian Senate. Remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, that over 100,000 Malaysians were educated in Australia—graduates of Australian universities—and the goodwill that exists within Malaysia towards Australia is there to be seen and appreciated. For myself, I appreciated the courtesies extended to us.

The prosperity that Malaysia's economic development has brought in recent decades is clearly evident in the skyline of its capital and in the modern factories which are everywhere apparent. The bilateral visits undertaken by the delegation to the Republic of the Philippines and to Brunei Darussalam were also highly informative and most effective in strengthening our relationship with those countries.

In the Philippines in particular we had an extremely busy program that enabled us to accomplish a great deal. We had discussions with a number of ministers and key officials and dialogue sessions with members of the Congress and the Senate, and were honoured with a detailed briefing by the President of the Philippines, President Ramos, the most distinguished leader of his country. We visited the islands of Cebu and Mindanao, which provided us with an opportunity of seeing the potential of those areas as well as the excellent achievements of Australia's aid program.

There is no doubting the special warmth of the relationship between Australia and the Philippines. Australia has provided considerable aid assistance to the Philippines—more than $30 million annually—which has been well targeted and effectively implemented. That aid has produced real benefits for the Filipino people and, let me tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is appreciated by them.

The Philippines needs assistance particularly with the protection and regeneration of its forests with land care. Australia's expertise in these areas would be very much welcomed by the Philippines government. The report also mentions our visit to the Philippines eagle breeding program in Mindanao. The eagle is the symbol of the Philippines, its independence and its pride, and whatever assistance Australia could provide to ensure the success of rescuing the eagle from extinction we should give willingly.

Australia could also provide technological assistance to the Philippines Commission on Elections, which is in the process of modernising its voting system. The people of the Philippines have fought to keep their country democratic. Australia should do what it can to help the democratic system in the country to function efficiently and honestly.

There are many opportunities for greater economic involvement by Australian companies in the Philippines. There are opportunities in infrastructure development, food, mining, sugar, tourism and marine industries and the provision of educational services and pollution control materials and methods. The Philippines have so far largely missed out on the rapid growth experienced by other ASEAN countries but the potential is clearly there, as is evidenced by the recent months of dramatic growth in the economy of the Philippines. In recent years the government of the Philippines has implemented many economic reforms and investment is welcomed. Those Australian companies which have invested in the Philippines are reaping the rewards.

Australia should become involved in the economic development of the ASEAN growth triangle of the southern Philippines, Brunei, Sulawesi, Kalimantan and Labuan. This region is very close to our northern shores. In eastern Malaysia, where Australian troops fought during the period of confrontation, there is much potential for Australian investment and trade and an Australian presence to work in cooperation with Malaysia. I commend to the parliament that there be a more active involvement in this area. Among the recommendations in the delegation's report is the suggestion that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) consider the establishment of regular direct air links between Darwin and Davao city on Mindanao and that measures be taken to increase commercial shipping links between Australia and the southern Philippines and, may I add, eastern Malaysia.

Our visit to Brunei demonstrated to the delegation that our relationship is on a sound footing. We were received with every courtesy and assistance. We held very useful discussions with ministers and officials across a wide range of portfolio areas. The report identifies some matters where difficulties have arisen and areas that warrant investigation. There is a certain lack of confidence on the Brunei side in the capacity of Australia to supply meat which has been killed according to halal requirements. This needs to be fully examined to correct the impediment to trade between our two countries.

There is much that could be done to develop education links between Brunei and Australia. A recent agreement for more cooperation and training in education was signed between the University of Brunei and James Cook University. A delegation of representatives from Australian education institutions could help provide and promote mutual understanding and could help develop twinning arrangements at the tertiary level. Although Brunei is not a large country, it does have considerable wealth. There are opportunities for Australian companies to become involved in the development of Brunei's infrastructure needs and in the provision of food and consumer goods.

The delegation was particularly pleased to be given a thorough tour of the oil and gas developments on which Brunei's wealth is based. By way of contrast, we also had the chance to travel into Batu Apoi forest reserve and to the Kuala Belong Field Studies Centre. It is clear that Brunei recognises the wealth of its flora and fauna as well as that which lies under its lands and seas.

On behalf of the delegation, I wish to thank the parliament and the government of the Philippines, the secretariat of AIPO, the parliament and government of Malaysia and the government of Brunei for their hospitality and courtesy. I wish to thank my colleagues who came with me on this delegation. Above all, I thank Mr Paul McMahon. As I say in the report:

SPEECH.PARA: He was most indefatigable in the performance of his duties and unfailingly courteous and of great assistance to the delegation at all times.

I thank the officers from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in the countries we visited and the officers of the Parliamentary Relations Office of our parliament who rendered us great service.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time I have available, I would like to echo the words of my colleague the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) particularly in thanking all those who made this such a successful delegation. I also emphasise the importance of Australia attending the AIPO conference. I believe we have a very important role to play in that conference. It is a role that will continue to grow and it will see us more actively participating in that organisation.

PARA.TAB: Without going into any detail, I will quickly mention a couple of the recommendations in the report which I believe should be taken up by the government. One relates to live cattle exports and the improvements that could be made there. The other is a question of better transport links. I think some of the questions on education should be investigated further because, as the honourable member for Herbert already pointed out, 100,000 people from Malaysia have already studied in Australia. We ought not underestimate the importance of developing those links further.

Our aid program in the Philippines is a credit to Australia and I hope that more people are made aware of that. Overall, the recommendations were very much about how we might enhance our relations with the countries of South-East Asia. All members of the delegation came away with the clear impression that we can continue to improve and build on the very good relations we already have there and that it is very much in Australia's interests to continue that work.

I would like to thank the officers of the embassies and the High Commission. I would also like to thank my fellow delegates. It was a very successful delegation in many ways. Finally, I would also like to thank Mr Paul McMahon who did such a marvellous job as secretary to the delegation.

PARA.TAB: That the House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes that the Anzacs who landed at Gallipoli on 25 April 1915 were instrumental in forging a new identity for Australia and further notes that although the landing was a lifetime ago the deeds of those Anzacs still speak a message of selfless service and sacrifice that will last forever;

(2)recognises that Anzac Day is a day to remember those who left their homes with a strong desire to return but did not, as well as those who did return but carried with them for the remainder of their lives the scars of their experiences;

(3)recognises that Anzac Day is a day to contemplate the spirit that moves men and women to serve, to suffer discomforts, dangers and fears and to risk their lives in defence of their country and in the pursuit of peace, justice and freedom;

(4)salutes on Anzac Day the spirit of the Anzacs and in paying tribute to them calls on Australians to dedicate themselves to striving for their country as the Anzacs did and to upholding the finest qualities of courage, commitment, endurance and mateship; and
(5)is of the view that the Australian Government should declare Anzac Day as Australia's National Day of Commemoration and that it be held on 25 April in each year and on no other day.

I indicate to the House that this motion carries the unanimous endorsement of the national RSL executive and is in fact RSL policy. As Anzac Day is currently subject to state acts, it is its legitimate request that Anzac Day should be a federal responsibility, should become Australia's day of national commemoration and should be held on 25 April each year. I make it clear that that request—which I regard as a very simple request and one that ought to be acceded to by this parliament—is not intended to compete or detract from any other national day.

PARA.TAB: On the occasion of the 75th anniversary of Anzac Day this House agreed on the significance of Anzac Day and endorsed the statement that the Anzac Day tradition and its commemoration, far from being a glorification of the waste of war or a celebration of militarism, represents a statement of values and ideals of service of enduring relevance to the people of Australia. The fact that Gallipoli claimed over 7,500 lives, that 46,000 Australians lie in the cemeteries of France and Belgium, that 18,000 Australian troops perished and have no known grave and that 152,000 were wounded changed forever Australia's perceptions of itself.

The loss of a generation, the talent wasted that can never be measured, the generation gap that struck at the very heart of Australian country towns, regions and cities, and the enduring tragedy for those thousands of Australian women whose grief and reparable loss had to be lived with day by day meant that the term `Anzac' wrote into our national lexicon concepts of sacrifice, commitment and mateship that have come to embody the finest qualities of our people. Anzac Day is now the day when we remember our war dead—all young and in all conflicts. It is a day which gives common purpose to all who were born here or who have come here and want Australia to be their country.

There would be no member of this parliament who has not been involved in Anzac Day ceremonies. There is one aspect of those ceremonies that we would do well to evaluate in this year of 1994. Why is it that the numbers of those attending these ceremonies have increased dramatically in recent years? Why do young Australian backpackers going overseas make constant visits to Gallipoli, almost in the nature of a pilgrimage? I believe that, in a sense, the parliament is lagging behind what is happening in the community. Australians, both here and overseas, on Anzac Day are voting with their feet.

As the ranks grow thinner, the audiences grow larger. One only has to attend a dawn ceremony and see the tear-stained faces of older generations and young people to realise that Anzac Day has inspired very real commitments in all generations of Australians.

In mentioning that, I think we have to pay a very real debt of gratitude to, and place on record, the role played by the Returned Services League of Australia in its staunch advocacy, defence and development of current Anzac Day ceremonies. This nation is very much in its debt and is the reason the motion comes before the House in this way. It would have been open to me, as it would have been to some of my colleagues, to advance it through the party room, but because Anzac Day is not and cannot be the prerogative of any one political party or any one individual, it has to be the responsibility of this parliament, both in the sense of the role of the individual member and the collective responsibility of the parliament itself.

The fact is that our parliamentary system, based on the Westminster tradition, is always and inevitably in an adversarial situation. The average Australian who listens to the parliamentary broadcasts or even attends this place could conclude that there are very few things about which we in this place are agreed. I believe there is at least one thing—that is, Anzac Day—about which this parliament, in its individual and collective membership, is agreed. It is necessary that we do that which I think, as I have already pointed out, the Australian people recognise.

The reality is that the ranks of the original Anzacs are very small indeed and that those who served in the last world war are reducing in number. I believe they are entitled to know that this parliament is committed to this motion. They are entitled to know that, for so long as this nation endures, 25 April will always be Anzac Day and it will be conducted within the concepts of this motion. They have earned the right to know that on this day the nation will pause and with a sense of commemoration recall the sacrifice for Australia, the loyalty and commitment to their mates and to the future generations of Australians. They are entitled to know.

Their sacrifices and their efforts are not simply going to become part of the dust of history. They have earned the right for Anzac Day to be writ large as Australia's national day of commemoration, a day in which all Australians can pause and commit themselves to the future of this great nation and its people. The Anzacs have earned no less.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to second the motion, which has been put forward to this House jointly by my colleague the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) and me, that Anzac Day should be declared Australia's national day of commemoration and that it should be held on 25 April in each year and on no other day.

PARA.TAB: From the motion it will be seen that we strongly believe that Anzac Day is a day to remember those who left their homes with a strong desire to return but did not, as well as those who did return but carried with them for the remainder of their lives the scars of their wartime experiences. The motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: (3)recognises that Anzac Day is a day to contemplate the spirit that moves men and women to serve, to suffer discomforts, dangers and fears and to risk their lives in defence of their country and in the pursuit of peace, justice and freedom;
This motion also calls on the government to salute Anzac Day, and it has the full support of the Anzacs. It states:

. . . in paying tribute to them calls on Australians to dedicate themselves to striving for their country as the Anzacs did and to upholding the finest qualities of courage, commitment, endurance and mateship;

Surely there would be no-one in this House of this parliament who could disagree with this motion. It is straightforward. It does not impose any encumbrance whatsoever to 26 January being regarded and maintained as Australia's national day.

PARA.TAB: Contrary to what certain people have interpreted this motion to mean, it intends that Anzac Day shall be an official day of commemoration—no more than that but, most importantly, certainly no less than that. This motion has unanimous support of the national executive of the Returned Services League. In fact, the official announcement of it was made on 14 April this year in the company of the National President of the RSL, Major General Digger James—I do not know him by any other name.

I have been informed by the New South Wales state president of the RSL that it has its `200 per cent support'. This motion had the support of the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating), and the unqualified support of the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), and the Leader of the National Party of Australia in this place, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). I would expect that on this day of presentation of the motion it would have the wholehearted support of all sides of this House. It is a strange coincidence that our motion is being put before the House on the 50th anniversary of D-day in Europe—itself a very significant date for the whole of Europe and, in fact, the world.

The mover of this motion, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports, has put the case most eloquently. I must pay tribute to him at this stage of my speech and say how pleased I was that he phoned me from Melbourne, and we have had many a discussion since then. Though I have supported this motion totally as a member of the opposition to show that there is a bipartisan approach to this in every possible way, I still have no hesitation in saying that this is his motion. Anything that I might add about Anzac Day has nothing to do with issues other than tribute paid to those Australians who gave of themselves and, in fact, themselves to defend our country. We have all attended Anzac Day services, dawn services in particular.

I realise one significant point, and that is that there are very few Anzacs left with us. It so happens that the veterans of the Second World War now have a declared average age in the mid-70s. One can see that in the not too distant future we shall have only memories of our veterans. Unless we take the trouble as a parliament to legislate to ensure that Anzac Day shall be celebrated for eternity in Australia as a day of commemoration on 25 April in each year, we will be doing a disservice to all those Australians who served their country in the armed services.

One could go on for hours with anecdotes of particular veterans and particular moving observations of Anzac Day itself. Suffice it to say that I have attended the dawn service of the Miranda RSL for 30 years. As each year passes, the dawn service, in particular, becomes more significant to the general public here and all around Australia. In fact, there is a growing interest in, and a search for knowledge about, Anzac Day and its significance by young Australians.

One more anecdote is that a number of years ago, when I was in Zimbabwe observing the election of Muzorewa, I was part of the celebration of Anzac Day which was held at that country's memorial to the fallen who had served and died for their country in the interests of peace. Our small service, with MPs from both sides of this House, was observed and shared by many of the local citizens of all political colours. This commemoration is worldwide, and it is deeply felt by all people of all races, colours, religions and backgrounds. I am sure that each member of this House can tell of equally moving and significant commemorative celebrations. As one grows older, one can only hope that this commemorative day will be celebrated by future generations of Australians as yet unborn.

I think it is appropriate at this time to bring a rather interesting point before the House which relates to the composition of the Australian forces which landed at Gallipoli on Anzac Day in 1915. One-third of those Australians who went to Gallipoli were migrants to Australia. I wonder whether honourable members had considered that such a large proportion of our fighting force which served Australia in that capacity 80 years ago were migrants. We must never allow that spirit to be lost. I hope that people will contemplate the spirit that caused people to be Anzacs and to fight for Australia since then. I believe the fact that such a large percentage of Australians at Gallipoli were migrants should do much to convince the present migrant population of Australia, among whom I count myself, to appreciate the reason for the continuing commemoration of the Anzac spirit.

I would like to finish by expressing my personal thanks to Senator David MacGibbon for assisting with this motion in the Senate. I trust that all honourable members in the House will support the motion. I conclude by quoting from today's editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald about the 50th anniversary celebration of D-day:

SPEECH.PARA: And the moral crusade to preserve the values of life and liberty is as necessary and as valid now as it was in the darkest hours of June 6, 1944.
Surely, then, it is as necessary for Australians to commemorate those who gave of themselves and even themselves on the dawn of 25 April 1915 now and well into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support this motion because there is a need to legislate. Anzac Day is a national day of commemoration. After I supported a previous motion moved by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) which related to this matter, a lot of people contacted me and asked, `Are you trying to do away with Australia Day?' I am not. One could say, though, that we ought to look at what has happened to Australia Day and what could happen to Anzac Day if we do not legislate in the way suggested by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports and the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie).

PARA.TAB: To many people, Australia Day denotes when Westminster decided that this land officially became its penal colony. It was not a great day for the convicts that came out here; nor was it a great day for Aboriginal people, and it is not very significant for a lot of ethnic groups here in Australia. But it is an important anniversary, and there is no intention at all, as I see it, in this motion to replace that day as a day of national significance.

The problems that we have had, for instance, with the states being unable to recognise 26 January as an official holiday for Australia Day, indicates what could happen with Anzac Day. It is clear that Australia Day is an anniversary, and an important one, but it is not seen as a national day of commemoration. Lest Anzac Day become a date to be varied when pressures are on, we need to support the motion—and we need to support it now. All ethnic groups and Aboriginal people have represented Australia during war. People who went overseas made a sacrifice for Australia, whatever their ethnic origin. People who stayed at home made a sacrifice, whatever their ethnic origin.

I can remember, as a child in Melbourne, living through the years of World War II with the blackouts and brownouts, with relatives reported missing and lost, and with all sorts of turmoil socially and economically in our country which suffered far less than other countries around the world. Women, as well as men, suffered at war and at wartime, whether in our country or overseas.

Anzac Day also represents a long association with New Zealand, an association which ought to be remembered and which is now maturing. With the CER and other agreements with New Zealand there has been a great maturing of our relationship. The liaison can be symbolised by that great liaison on Anzac Day. I hasten to add that we are not remembering a failure. Certainly, the landing at Gallipoli could be seen as a military failure, just as Vietnam could probably be seen as a military and perhaps political failure, depending on how we look at it. But we are not remembering failures when we remember Anzac Day and when we remember people who represented us in wartime. In many ways, we are remembering, thinking about and commemorating the birth of nationhood in Australia.

A previous prime minister had really represented people when he committed our nation, to the last man and the last shilling, to the war effort that was being fought by Britain and Europe. This changed; there was a maturing of our nation at Anzac Day and after it. It really was the genesis of new world links that were espoused by Curtin, and later Menzies. It was before the debate, for instance, about what should be our official flag. There was a vitriolic debate in the 1930s about whether it should be the Union Jack or the blue ensign, as we know it. It was the genesis of Australia seeing itself as a nation, not as part of another nation.

Anzac Day symbolised Australia's maturity as a nation, which continued, not just with Curtin and Menzies, but with efforts by Casey and Holt in Asia and by Whitlam in north Asia and South-East Asia. It symbolised our nationhood. Above all, Anzac Day is a commemoration of the lives which were given to make Australia a nation, given to defend not just Australia but freedom in the world. Whatever a person's ethnic origin—aboriginality made no difference—people were not prevented from representing their nation.

It is interesting that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in the D-day ceremonies, has quoted former Prime Minister Curtin, who said when he went overseas at that time in 1944, `They have thwarted an invasion by a great and powerful continental foe.' We are remembering the 1914-18 war, we are remembering the 1939-45 war and we are also remembering encounters such as Korea, Malaysia and Vietnam. We need to legislate for Anzac Day lest we forget the men and women who gave their lives; lest we forget our long association with the New Zealand people; lest we forget that 25 April symbolises Australia's coming of age; lest we forget all those who suffered at home, including loved ones; lest we forget how all of this was regardless of ethnic origins; and, above all, lest we forget the men and women who gave their lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) and seconded by the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie). It is significant that the House debate this motion at the same time as nations of the world are commemorating the allied landing at Normandy and the subsequent liberation of Europe from Nazi oppression. We are all aware that Australians served with distinction in the events leading up to and including D-day. It is fitting that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has travelled to that part of the world to pay tribute to those Australians who served their nation.

PARA.TAB: Anzac Day marks an earlier time when Australians found themselves storming a foreign shore for the defence of freedom. Whatever hindsight may say about the Gallipoli campaign, it is recorded in history and in the minds of succeeding generations of Australians that their forebears served with dedication and distinction on the Gallipoli peninsula. Anzac Day not only commemorates those who served at Gallipoli; it is a time to reflect and remember all those who served Australia in all conflicts, from the beaches of Turkey in the First World War to the jungles of Papua New Guinea in World War II and in every other conflict where Australians have served.

But it was in the First World War at Gallipoli and in many other battles that Australians, perhaps unknowingly, forged a new identity for their nation. The cost to our young nation of serving in that war was enormous. An entire generation of Australians was affected.

The distinguished war historian C.E.W. Bean has recorded that 331,781 Australians served overseas in the First World War. Of that number, 250,000 became casualties. More than 8,000 Australians died at Gallipoli. Of this, more than 5,000 were killed in action while others died later of wounds. In the first nine weeks at the Somme, 23,000 Australians died; at Ypres, 38,000; and at Bullecourt, 10,000. The list goes on. Of the 330,000 troops who fought, more than 70 per cent were casualties, which arguably constituted the highest rate per capita for any of the nations.

When we consider that in 1914 the population of Australia was approximately five million, we can see how the First World War had a tremendous effect on the nation's psyche. The average age of Australians who enlisted in Australia was between 14 and 18. This era marked one of the very few periods, if not the only period, in Australia's modern history when the population decreased. Not only did it affect those involved directly; we can only imagine the sadness that pervaded the nation as most families suffered the loss of a loved one or close friend.

Sadly, the march of time is taking its toll on those who served in the First World War and who were fortunate enough to return. I recall a speech I gave in 1985 when I informed the House that only 5,500 Australians who served overseas in the First World War remained alive. Today, almost a decade later, that figure has dwindled dramatically. It is estimated by the Repatriation Commission and the Department of Veterans' Affairs that by 30 June this year there will be only 550 World War I veterans left. According to the estimates, that would be a decrease of 400 since the same time 12 months ago.

It is obvious that time is running out for the veterans of World War I. These men and women did more to bring respect and recognition to Australia in the early stages of its history than anyone or anything else. Because of this, this motion is all the more appropriate.

It is my belief that in recent years Australians have renewed their interest in the history of their nation in all aspects, particularly in its war history. During my time as a member of parliament, I have seen this interest grow in my electorate. The number of those attending Anzac Day services has increased, even though veterans of all the conflicts in which we have been involved are becoming fewer in number. In the Riverina, I have noted that small children attend with older members of their family. Many of their parents have no direct connection with the First World War or Second World War; in fact, many were not born in Australia, but they realise how important this tradition is to Australia and Australians. It is interesting to note that many Australians who served in the First World War were immigrants or children of immigrants.

The recent burial of the Unknown Soldier has further increased national consciousness of the contribution made by those who served their nation in war. As with most parliamentary members, I was honoured to be present at the entombment of the Unknown Soldier in the Australian War Memorial. Our War Memorial is an institution all Australians can be proud of. It is the national symbol of sacrifice and is a reflection of the smaller memorials which can be found in most cities, towns and villages across this vast continent. In some places, these memorials—some modest, some grand—have outlasted the local population which has long vanished, and they further indicate the effect the Great War had on Australia. So they should stand proudly, if sadly, to commemorate the young Australians who gave their lives in service to their nation.

It is not only the First World War that is rapidly moving out of living memory; next year, we will celebrate the 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War. Around the world, the generation of national leaders who were born or served in World War II or before is retiring. I believe it is therefore time to formally recognise in this place the importance of ensuring that Anzac Day is our national day of commemoration. It should be recognised always on 25 April each year and on no other day. I would point out that it is not my desire or intention to compare the importance of Anzac Day with Australia Day or any other day. However, the sacred quality of Anzac Day and its symbolism must be retained in the interests of all Australians.

When we commemorate Anzac Day, we are not glorifying war. A glance at the horrific figures of death, debilitation and destruction which I have just recounted puts paid to any such notion. I was therefore rather dismayed to read yesterday that a so-called peace group, the Sydney Anti-bases Action Committee, said that ceremonies commemorating D-day glorified war and distorted history. We can imagine what such groups must think of Anzac Day and other days of commemoration. If we do not recognise and honour those who fought for our nation, our national identity would not be complete. It is easy today to take for granted the freedoms which the blood and sacrifice of previous generations have made possible for us to enjoy. Therefore, we must always remember Anzac Day and we must always treat our veterans with the respect they deserve.

The traditions laid down at Gallipoli and on other battlefields of the First World War were the standards that the fighting men and women who served in the Second World War and subsequent conflicts, such as Korea and Vietnam, and more recently our peacekeeping forces, have upheld with honour. As Australians, we have all been left a legacy of comradeship, courage and tenacity of which we should be proud and which allows us to hold our heads high wherever we travel throughout the world.

I am honoured to be able to speak to this motion today, which I hope will go some way to preserving for all time the day on which we remember those who, in my view, above all others, have placed their indelible mark on the pages of Australian history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year, in company with several of my colleagues who are about to speak or have spoken in this debate, an interesting incident occurred during an inspection by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. In an informal meeting with an officer from the RAAF in Darwin, when discussing the issue of Gallipoli and its significance to Australia, he indicated that history would have had a different record of Gallipoli if only the allied forces had moved in on the Dardanelles some months before the Turkish army was able to fortify that area.

PARA.TAB: It is an interesting insight into history and how our attitudes may have changed. It is said that on Anzac Day we are celebrating one of the great military defeats, but we all recognise that it is much more than that. I commend the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) for bringing forward this motion to the parliament. Unfortunately, I suspect that, for a number of reasons, this motion will not receive a great deal of media attention, the principal reason being that both opposition and government members support this motion. Because we have that level of bipartisan support, this debate will not attract the news and the media interest as would other debates. Nonetheless, it is significant that the views that are being expressed here are shared right across the parliament.

I was interested in the comments of the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) about the number of survivors left from World War I. It is understandable that there are fewer than 600. It is interesting also that when we go through the hundreds, or perhaps thousands, of honour rolls throughout this nation, particularly in small towns and villages, we see the same surname repeated time after time. When we recognise that we did suffer the highest per capita rate of casualties and deaths in World War I, as honourable members have pointed out, we can understand the debilitating effect that it had on those country towns and villages subsequent to World War I.

Recently I was able to make a suggestion to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) and also to the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) that perhaps we need to do something about some of the memorials around Australia. I believe this is a great opportunity for federal government, in conjunction with local government, to look at a program of putting funds into the restoration of the many memorials that we see around Australia, many of which are in very poor shape.

While perhaps people's views of memorials have changed dramatically over the years, the fact remains that they are an important part of our history. To that extent, they should not be forgotten. I would like honourable members to think about that proposition. If they believe there is merit in taking further the sentiments behind this motion, in not only making Anzac Day Australia's national day of commemoration but also looking at the possibility of enhancing and restoring some of our memorials that are scattered around the length and breadth of this country, it would be very much appreciated by the veterans and their families who have survived them.

It is true that Anzac Day should be seen by this nation as a national day of commemoration. Like the other speakers, I do not seek to replace Anzac Day with Australia Day as a day of significance to this nation. But the fact remains that we certainly would not get any great community division on a notion that the Australian government make a declaration as to Anzac Day being a national day of commemoration.

It goes beyond that. We all recognise that on Anzac Day we are celebrating the loss, the suffering and the contribution made by countless thousands of men and women in World War II as well as in subsequent battles. Irrespective of the rights and wrongs of our involvement in any of those wars, the fact remains that governments send people to wars. In that sense, we should always recognise the contribution that those individual men and women make for their nation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a mixture of sadness and humility, but with a large dose of national pride, that I add my unqualified bipartisan support to the motion of the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) on this historic day of 6 June, which was such a turning point half a century ago in World War II. For those Australians who were part of the D-day operations in Europe, it simply reinforced the well-established and respected Anzac spirit.

PARA.TAB: While it is said by some that Australia came of age as a nation at Anzac Cove in 1915, this remains a questionable viewpoint. Nevertheless, there is a modicum of truth in this perception. Although a nation surely does not need a major war only to achieve a sense of identity, the Gallipoli campaign gave all Australians the opportunity to identify positively with Australian forces fighting in a distinct campaign.

Anzac Day is remembered and revered for three reasons. Firstly, our troops showed courage and fortitude throughout the operation. We might have been defeated, but we did not run away. We withdrew in good order in a manoeuvre still regarded as one of the most skilfully conducted withdrawals in adverse conditions ever attempted. Secondly, throughout the Gallipoli campaign, Australian and New Zealand troops did everything which could reasonably be expected of them and more. The failure of the operation lay with its planners, not with the troops assigned to the job. Finally, and most importantly, the Gallipoli campaign was the first major campaign in which Australian troops fought as a body under their own commanders and carried the bulk of the operation on their own shoulders.

Some people may try to use this memory to glorify war or to justify later wars, but this is not the real significance of Gallipoli and the Anzac spirit at all. That significance lies in our understanding of the sacrifices and privations willingly undertaken by those who fought in the service of their country then and who have done so since. In 1991 a senior churchman in New South Wales said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australians have become too accepting of war and the Anzac Day celebrations have fuelled, in part, an all-too-easy alliance . . . I am very troubled about the war myth that seems to have gripped Australia and I believe it's all because we are conditioned by our tradition to accept war, and Anzac Day is part of that tradition—I know it is meant to remember sacrifice and bravery but in a subtle way it makes war seem acceptable to us.

I reject that simplistic view which shows how 25 April has been misrepresented by some. Anzac Day is not a glorification of war. It is a tribute to those who died for the nation and is a stark warning of the misery which war brings. It is the nation's collective funeral which should be treated with the dignity and deep reverence it deserves. It is a healing experience—a time when lost comrades can be remembered; a time when veterans can mix and talk with people who have suffered the trauma of battle; and a time when we draw together as a nation to remember those who have served and/or fallen to maintain our democratic ways.

PARA.TAB: Just as Australia Day on 26 January celebrates national unity, acknowledges our nation builders and is the occasion on which our pioneers are honoured, so it is entirely appropriate that we have a separate occasion to honour the men and women who fought to preserve the work of those pioneers. However, common to both Anzac Day and Australia Day is a sense of national unity and purpose.

I ask that all of us in this place today honour that spirit of progress and understanding. We should particularly pay tribute to the memory of those who have paid the supreme sacrifice since Federation. In doing so, I hope that all of us will recommit ourselves to the Australian national ethos and its enhancement. I salute the honourable member for Melbourne Ports for his initiative. I commend his motion to the House, particularly part (5), which calls for the declaration of Anzac Day on 25 April as Australia's national day of commemoration. In this way, the spirit of Anzac will live on in legislative form. Mr Deputy Speaker, lest we forget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very proud to support the motion moved today by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding). I am a privileged Australian and, like many members of this House, I have never had to fight a war. I have not known the tragic loss of parents, sons or daughters on a battlefield; nor have I suffered with family members who have carried with them for the remainder of their lives the emotional or physical scars of their war experience.

PARA.TAB: My children have grown up in an era of peace, an era in which justice and freedom were taken for granted. However, this does not in any way diminish my respect and my admiration for and especially my gratitude to those Australian men and women whose selfless service and sacrifice made such an era possible. Those are the feelings that so many Australians want to express every Anzac Day. We want to pay our respects not only to the Anzacs but to all the men and women who left their families, their jobs and their country to fight wars in other places. We want to say thank you.

We want to salute the spirit that moved them but, more than that, we also want to express our pride in being Australian because somehow the idea of being Australian is inextricably linked with the Anzac legend. The very first commemoration of Anzac Day was held only one year after the Gallipoli landing. One might wonder, with the Great War still to rage for another two years, why a special day was set aside to mark a battle fought on the other side of the world, a battle acknowledging a defeat.

It was celebrated with unprecedented fervour and thrill. To understand this, one has to understand our national psyche at the time. The Commonwealth was only 14 years old: a federation of states divided by jealousy and suspicion, founded in such totally different ways—from the squalid dumping ground at Sydney Cove for British felons to Colonel Light's planned city in South Australia for middle-class free settlers. A new nation had certainly been formed, but it had no traditions and no symbols of its new identity. The AIF troops doing their training in Egypt still thought of themselves as Victorians or Queenslanders or New South Welshmen.

It was also widely believed that we did not have the discipline necessary to build and deploy a national army. In fact, Australians regarded themselves as inferior and second-rate. So when those at home first heard about what had happened at Gallipoli, about the superb skill and outstanding courage of the AIF and the accolades of the world, they were filled with amazement and thrilled with a great outburst of national pride.

The dispatch from war correspondent Ashmead Bartlett describing the raw colonial troops as heroes worthy to fight side by side with the heroes of Mons, the Aisne, Ypres and Neuve Chapelle was read out to school children throughout Australia by order of Prime Minister Billy Hughes. Whatever the tragedy of the slaughter or the arguments over the ineptness of the campaign, nothing could detract from this sense of pride—nor has it since. This was the real birth of our nationhood and this was when we were able to define the values we cherish as a nation.

The gallantry of the Anzac troops—nine Victoria Crosses were awarded—is not alone enough to explain the overwhelming sense of national identity that Gallipoli engendered. It is the particular nature of that quality that is important. Gallipoli was fought in circumstances that created instant legends. To the storming of the cliffs and the confusion and ferocity of the hand-to-hand fighting, the Australian troops responded with utmost daring, endurance and devotion to their mates.

The Anzacs fitted our image of ourselves as a daredevil people, enduring any hardship and sticking by one's mates at all costs. They are the values that have become enshrined in our national psyche and I believe they hold true today. Australia earned its nationhood and gained its identity at Gallipoli.

Participation in Anzac Day ceremonies is increasing all over Australia. The 75th anniversary at Anzac Cove attracted an amazing number of young people who have known nothing of war, who stood silent and were moved in the Gallipoli dawn. Little country towns have been making Anzac Day the focus of their community celebrations since 1916. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Anzac Day is indeed, as all who have spoken in this debate have said, a unique day. It is unique in the Australian calendar in many respects, and it is unique in the world. Ironically, as has also been pointed out in this debate, Gallipoli was a defeat in military terms, but it was certainly a victory for Australia's nationhood. It has become an event which epitomises what Australia is as a nation.

PARA.TAB: At Gallipoli a truly multicultural force fought and died together. Anzac Day unites us in a unique way at a time when many things divide us. Anzac Day imbues in all Australians a sense of pride and nationalism. Each Anzac Day we pay homage not only to those original Anzacs but to all who died or were disabled in their service to this country. In fact, they adorn our nation's history. Their hope was for the freedom of mankind. We remember with pride their courage, their compassion and their comradeship. They served on land and sea and in the air in many diverse parts of the world.

Those who fought and died did so because they believed our future was worth fighting for. For them it was an ideal. Perhaps it is time for us as a nation to evaluate whether or not we have attained this ideal. I believe that in many respects we have fallen short.

The bipartisan support for this motion is encouraging. I accept that the motion is moved in good faith by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), and I have no reason to doubt his true commitment to this cause. I do, however, question the credibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on this issue. In our commemoration, we should not distinguish in any way where or how our servicemen died or suffered. There is no sense in which we should diminish the quality of the supreme sacrifice, whether it was at Gallipoli, the Western Front, the deserts of Sinai or the jungles of Vietnam. The suffering of those who mourned is no more or less great, or their pride of knowing that their kin died with their mates and for their mates, for king or queen and country. Wherever they died, each and every man or woman adorns our nation's history.

The Prime Minister also threatens to change our Australian flag. Yet those who died in serving their country and to whom we pay homage on Anzac Day fought and died under this flag. To most veterans, talk of changing this flag is extremely offensive.

I support the motion. I ask the mover to, if he gets the opportunity, clarify one aspect in part (5) of it. As I have said, I cast no aspersions on him but we are being asked here to support that Anzac Day should be Australia's national day of commemoration, and I want to be sure that there is to be a strict connotation placed on that word so that on Anzac Day we shall never be diverted from anything other than a commemoration of our war dead; that it will not be confused, as it may be over time, with commemorating other things. I support the motion with the proviso that we are talking specifically about 25 April each year being a national commemoration of our war dead and a special time of saying thankyou to those who served and died and to the many who served and survived but have suffered since.
