DEBATE.TITLE: NEW DELHI STATEMENT ON TIBETAN FREEDOM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), I move:

PARA.TAB: That:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)this Parliament acknowledges and accepts as a resolution of this House the statement known as the New Delhi Statement on Tibetan Freedom.

(2)a copy of this resolution be forwarded to His Holiness the Dalai Lama and the Tibetan government in exile, presiding officers of the two Houses of the Indian Parliament, all Parliaments whose members are participating in the New Delhi Statement on Tibetan Freedom and the Chairman of the Chinese National People's Congress.

Unfortunately, due to unforeseen circumstances, the honourable member for McEwen is unable to be with us this afternoon to move this motion and asked me to do so on his behalf. I say from the outset that I hope I am able to do him justice in putting this motion before the House.

In March of this year in New Delhi, 40 parliamentarians from some 25 countries gathered under the auspices of the All Party Indian Parliamentary Forum for Tibet to discuss issues relating to Tibet. At the end of their three days of deliberations they made a statement that is now known as the New Delhi Statement on Tibetan Freedom. This statement is over three pages long and, unfortunately, could not be incorporated in the motion moved by the honourable member for McEwen. I understand that it also might be outside the Speaker's guidelines to have it incorporated in Hansard. If so, I seek leave to table the statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that honourable members will take the opportunity to look at the points outlined in the statement. There are 12 items of a factual nature and 12 items of an action nature listed by the gathering. The first point in the statement, which I bring to the attention of honourable members, is:

PARA.TAB: Tibet was a separate, independent and sovereign nation prior to its invasion and subsequent occupation by the People's Republic of China.

SPEECH.PARA: That is something that, from time to time, has been a matter of dispute between the two parties to this discussion. It is one of the stumbling blocks in trying to get both Tibetan and Chinese officials together to have meaningful dialogue. I was interested to have quoted to me a portion of a perpetual treaty which was referred to in the Dalai Lama's autobiography. The treaty, which dates back to AD 821 or AD 822 and is displayed at Jokhang temple in Lhasa, is between the Tibetan and the Chinese people and acknowledges and confers together for the alliance of their kingdoms. At that time the Great King of Tibet and the Great King of China, being in the relation of nephew and uncle, put together this alliance. The quote from the treaty as set out in the autobiography states:

They have made and ratified a great agreement. Gods and men will know it and bear witness so that it may never be changed; and an account of the agreement has been engraved on this stone pillar to inform future ages and generations.
In part, the treaty says:

Tibet and China shall abide by the frontiers of which they are now in occupation. All to the east is the country of great China and all to the west is, without question, the country of great Tibet. Henceforth on neither side shall there be waging of war nor seizing of territory. If any person incurs suspicion he shall be arrested, his business shall be inquired into and he shall be escorted back. Now that the two kingdoms have been allied by this great treaty, it is necessary that messages should once again be sent by the old route to maintain communications and carry the exchange of friendly messages regarding the harmonious relations.

Unfortunately, as we know, some 40 years ago, the Chinese entered Tibet and, since that time, have occupied what they now refer to as the Tibetan autonomous region. The other aspect that the New Delhi statement goes to has been the great deal of population transfer that has been carried out by the Chinese. Part 4 of the statement says:

PARA.TAB: Chinese policies in Tibet, through official incentives, have encouraged the settlement there of 7.5 million ethnic Chinese designed to marginalise the six million Tibetan people.

SPEECH.PARA: Part 5 of the statement says:

PARA.TAB: The major areas of eastern Tibet and north-eastern Tibet have already become dominated by ethnic Chinese. The consequences of the massive influx of Chinese people is becoming clear in central Tibet. For example, of the 12227 shops in Lhasa (excluding the Barkhor areas) only 300 are now owned by Tibetans.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement outlines various reports from parliamentary delegations, including this parliament and the European parliament and reports of independent international human rights organisations, such as Amnesty International and Asia Watch, which have confirmed the continued abuse of Tibetan human rights and denial of fundamental freedoms by the Chinese authorities.

PARA.TAB: The statement acknowledges that His Holiness the Dalai Lama and the Tibetan government-in-exile have, over the years, proposed constructive initiatives to solve the Tibetan problem peacefully. Part 9 of the statement indicates that the permanent tribunal people's session on Tibet in 1992, the international lawyers conference in Tibet in 1993 and the conference of European parliamentarians on Tibet in 1993 have each confirmed the right to self-determination of the Tibetan people enjoyed by them under international law. Part 12 of the statement states:

China's destruction of the Tibetan environment through indiscriminate deforestation and mining is leading to ecological imbalance with potential consequences affecting nearly half of the world's population.

SPEECH.PARA: When I had the opportunity back in 1988 to speak in this place on a similar motion, I found that one of the most disturbing actions of the Chinese government in Tibet. In the action items of the statement, part 2 expresses concern `at the continued maintenance of Chinese nuclear installations in Tibet and reports of the conduct of the testing of nuclear weapons and the alleged dumping of nuclear wastes'. And so it goes on.

PARA.TAB: There are two main concerns that I bring before the parliament in speaking to this motion. One is the continued reference to human rights violations that have been well documented and that continue to be well documented. The year 1994 has been proclaimed by the Tibetan government-in-exile as the international year of Tibetan women. The April-May 1994 issue of the Tibetan News quotes an interview with a representative from the Australia-Tibet Council and four nuns who have had to flee Tibet through Nepal to Dharamsala in India because of the types of religious persecution that continue to be carried out.

Sometimes the discussions and debates that have occurred in this place have not touched directly upon the question of independence, which is the stumbling point. What they have touched upon is that one of the basic rights of Tibetan people is that they be allowed to be involved in self-determination and to enter into peaceful protest about the issue of independence. This clearly has not been the case since 1949 and the occupation.

Late last year, as the leader of the parliamentary delegation to the Indian subcontinent, whilst we were in Delhi we were able to meet with people at the central Tibetan administration, including the Vice-Chairman of the Assembly of Tibetan People's Deputies. We were able to have discussions about the progress of representations with the Chinese government, or should I say at that stage and still now, the lack of progress. We are encouraged through this motion and the continuing activity arising out of the Delhi conference that parliaments throughout the world should use their power and influence to sit down with the Chinese government to try to encourage them, as we see the changes throughout the world, to fulfil their obligation to at least address some of the issues that are being raised and identified and allow for independent inquiry of those things so that the Tibetan people can be seen to have the basic human rights that have been denied them returned to them.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Before I start I would like to acknowledge, if my eyes do not deceive me, that the representative of the Dalai Lama and the People's Republic of Tibet and government-in-exile in Tibet is in the gallery with us today. It seems to me that on most occasions when one rises in this place it will inevitably be to address matters of important domestic concern. Probably that is quite rightly the case. As members of a democratically elected parliament, our major concern and priority must continue to be how best to serve our electorates and our nation, particularly the communities we represent.

PARA.TAB: However, as a multitude of social and economic domestic issues arise and various interest groups jostle and compete for priority and attention for their particular issues and matters that worry and give them concern, we can sometimes be in danger of forgetting some of the bigger issues in the world. Just as we have rights and responsibilities as representatives of Australian citizens, so too do we have obligations according to our global citizenship. It is in this context that I rise today and support the motion of the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), which was delivered on his behalf by the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins); that is, that this parliament accept the New Delhi statement on Tibetan freedom, a statement flowing from the World Parliamentarians Convention on Tibet which was held in New Delhi between 18 and 20 March this year. That New Delhi convention, as we have heard, received parliamentary representatives from 25 countries.

It is important, I believe, that emphasis be given to the international context which underpins this motion, for sustained pressure from the international community is paramount if ever a peaceful solution to the unwanted Chinese occupation of Tibet is to be found. We must always maintain the hope that a solution is indeed possible, as noted, I believe, by the chief organiser of the convention, Mr George Fernandes MP, in his welcoming address. He said that, if the Israelis and Palestinians could finally sit across a table and find a solution, there is every reason to believe that Tibetan freedom is indeed possible.

I was honoured to meet the Dalai Lama when he came to this country. I met him not far from this spot, just upstairs in the mural hall. I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would have been one of those who were also there. The Dalai Lama is indeed a gentle and courageous man who has been carrying on a long and sustained fight in incredibly difficult circumstances.

In these sorts of situations there are often difficulties for countries like Australia when we start to look at justice in terms of human suffering and human rights in small countries and compare how we stand with our views of some of the bigger neighbours that are causing those difficulties. We often find ourselves looking at whether, as a country, we are concerned about trade or human rights. On one hand, we might be talking about our future long-term relationship with China but, on the other hand, not be impressed with what that country has done in Tibet. There are similar concerns with Indonesia and East Timor; and that has been topical over just this last weekend with the John Pilger program on television. For governments, that can cause a problem.

I know for some of the honourable gentlemen opposite, when we have talked about things like East Timor and yet had a lot of other formal relations with that country, Indonesia, it has caused some problem. But it seems to me that ultimately we come to the point where we cannot put dollars before human rights. So it is important that we stand up to be counted on these issues. I am sometimes tempted to think the Dalai Lama is not dissimilar to Gandhi in terms of his peaceful approach to the problems besetting his country. But, of course, Gandhi had one particular advantage that the Dalai Lama does not have, and that was tens of millions of population. A peaceful demonstration by tens of millions tends to have more impact than just a handful of millions.

The other issue of which Australia needs to be aware when we stand up and talk about our concerns in other people's countries is that sometimes we run the risk of having the finger pointed at us with the way we treat our indigenous people and some of the human rights they do not really receive in full measure. That is all the more reason, if we want to talk about what happens elsewhere, that we need to do something about our own indigenous population.

It is also perhaps worthy of note to look at the world action that took place in that international conflict in the Gulf War not so very long ago, and the world's inaction when it comes to the issue of China and Tibet. Whilst the invasion and occupation in 1949 of Tibet by communist China and the subsequent campaign by Tibetans to re-establish their freedom and sovereign right are all well documented, of course, I would like to point out some highlights of various aspects of the struggle which I think are noteworthy.

Firstly, as with any form of human rights abuse, the particular human rights abuses being carried out against Tibetans by the Chinese regime are to be condemned by the international community. Let us make no mistake that such actions do indeed constitute very real abuses of human rights. For example, they take the form of enforced assimilation through population transfer. That is not taking the Tibetans out; that is shipping Chinese nationals into Tibet. We have seen something like 7.6 million Chinese moved into the country, which now completely swamps the six million Tibetans.

There is racial discrimination in employment, accommodation and education. For example, 60 per cent of places in schools are reserved for Chinese. There is confiscation of Tibetan land. There is coerced sterilisation of Tibetan women. If Tibetans produce more than two children, they incur a fine and their citizenship is withdrawn. The withdrawal of citizenship means that they lose their identity papers, their ration cards, their kids cannot go to school and they are not allowed to work. There is no freedom of expression. Instead—and the authority for this is a well-respected organisation called Amnesty International—harassment, arbitrary detention and torture are commonplace.
Secondly, I would like to draw to the attention of the House the words of the Dalai Lama. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our struggle is not an ideological one . . . Tibetans do not oppose reforms, communism and changes. We don't harbour ill-feeling against the Chinese people as such. We are fighting for our rights against the illegal occupation of our country by an alien force.

This dignified and tolerant response by one of the world's truly great leaders comes after, mark my words, 44 years in exile, the death of over 1.2 million fellow countrymen, the destruction of more than 6,000 monasteries and historical sites and years of continuous and systematic population transfer of ethnic Chinese into Tibet leading to a situation that I mentioned before where Tibetans are now a minority in their own land. It seems to me that we in the Western world have much to learn from the Dalai Lama about human tolerance.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, it is clear that a conciliatory, non-violent approach has been pursued by the Tibetan government in exile in its dealings with the Chinese government. In accepting Deng Xiaoping's statement in 1979, after 20 years of no contact, that all things `except for the independence of Tibet' are negotiable, Tibetans have expressed their willingness to try to come to some agreement by putting forward suggested solutions within this criterion.

However, in spite of this overwhelmingly generous concession in relation to independence, China has refused to play ball. Instead, Chinese authorities have undertaken to continue their population transfer and their assimilationist policies and to use international forums to publicise China's `claim' to Tibet. Therefore, it is imperative that we, as global citizens, do everything in our power to bring pressure to bear in support of freedom for Tibet. There could be no ideal more worthy of our support than that of independent democratic freedom.

Fourthly, I would like to pay tribute to the Indian government because I believe that its continuing assistance to the Dalai Lama and the Tibetan government-in-exile has been absolutely crucial. That support has been extensive and often under extremely difficult conditions and circumstances in its own relationships with China. In conclusion, I commend the honourable members for McEwen and Scullin for bringing this motion forward. I think we have to stand up and be counted on human rights issues regardless of any embarrassments for governments. There is a clear situation in Tibet of abuse of human rights by China and a clear case of removal of Tibet's own sovereignty. These actions are to be condemned. I urge the House to strongly support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1986 I visited Tibet. I believe that at that time I was one of the very few members of this House ever to have had the opportunity and pleasure of going there. I went there in my capacity as a member of parliament and I think I was also the first Australian member of parliament to visit there. I visited Lhasa, Xigaze and other areas of Tibet. The friendliness and openness of the people is something I really did not expect.

PARA.TAB: I had been in China for a week or two before I flew into Lhasa. The view we saw when we landed at Lhasa airport, which is 30-odd miles from the city of Lhasa, was quite outstanding. From the airport we travelled along a long valley and took a right-hand turn, and away in the distance was Potala Palace. It is quite magnificent, and I can assure the House that it is an impression that will last with me forever. Back in 1986, there were huge numbers of Chinese people in Lhasa itself. Tibetan people, even then, were outnumbered by the Chinese—a lot of whom had been transported in there to build up the hotels and the infrastructure around the city.

I will never forget one of the hotels at Xigaze. It was a huge hotel with a huge foyer of green marble. It was very impressive. We were on the third floor and as there were no lifts we had to walk up the stairs. In the very thin air it was very hard to do.

However, Tibet is having some little problems as it tries to cope with an influx of visitors who want to have a look at this beautiful country and with the way the Chinese have virtually overrun it. The Chinese claim, of course, that it is part of China and, I believe, this came about through a marriage of a Chinese princess some centuries ago.

We should all look up to the Dalai Lama, and all our leaders should make certain that they take a leaf out of his book. He won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to bring about a peaceful resolution of the problem of restoring Tibet's freedom to a truly autonomous region. When asked why he was not hard line and why he did not promote violence, he said:

Quite often they say, `The Chinese know only force.' It's not a generational matter. There are many, many elder Tibetans who think violence is the ultimate answer, too. Sometimes, perhaps, I think among the younger generation, there is more attraction towards Yasser Arafat or the mujihadeen in Afghanistan. They often tell me, `Oh, look at them. Through violence, there is more publicity, more support from the outside world'.
My fundamental belief is that human nature lies in gentleness. Human nature is compassionate, is affectionate. Therefore, using violence is against human nature.

. . . Tibetans and Chinese have to live side by side in the future. In the past, we lived like that. So in order to live in a friendly, peaceful and neighbourly way, while we are carrying out this freedom struggle, we must pursue non-violence, so that our struggle will not affect our long, long friendship.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe there is any other leader in this world today who would have said those words. Even after all of the terrible things that have happened in Tibet, this man is certainly someone from whom, as I have said before, all of us can learn a great deal. In his autobiography he said:

Chairman Mao once said that political power comes from the barrel of a gun. He was only partly right. Power that comes from the barrel of a gun can be effective only for a short time. In the end, people's love for truth, justice, freedom, and democracy will triumph. No matter what governments do, the human spirit will always prevail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In May 1993 communist Chinese authorities adopted the following dual strategy in an attempt to suppress Tibetan resistance: firstly, to transfer even greater numbers of Chinese into Tibet in order to make it demographically impossible for Tibetans to continue to oppose Chinese occupation; and, secondly, to manipulate important international Tibet supporters and Tibetan religious persons and to infiltrate religious institutions in order to publicise China's claim to Tibet and to create discord in the Tibetan movement.

PARA.TAB: Tibetan people are understandably distressed by the increasing threat to their culture and civilisation. They are placing their faith in international efforts to persuade the Chinese government to enter into serious negotiations with His Holiness the Dalai Lama and his representatives towards finding a peaceful solution to the Tibetan issue.

Last week I was privileged to meet with the Dalai Lama's representative in Australia. We spent about an hour discussing the situation in Tibet. I was shocked at what I heard. I am therefore pleased to speak in support of the motion before the House, to express my deep concern about the human rights abuses which have been committed in Tibet and to support the Dalai Lama and his representatives for continually rejecting the use of violence. Quite frankly, it is amazing that the Tibetan people have been able to greet the aggression and the genocide in their homeland with such a peaceful approach.
The situation in Tibet has often been debated in this place. In 1992 the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) while speaking to a similar motion said:

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the history of Tibet, it has always been part of greater China.

Generally I would like people to resolve their own affairs, but I am a realist who has to live in the real world and it is quite clear that China will never forgo its sovereignty over Tibet.I do not agree with the honourable member for Kalgoorlie in this matter or, for that matter, on many other issues. Tibetans will also disagree with the account of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. Unfortunately, while many nations and ethnic groups would like to be in a position to resolve their own affairs, they are not, and therefore need the support and encouragement of others, such as the members of this House.

PARA.TAB: Tibetans have not had the attention of the international media which has been bestowed on other global hot spots such as Kuwait and Bosnia-Herzegovina. This is partly because of the control of communist China. Also, unlike Kuwait, Tibet has no oil and, unlike European countries, Tibet is perceived as being of no strategic importance to the major world powers. It is a tragedy when those considerations determine whether or not the people of a particular nation get a fair go.

Tibet lies at the centre of Asia, or the roof of the world, on a mountain plain at the back of the Himalayas. In 1949 communist China invaded Tibet and the Dalai Lama fled to India in 1959 when he was aged 24. The spiritual leader of Tibet and Nobel Peace Prize winner visited Australia in 1992 and impressed many with his dignity and wisdom. The Dalai Lama has declared his willingness to enter into negotiations with Chinese officials and has put forward proposals which fall within the framework for negotiations proposed by Deng Xiaoping; however, China has refused to enter into discussion. It always seems to be a question of China moving the goalposts.

Like other members of this House, I am well aware of China's economic significance in the world and of the importance of building our relationship with China; however, we cannot ignore the facts of what has happened in Tibet. The facts are that, in close to 40 years of Chinese occupation, the Tibetan people have suffered brutal and barbaric treatment. Amnesty International documents many reports of inhumanities which have occurred in Tibet and it is estimated that more than 1.2 million Tibetans have been killed. The autobiography of the Dalai Lama, Freedom in Exile, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The methods the Chinese used to intimidate the population were so abhorrent that they were almost beyond the capacity of my imagination. It was not until I read the report published in 1959 by the International Commission of Jurists that I fully accepted what I had heard: crucifixion, vivisection, disembowelling, dismemberment of victims was commonplace. So too was beheading, burning, beating to death and burying alive, not to mention dragging people behind galloping horses until they died or hanging them upside down and throwing them bound hand and foot into icy water. And, in order to prevent them shouting "Long live the Dalai Lama" on their way to execution, they tore out their tongues with meat hooks.

I would like to commend the Dalai Lama and the people of Tibet on their promotion of peace and non-violence despite the shocking treatment of their people. I think every member of this House, on both sides of the chamber, should support this motion because the treatment of the people of Tibet has been absolutely outrageous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my voice in support of this motion before the House. I am greatly saddened by the fact that such little progress has been made in this matter. There has been an attempt by a number of governments throughout the world and by various bodies at the United Nations to try to raise with the present government of the People's Republic of China the situation with respect to the Tibetan people and their continuing oppression.

PARA.TAB: I think it is indicative of this point that this convention of world parliamentarians on Tibet was held in New Delhi, India. At that meeting a statement was formulated which contains some very important clauses. I understand the statement has been tabled but, with your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will refer to a couple of key clauses. It is sad that the government of China is continuing a policy which involves an attempt to undermine and destroy the culture and traditions of the Tibetan people. This is quite an intolerable and an unacceptable situation and one which has to be reversed. Clause 4 of the statement states:

Chinese policies in Tibet, through official incentives, have encouraged the settlement there of 7.5 million ethnic Chinese designed to marginalise the six million Tibetan people, destroy the traditional Tibetan landscape, and threaten the Tibetan people's distinct national, cultural and religious identity.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that a people threatened by these kinds of manoeuvres would, in previous times, have rebelled in a very violent fashion. But if we look at the long history and traditions of the Tibetan people, especially at that advanced luminary of Buddhism, the Dalai Lama, we can see why he has continued to insist on peaceful and non-violent forms of protest in relation to what has happened to his people. It is in this sense that two paragraphs of the resolution agreed to by the convention should be emphasised. Paragraph (iii) states:

PARA.TAB: Support the non-violent efforts of His Holiness the Dalai Lama and the Tibetan Government-in-Exile to solve the Tibetan problem, particularly the Dalai Lama's campaign to make Tibet a zone of Ahimsa (non-violence) through demilitarisation, protection of Tibet's natural environment and the commencement of earnest negotiations between Tibetan and Chinese representatives on the future of Tibet.

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph (iv) states:

PARA.TAB: Urge the Chinese Government to respond positively to the above initiatives of His Holiness the Dalai Lama and the Tibetan Government-in-Exile for negotiations without preconditions to solve the Tibetan problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The very advanced religious tradition of Buddhism of the Tibetan people has, in a sense, embedded into national consciousness the idea that non-violence is the way to proceed. For that reason the Tibetan people have not resorted to an armed struggle to try to achieve their self-determination and freedom. But that does not mean that the international community should ignore the plight of the Tibetan people. The fact that there is no armed struggle does not mean that the Tibetan people are not oppressed, especially if we understand the reports of Amnesty International and other bodies about the level of oppression, torture and of judicial killing in Tibet. I urge honourable members to support the motion put forward by the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland). (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, I will add a few remarks to the ones I made previously on this matter as we have a few moments left in the debate. One thing that I do not think has come out in this debate is the fact that, with the occupation in Tibet, we have obviously, and quite rightly, concentrated on the action against individual human beings. It is also interesting to note that very considerable environmental damage is occurring in that country through indiscriminate deforestation and mining.

PARA.TAB: Part of the statement that came out of New Delhi specifically referred to those actions. It said that they were leading to ecological imbalances, with potential consequences affecting nearly half of the world's population. I do not know how accurate that statement is, but it is a further matter for concern.

—In contrast to the British House of Commons, in Australia's House of Representatives there seems to often be a lack of confidence in the impartiality of the chair. This has not always been justified, but results in a lack of respect for the institution of Speaker. The subsequent disorderly conduct which results distracts from the standing of parliament and further lowers community respect for politicians in this country and the political process.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the traditions of Westminster do not operate in Australia. Therefore, unlike in the House of Commons, the Speaker of the House of Representatives must remain a member of his political party and fight to retain his endorsement and seat in this House and the speakership. Under these circumstances, even well-intentioned Speakers would find it difficult to act continually in an impartial manner. Labor Speakers would have to have one eye on the precedent of Speaker Cope in the best forgotten Whitlam years.

I urge honourable members of this House to consider seriously the benefits of the Westminster convention, as it provides the most effective means of removing a Speaker from party politics. Major elements include that the Speaker shall refrain from partisan controversy inside or outside the chamber; be unopposed at general elections by the major parties; cast his or her vote in accordance with the established conventions, which avoid any judgment on the merits of the question; and resign from the House on resigning from the speakership. This arrangement would give the Speaker the political neutrality required to command the respect of honourable members on both sides of this House. After all, the speakership is, as far as the parliamentary institution is concerned, the most important office in the House of Representatives.
