DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Fairbairn, Hon. Sir David Eric, KBE DFC

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House expresses its deep regret at the death, on Wednesday 1 June 1994, of Sir David Eric Fairbairn KBE DFC, member of the House of Representatives 1949 to 1975, Minister for Air 1962 to 1964, for National Development 1964 to 1969, for Education and Science 1971, for Defence 1971 to 1972, and places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker:
Although he was the antithesis of the political infighter, he turned out to be a very good survivor indeed for a gentleman politician.

This is the way the Canberra Times summed up the political career of Sir David in its tribute on Saturday—it seems a most fitting description. David Eric Fairbairn was born in Surrey, England, on 3 March 1917. He was educated at Geelong Grammar School in Victoria and later at Jesus College, Cambridge. In 1939, Sir David took over `Dunraven', a pastoral property at Woomargama, in the Riverina district of New South Wales. He was a dedicated farmer and grazier and his skills in land management were highly regarded. Sir David is reported to have rated himself as prime ministership material because of his 30 years experience of running a family farm.

PARA.TAB: Sir David had a distinguished record of military service. He served in the 21st Light Horse Riverina Regiment from 1939 to 1941 before joining the Royal Australian Air Force in 1941. Sir David's war service included spells in Britain and New Guinea. He commanded a flight in a photographic reconnaissance unit which located the first V1 rocket launching site. In 1945 he was badly wounded and discharged from the RAAF with the rank of Flight Lieutenant and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross.

Having regard to his family background, it was not surprising that he turned to politics after World War II. He was the fourth generation of his family to serve in a state or federal parliament. Both his grandfathers—Edmund Jowett and Sir George Fairbairn—were in the first federal parliament. His uncle, James Fairbairn, was one of three ministers in the Menzies government who were killed in the crash of a Lockheed bomber between Canberra and Queanbeyan in 1940. The Fairbairn memorial marks that spot.

In 1949, Sir David was elected to the House of Representatives as the federal member for Farrer. In those early days, he is known to have buzzed the Old Parliament House as he returned in his private plane. He survived the gruelling nature of political life for 25 years. Sir David's career was notable as quiet and constructive until he unexpectedly resigned from the ministry in 1969.

Sir David served in a diverse range of ministerial portfolios. In 1962 he was appointed Minister for Air and retained this portfolio until the 1963 election. In 1964 he was appointed to the portfolio of national development, a position he held until 1969 when, amid controversy over leadership, he resigned to the backbench. He was a man of integrity and deep loyalty to the Liberal Party. In 1969, when he informed John Gorton that he would not serve in his cabinet, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have given deep thought and consideration to this decision. I have made it reluctantly. My sole concern in coming to it is the future of the Liberal Party, the Government and the Nation.

Sir David served as Minister for Education and Science from March to August 1971. He was appointed to the portfolio of defence on 13 August 1971, a position he held until December 1972. His collective parliamentary experience included appointments as chair of the Immigration and Planning Council from 1962 to 1964, and to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs from 1970 to 1971.

PARA.TAB: Sir David retired from politics in 1975 and later, in 1977, became Australia's Ambassador to the Netherlands. In 1980 he returned to Canberra and retired from public life. On behalf of the government, I extend to Lady Fairbairn and her family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have much pleasure in seconding this motion. Today we remember the life and the work of Sir David Fairbairn, who was elected to this House of Representatives when the Menzies government was swept to power in the 1949 election. David Fairbairn's whole life was a monument to his sense of duty and service to the Australian community and to his pursuit of the highest standards. For David Fairbairn, achievement was not a matter of narrow self-interest but, rather, of doing justice to one's attributes in a way that advanced the good of the wider community. These were values which Sir David's pioneer pastoral family had epitomised for generations in both commercial and public life.

PARA.TAB: David Fairbairn was the fourth generation of his family to serve in either a state parliament or the federal parliament. His great-grandfather was a pioneer of the canned and frozen meat industry, both his grandfathers were members of the first federal parliament and his uncle James Fairbairn was the Minister for Air in the Menzies government, who was tragically killed in the well-known air crash between Canberra and Queanbeyan in 1940.

In times of greatest challenge and danger, David Fairbairn displayed a quiet heroism. As the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Howe) pointed out, in the Second World War, David Fairbairn served in the 21st Light Horse Riverina Regiment before joining the Royal Australian Air Force. As a member of a photographic reconnaissance mission, using unarmed Spitfires, he located the first V1 rocket landing site from which Germany was raining terror on British cities.

The bravery he showed in his wartime service was recognised by his being awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross. As I mentioned earlier, in 1949 David Fairbairn was elected as the Liberal member for Farrer, an achievement which he repeated at the next 10 federal elections. He made important contributions as a member of key parliamentary committees, particularly on foreign affairs, transport and immigration issues. He later served in various portfolios as Minister for Air, Minister for National Development, Minister for Education and Science and Minister for Defence.

In these various ministerial capacities, David Fairbairn was a man who made a difference. He was passionately committed to the development of Australia's great natural resources. He gave practical effect to his lifelong commitment to advancing Australian agriculture and the interests of those who worked on the land.

He undertook innovative work in the area of water conservation and in the development of a national system of transportation. He pursued his vision for the application of emerging forms of technology to the challenge of opening up Australia. He made a vital contribution to the evolution of Australia's post-Vietnam defence strategy. He promoted proper standards and expanding horizons in education and science. He also gave distinguished service as Australia's Ambassador to the Netherlands between 1977 and 1981. There is so much more to David Fairbairn's record of achievement in public life.

Many of David Fairbairn's views were, of course, controversial but all of them were inspired by his deep patriotism and his desire that Australia fulfil its great potential during a period of what was unprecedented social and economic change. When involved in controversy, David Fairbairn always focused on the issues rather than personalities and always conducted himself with openness and integrity. It is right today, as we mark Sir David's death, that we honour his outstanding record of service and commitment over three decades in public life.

David Fairbairn was a man of decency, determination and also deep loyalty to the Liberal Party. He believed that Liberal values best expressed the Australian commitment to achievement, progress and genuine equality of opportunity. He contributed importantly to the work of coalition governments which gave Australia its longest period of sustained prosperity and growth. In both peace and war, David Fairbairn gave sterling service to his country and to the ideals which inspired him through his life.

I knew David Fairbairn throughout my life. He was elected to the House of Representatives with my father, and David and Ruth Fairbairn became amongst our closest family friends. My parents, sisters and I frequently visited and occasionally stayed at Dunraven at Woomargama, the Fairbairn family property, when we drove between Canberra and Adelaide. Sir David was always welcoming, gracious and thoughtful.

More recently, Sir David was Ambassador to the Netherlands at the time I occupied the very humble position of Third Secretary at the Australian Mission to the European Community in Brussels. He noticed me even in that humble position. David and Ruth Fairbairn frequently invited me to stay with them for weekends in The Hague. One of those weekends was the weekend of the 1977 federal election in Australia. Sir David and Lady Fairbairn and I all celebrated the triumph of the coalition in that election but, of course, with suitable diplomatic discretion.

I last saw David Fairbairn in hospital last Tuesday and, despite his illness, he greeted me with his characteristic warmth and kindness. With the passing of David Fairbairn, Australia has lost one of its best, a man of courage, integrity and achievement. All Australians have lost a man whose driving force was a commitment to principle, to love of country and to the pursuit of opportunities from which all Australians would benefit. On behalf of the coalition parties, I express my deep sympathy to Sir David's widow, Ruth, who is in the gallery this afternoon and who always gave Sir David outstanding and strong support throughout his career. I also extend our sympathy to their three daughters, Frankie, Paulie and Rosie.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great honour to join with the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Howe) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) in this condolence motion for Sir David Fairbairn, the first member for Farrer. As the third member for Farrer, I have great respect for the contribution made by Sir David Fairbairn. My late parents, Ralph and Barbara Fischer, were friends of David's when he first set out to represent Farrer, which then and now includes my home town of Boree Creek.

PARA.TAB: When I visited David in Woden Valley Hospital last Tuesday, despite his deteriorating condition, I sensed he was fighting on. That is a manifestation of his dedication and determination which carried him through all those positions which my colleagues have mentioned, including his diplomatic service, his time as a member of the RAAF and his 25 years as a member of the parliamentary Liberal Party.

Born in England in 1917, he came from a distinguished family, a family that was no stranger to politics. Let me dwell on different aspects of that contribution. His grandfathers were in the first Australian federal parliament. David Fairbairn's uncle James was not only Minister for Air but a leader of a key delegation to the Ottawa conference in the build-up to World War II. It is noteworthy that that tragic accident took out not only James Fairbairn, then Minister for Air, but also Brigadier Street, father of Tony Street, and Vice-President of the Executive Council, Sir Henry Gullett, father of Joe Gullett, and the Chief of the General Staff at the time, General Sir Brudenell White. That air accident in 1940, a very difficult and critical time for Australia, claimed three ministers and a chief of our armed forces.

The Fairbairn family played a remarkable role in the development of Australia. Recognised for their contribution socially, pastorally, politically and patriotically, the Fairbairns have been on the land since the middle of last century. The family owned vast properties, not only at Woomargama near Holbrook in Victoria but also in New South Wales and Queensland, in the area of Cappella and Peak Downs. The old Fairbairn homestead has now been shifted into the town of Capella where it forms part of a major tourist exhibition. The Fairbairn Dam, just near Emerald, was named after the family.

Others have mentioned pioneering work of the family with frozen meat and the like, so I will not dwell on that other than to point out that his uncle Stephen was famous for revolutionising the technique of English rowing while studying at Cambridge, although the same Uncle Stephen prided himself as having only ever attended one lecture in the six years he was at Cambridge.

Sir David served in the Light Horse, enlisted in the RAAF, served in England and New Guinea and was badly wounded, awarded a DFC and discharged in 1945. He never really spoke much about that. It is a great pity that so many of our wonderful World War II service personnel are reluctant to pass on much of what they saw in that service, as that service is of great historic importance to Australia and part of our history. I regret that is so but it was part of his approach, dominated as it was by humility.

David Fairbairn's 25 years as a member of the House of Representatives was served with great honour, great determination and great dedication in all those portfolios, including national development, where he played a key role in selecting the site for the mighty Dartmouth Dam, which has done so much for the Murray-Darling Basin. He retired from federal politics in 1975 and described it as `a very good innings'. Only a week ago we were speaking on a condolence motion for the first member for Bennelong, Sir John Kramer. Both men were true blue Liberals. Both shared a sense of special honour in public duty.

David Fairbairn was a man driven by his sense of duty and committed to improving the present and planning for the future for all Australians. To dwell on another different aspect, I consider one of his greatest contributions was his role as secretary of a parliamentary committee chaired by that controversial and colourful figure William Charles Wentworth, now a resident of Far North Queensland, which recommended standardisation of the rail gauge system on the key routes Sydney to Melbourne, Sydney to Perth and elsewhere. I often spoke to David about that work. It was manifestly important work in starting to get the rail equation right in Australia.

Standardisation was completed in the 1960s but so narrow was the majority after the 1961 election that both David and Bill Wentworth had to travel by taxi after the parliament got up in Canberra across to Yass to jump on the inaugural Southern Aurora train, the first ever train to run from Sydney to Melbourne. But they made it, and they made a very big contribution to the modernisation of our rail system at that time.

David Fairbairn was at all times a proud federalist, believing in the rights and significance of state governments and was outspoken against any moves to further centralise power in Canberra. David Fairbairn was a man who truly represented the people of his electorate. Their concerns were his concerns, as reflected in his maiden speech in 1950, which particularly made reference to the supply of basic amenities such as electricity and water, both of which arrived in the town of Boree Creek in his first few years as our federal member.

David Fairbairn recognised regional development and decentralisation as important aspects for the future of Australia and was concerned about demographic trends in Australia. Federal politics were certainly in his blood and, when the quiet man spoke, he did not mince his words. David Fairbairn described the difficulty he went through to come to his reluctant decision to take on the then Leader of the Liberal Party, John Grey Gorton. But he was driven to do what he thought was best for the party, the government and the nation, and to forgo ministerial rank in the process.

I salute his commitment to the people of the electorate of Farrer, I salute his sense of duty to his party and I salute his enthusiasm for this great country. As we commemorate the 50th anniversary of D-day, Sir David was there in the air over Europe throughout significant parts of World War II.

As Leader of the National Party, on behalf of my colleagues, I extend my deepest sympathy to Lady Fairbairn and members of the Fairbairn family. I make special mention of his wife, Lady Ruth Fairbairn, and her long running interest in politics, her own contribution and her considerable influence. You, Madam, have a right to be proud of Sir David's fine life. It was, as Sir David well may have said himself, a very good innings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not have the privilege of knowing Sir David Fairbairn personally but, as one who now represents in this place part of the region he once did, I know of the high esteem in which he was held. A perusal of Sir David's maiden speech shows that his concerns for Australia, particularly rural Australia, still remain relevant. As the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) has said, Sir David spoke of regionalisation and decentralisation, population drift to the cities, services in rural areas, the care and improvement of rural lands, industrial relations and profit sharing.

PARA.TAB: He was a man of quiet vision and determination who served his nation in various capacities: veteran of the Second World War, member of the House of Representatives, farmer, minister and diplomat. In all of these undertakings, Sir David carried out his responsibilities with distinction. A sense of duty characterised Sir David's military and public life. There is no doubt that my electorate, part of which Sir David once represented, still bears his influence. On behalf of the people of Wagga Wagga and surrounding districts, I pay tribute to the memory of Sir David Fairbairn DFC and extend my sympathies to his family, who I know are very proud of his life and achievements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in the remarks made about the late Sir David Fairbairn and endorse the motion moved by the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Howe) and supported by my colleagues. I think anyone who knew David could not but help be marked by the quality and sincerity of the man. Of him perhaps more than most others, the characteristics of belief in what he did and complete devotion to the cause were immediately apparent. As one who worked with him in cabinet, there are two events I really want to refer to, as I believe they are worth remembering.

PARA.TAB: It was he, rather than any other of the Menzies ministry, who was responsible for finally deciding, not at that time but later, that there should be funding federally of the Ord River Dam. It was a project that had been spoken and thought about for years, but it was David who, as Minister for National Development, ultimately was the minister responsible and who took that project through cabinet. While it was a matter at that time of some controversy, without doubt it was a project which in this the driest of all continents was worth while. I think it is quite fitting that Fairbairn Dam near Emerald in Queensland, which was named after his family perhaps rather than David himself, bears his name, for throughout his life David was a very great advocate of the need to improve the resources of outback Australia and certainly the availability of water.

The second event relates really to his attitude which led to his dispute with John Gorton. That was really a product of John Gorton's firm commitment to the declaration of the three-mile limit of offshore mineral resources for the Commonwealth. David was a great federalist and he quite strongly believed that it was inappropriate for the Commonwealth to assert its authority and leave it for the High Court to resolve the difference between the Commonwealth and the states. It was on that matter of principle that he and John Gorton fell out. Yet, in so many ways, they were similar: they each had university degrees, one from Oxford and the other from Cambridge in the United Kingdom, and both were distinguished aviators during World War II. However, David always felt that John was far too much of a centralist and it was very much on that matter of principle that he declared his hand and, of course, contested the leadership of the Liberal Party against John Gorton.

To Lady Fairbairn: Ruth, you have every reason to be proud of the contribution your husband made to the parliament, to the Liberal Party and to Australia. In every way he was a great man. He served Australia with distinction during World War II and he certainly served this parliament with very great distinction and subsequently as Australia's Ambassador to the Netherlands. He is a person whom I regarded as a friend and as a person who certainly gave me great guidance in the days when I first became a minister. To Ruth, Frankie, Paulie and Rosie, my Rosie and I extend our deepest sympathy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make just a few comments. My electorate of Indi adjoins Sir David Fairbairn's electorate of Farrer. I grew up in Albury and met Sir David Fairbairn because he was my local member. He encouraged me to become involved in Liberal politics and eventually to run for and enter state parliament. On the rare occasions when I did see him after I was elected, he was always very supportive of me and encouraged me in my work.

PARA.TAB: I also knew a lot of friends of Sir David. One of the best memories I have is of a tradesman telling me that he was working out on his family property on a very hot day digging a trench. Sir David came along, took his suit off because he had just come back from Canberra, proceeded to grab a shovel, hopped in the trench and worked with the person to help dig the trench.

He was a very humble man who had no pretensions, but he had an enormous amount of dignity. People respected him for his quiet grace and certainly his courage. He was also honorary colonel to the 8th/13th Victorian Mounted Rifles of which I was a member. He served in that position with distinction and encouraged a lot of young Australians to serve their nation in the reserve forces. He was indeed a great Australian, a great parliamentarian and a person who helped make the Liberal Party great in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join with others in speaking on this motion of condolence. I served, like the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), in the parliament with David Fairbairn and in ministries in the 1960s and 1970s and was foreign minister when he was Ambassador to the Netherlands. I think honourable members who did not know David will have gained from the remarks that have passed, particularly from the right honourable member for New England and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer), just what a fine, quiet and dignified man David Fairbairn was. He was a very, very decent Australian—a man who committed himself to public service, at very great cost to himself, his wife and his family, with never a complaint.

PARA.TAB: I disagreed with him on his views and arguments with John Gorton. But you could only disagree with David Fairbairn; you could never hold any ill thoughts against him. He was too fine a man. You could respect the different arguments he produced and indeed such was the quality of the person that you even felt a fondness for him despite the difference of view. He was almost shy; a quiet and polite person but a firm believer in Australia and his commitment to it. I simply want to say to Ruth, who has been a vibrant, energetic, loyal and loving wife supporting him in everything he has done, that I join with the others in expressing sympathy to her and her family. It really is a very deep loss—the loss of a fine and decent man.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone who knew Sir David Fairbairn could only describe him as one of nature's gentlemen. One remembers that David Fairbairn applied the strictest of rules to his own behaviour as a person, as a member of our parliament, as one of Her Majesty's Australian cabinet, and as a dedicated Ambassador to the Netherlands. I recall how he adjusted his own private financial interests in such a way that could not allow any suggestion of a conflict of interest with his public duties.

PARA.TAB: Personally, I remember him with deep affection, and for the hand of friendship he gave to all of us who came into this place as new members some time ago. He made us welcome. More than any other folk, he and his wife, Ruth, opened their home and their hearts to us new boys and eased many of the new boy problems. The hearth of their home was well known to many of us.

David Fairbairn not only served his country well, he was also an example to all of us who came into close contact with him. I shall miss this ex-serviceman, ex-MP and ex-ambassador very much. He was a great Australian and the finest of men. To Ruth, I offer my condolences and pray that she will have the grace to pass through her time of grief and sadness with strength and courage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to briefly associate myself with this motion. I served as a parliamentary colleague of the late Sir David Fairbairn for 18 months, between 1974 and 1975. When one thinks of David, one thinks of a quintessential traditionalist: the instincts of honour, decency, service, commitment, loyalty and all of those values that people sometimes sneer at and deride but which at the end of the day mean more in the collective life of a nation than some of the more passing, fashionable and seemingly more attractive qualities of men and women.

PARA.TAB: David was all of those things. He was unfailingly courteous and kind to new members. I still remember with some affection the day I was sworn in, in July 1974. After the swearing in ceremony David invited my wife and me, in company with the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and his wife, to lunch at the Lobby. It was one of those occasions that I have remembered for many years. It is the sort of gesture that was typical of him. He was a person who always wanted to impart some of his parliamentary experience to some of the new members.

His wartime record has been documented; his defence of the principles of federalism has been documented. I join my colleagues in extending to Ruth and to his family my very profound sympathy. We send our love. He has left behind many happy memories for them, I am sure, and an instinct for honour and decency that we could all do well to emulate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike most who have spoken, I did not serve in the parliament with David Fairbairn, as is obvious from the time that he served. But I do want to say, from my having been in the organisation, that I knew him to be a man who was respected, to be an elder statesman who set an example. I knew that he was a man steeped in the concept of service. Duty was important to him. He believed in that concept of duty and service. His partner in life, Ruth, joined him very strongly in that same commitment.

PARA.TAB: In joining in this condolence motion, I simply want to say a very fine Australian has left us, but he has left his mark. With the sympathy that goes to the family goes, as well, a sense of thanks for the service given. Australia is the better place for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of those who were Young Liberals in the late 1950s—
—Still young.

—And I am still a young Liberal; I want to associate myself with this condolence motion because David Fairbairn to all of us then and to those of us who remain now was an outstanding example of what a Liberal parliamentarian should be all about. He was dedicated. He had a quiet determination to do all the tasks he was required to do and to do them well. For all the reasons which have been mentioned by my colleagues, we dearly regret his loss.

PARA.TAB: I remember when I first came here as private secretary to the President of the Senate—I was only 23. Ruth and David Fairbairn gave me their friendship, opened their door to me, and gave me the opportunity to see the inside of the parliamentary community as it then was, to meet the personalties involved and, in a sense, imbibe the very cultural traditions that are now so much a part of this House and a part of the Liberal Party.

Mention has been made of his outstanding military career. I remember when he was the Minister for Air. My very first, shall we say, dealing with David was when I was an officer in the university squadron of the RAAF and we had just committed ourselves to Vietnam, by sending our first advisers over there. I was able to successfully talk him into sending two of us over to do a report on the Australian presence in Vietnam at that very early stage. I go on record as saying that I was less than impressed with the performance of President Diem at that particular time, but events have passed us by and that is now part of history.

As I said, whatever he did, he did well. He set an outstanding example as a father, a friend, a parliamentarian, a diplomat and a soldier. In every sense of the term he was a great Australian. On behalf of my wife and I, I would like to pass to his wife, Ruth, and to their children our sincere condolences at this time when Australia has lost a great son.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6 June 1994, I understand that it is the wish of the House to observe one minute's silence as a mark of respect to the great gallantry and courage displayed by the young men who took part 50 years ago in the D-day landings in Normandy and in particular to the 2,600 Australian servicemen involved. I invite honourable members to now observe one minute's silence.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Honourable members having stood in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Acting Prime Minister to the Westpac Market Insights, released today, which notes that the government increased outlays in the budget and states:

QUESTION.PARA: The better strategy would have been . . . to wind back the deficit and ease the looming pressure for monetary policy to be tightened.
Does the government now concede that interest rates will rise as a result of the budget and does it agree with Westpac that they will rise more than three per cent by late 1995?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the deputy leader for his question. The government certainly does not agree with the conclusion suggested by the honourable member. The government has set in place a strategy not only for the current calendar year but also for the years ahead. The government has made firm decisions about that strategy. It has shown not only in this year's budget but also in last year's budget that it is prepared to take the difficult decisions necessary to ensure that that strategy remains on course.

PARA.TAB: In this year's budget, I think we have seen the government successfully make room for a very substantial package which deals with the issue that most Australians have been concerned about over the last two or three years: unemployment. The measures taken in this statement, together with the overall fiscal strategy, are designed to wind back levels of unemployment to that which will be much more acceptable. That is the key to our strategy and there is no reason at all why that strategy should not be effective.

It has been implied, not only in this question but in previous questions from the opposition, that somehow what we need to have is a tighter fiscal strategy and to be reducing expenditure more rapidly and, therefore, by implication, we ought not to be setting the priority in unemployment that the government has set. We reject that approach.

We believe that, when you look not only at what forecasters are saying but also at what business is saying, the government's approach is widely accepted. After all, we are moving into a position of recovery, not in terms of high levels of inflation, but in terms of levels of inflation which are comparable to any time over the last decade, employment growth which is strong and indications that investment is likely to be very much on track with the government's forecast.

So one has to ask: why is the opposition returning again and again to question the government's fiscal strategy? Essentially, it is doing it not because it is concerned with priorities that might be set by Westpac or by itself, but because of a preoccupation with a lower deficit, irrespective of what the consequences might be for employment and creating a fairer society.

So the government rejects the conclusion of the honourable member for Higgins. We will continue to work to achieve jobs. Last year we created 250,000 jobs. We will work in terms not only of that strategy, but also in a way that has the broad support of business, that will achieve investment, protect low inflation and ensure a fairer society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Acting Prime Minister inform the House of the actions taken by the government to recognise the contribution of Australian service men and women on D-day 50 years ago today?

—The government—and I am sure the opposition joins me—pays tribute to the Australian service men and women who took part in Operation Overlord 50 years ago. More than 2,600 Australians took part in the invasion of the beaches of Normandy—the biggest and most successful military undertaking in history. We honour these Australians. They bestowed a great honour on this country.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister is today attending D-day celebrations in Normandy with other leaders of the allied nations. During those celebrations, a Lancaster bomber will drop two million red paper poppies over the English Channel as a symbol of remembrance. One of its targets is the MV Canberra which is hosting D-day veterans, including four Australians.

As the Prime Minister has said, the principles for which Australia fought in Europe are universal principles of liberty, justice and human decency. As a nation, we must never forget why we came to fight alongside the British, the Americans and the Canadians. Australians fought for the democracies of the free world. They fought to free those nations whose freedom had been taken from them. Many gave their lives so that we might enjoy that freedom.

Today is an important day in Europe. It is also an important day in Australia. It is a day which many of us remember and for which all Australians owe a great deal for the courage and the dignity of so many Australians and allied forces that were active at that particular time. It is part of a history that has not only helped shape the values and attitudes in this country, but also helped shape, in a crucial way, the attitudes and values of the modern world.

I am sure that the opposition joins with the government in paying tribute to the bravery of our young servicemen and personnel. It was because of their bravery, as I have suggested, that we live in a fair and free country. We must not forget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, on behalf of all the coalition members, I join the Acting Prime Minister and support the comments that he has made in relation to D-day. We also honour those Australians who fought Nazism and tyranny in the interests of a better, fairer and more decent world.

—I direct my question to the Acting Prime Minister. On 3 March, the Treasurer told the parliament, `What is important for business investment is interest rates being low and remaining low.' Last week, the Prime Minister said, `I do not think business investment has got anything to do with interest rates.' Given Westpac's forecast that by 1996 investment growth will be slowing and interest rates will go from 4.8 per cent to eight per cent—a 70 per cent increase in interest rates—who is right: the Treasurer or the Prime Minister?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—
Mr McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting, the honourable member for Gippsland in particular.

—The question of business investment has been a matter of concern to the government. Business investment grew by 4.4 per cent in the March quarter this year and by 4.8 per cent over the year to the March quarter 1994. Investment in plant and equipment grew by 5.8 per cent in the quarter and six per cent over the year. The Business Council of Australia's last half-yearly survey of large firms foreshadows a strong surge in business investment. Almost half of the firms expect to boost their investment—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under standing order 321, I ask the Acting Prime Minister to table the document which he is patently reading from, thereby establishing the fact that it is not confidential. Mr Speaker, I invite you to require him to be relevant.
—The Acting Prime Minister was asked a question about investment and interest rates—
—He's quoting from a document.

—Hang on; I will get to that part in a minute—and he is responding to that. The Acting Prime Minister has also been asked whether the documents that he is quoting from are confidential. Are they confidential documents?
—They are confidential notes.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I do not object to a request that documents be tabled. But there is a convention in this place that when an answer is complete and a document has been read from—
—What a load of rubbish.
—Grow up.
—Order! The Leader of the House has the call.
—If a document has been read from, the convention is then that a request is put forward on the tabling of it—not as a means of interrupting an answer.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just relax. The Leader of the House—

—Order! The Acting Prime Minister might resume his seat for a minute. The Leader of the House raises a very valid point. The convention that he has outlined has certainly been the case that I have observed. The Acting Prime Minister is in order.

—The questions that I have received today went to both the question of interest rates and the issue of investment. The second question went to the issue of investment. It speculated about interest rates but it went fundamentally to the question of investment. I am answering that question on a factual basis. One thing about the opposition, and the reason why it is in opposition, is that it has failed to focus essentially on facts.

PARA.TAB: The Business Council of Australia's latest half-yearly survey of large firms foreshadows a strong surge in business investment. Almost half the firms expect to boost their investment by 20 per cent or more over the six months to September. This strongly supports the budget's forecast for business investment growth of 14 1/2 per cent in 1994-95. Mr Ian Salmon, chairman of the BCA's economic and financial panel, said that that survey, together with the March quarter national accounts, suggests that the budget forecasts are attainable. There has been some attempt by the coalition, which is destructive in the extreme—

TALK.START.PARA: —In the extreme.
—to suggest that there is some basis—
—The Leader of the Opposition is not setting a very good example.

—The opposition is seeking effectively to talk down the economy by talking up the issue of interest rates. The reference by the Governor of the Reserve Bank last week was a suggestion, effectively, that when people made investment decisions they needed to take account of what might be the long-term situation. It was not a matter for people to simply say that, because current circumstances had particular elements in them, those circumstances would remain over the longer term.
—Oh!

—Oh, ha, ha, ha! That simply is an indication that when people are making investments they need to be judicious about those investments. In terms of the current investment climate in Australia, there is every reason to think that the government's forecast will be met. When I met with Business Council leaders only a week or so ago and talked to people around the room, it was pretty clear that people in business believe not only that inflation, and low-level inflation, is here to stay—something you were never able to achieve—but also that the climate is there for investment and the climate is there for sustained employment growth.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons why the government enjoys the confidence of the Australian people is that, in terms of our approach to macro-economic policy, we have governed for the longer term, not for the shorter term, and not in the opportunistic way that the opposition currently seeks to pursue. Simply reading the morning's press is not sufficient preparation for an intelligent question time. Perhaps after you and the Deputy Leader have been in the chair a little bit longer, you might get to that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Has the minister seen reports that a major tobacco company is proposing to challenge the validity of the government's Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992? In these circumstances, what are the government's intentions regarding such a challenge?

—I think it is important that the House express its views early on this question. I do not know whether all members are yet aware, but the Philip Morris group of companies has challenged the act. I am very disappointed that it has done this—a dramatic gesture—some 18 months after the introduction of the legislation. Of course, we would have considered those legal questions in the course of framing the legislation.
—They have a legal right.
—They have a legal right.

—I want to make it very clear that the government—I am not so sure about the opposition, judging from those interjections—does not regard the ban on tobacco advertising being removed, by any means, as a responsible proposition. I do not think it needs to be repeated, except to a few on the other side, that this is the major preventable cause of death and illness in our community.

PARA.TAB: While I agree with the honourable member for Bennelong that the company has a right to a legal challenge, I think the community needs to stand behind the stance of the government and, I believe, the opposition on this question—I thought it was the opposition's stance on this question—that we did not want the image of tobacco companies and smoking associated with youth and with positive images in this society. That has been the motivation behind this legislation. I simply want to make very clear to Philip Morris and other companies that that remains the government's motivation. I look forward to bipartisan support.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister is aware that since 1982 the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Populations has been drafting a Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. At the 11th session of the working group, in 1993, the draft was recast so that it states that indigenous peoples have the right of self-determination, including the right freely to determine their political status. In other words, the draft declaration provides for indigenous peoples to have the right to secede from sovereign states and to form independent nations. Will the minister confirm that while the draft declaration contains a provision to that effect the government will not be supporting it in any international forum?

—The conventions of the treaty making process in this House have been supported by both the government and the present opposition for many years. The question asked by the honourable member goes to matters of considerable detail. I believe that I should refer them to the responsible minister—namely, the Minister for Foreign Affairs—and I shall do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and it follows from the answer of the Acting Prime Minister concerning the results of the most recent survey conducted by the Business Council of Australia on likely levels of business investment. I ask the minister: do these results support forecasts made by the Treasurer in the recent budget and underline the strength of the current economic recovery? Is the minister aware of alternative forecasts which appear to have no factual basis whatsoever?

—Yes, I am aware of alternative forecasts which have no factual basis whatsoever. They are the bedlam that comes from the opposition in policy in this area. On Laurie Oakes's segment of the Sunday program yesterday, evidence was shown that a bit of cross-referencing is at last beginning as far as opposition policy is concerned. The shadow spokesman on Treasury matters had the opportunity to sit down and contemplate his two forecasts—one of negligible business investment and one of interest rate rises. When it was suggested that there might be some contradiction in these propositions, which he has been waving out there in the public with such joy since that point of time, he found himself backing, filling, sliding and trying to work out, as he did from day one, what GOS stands for.
—No, that was one of yours.
—It was someone on your side. You should not have been caught out on that.
—That was John Kerin.

—Given that it happened so unfortunately to John Kerin, why did it then happen to you as well? It was a very amusing interlude. But, at that stage of the game, there was neither much cross-referencing going on nor a great deal of attention being paid to following up questions that had clearly trapped you. As you slid out from under that one on that occasion, so you attempted to slide out from under Laurie Oakes's pretty relevant questioning in this area. The fact of the matter is—
—It's hard to slide out from under you, too.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—I notice that you have been putting on a bit of weight lately too, old son. Watch out for yourself. As the years go by, you will find that those benches will become more and more comfortable for you.
—The honourable member for Flinders might be able to give advice all around.

—The predictions of the Business Council of Australia are merely one of the many forecasts which are in opposition to the opposition's forecasts on the direction of investment. Sixty per cent of the council's survey respondents expected to increase their investment by more than 10 per cent, and about 45 per cent of survey respondents expected to increase their investment by more than 20 per cent. The survey found that 46 of Australia's 86 largest corporations also expected the value and volume of their sales to rise. The survey found that uncertainty associated with investment is diminishing and that excess capacity is falling. Some businesses have reached full capacity. Productivity growth with respect to both capital and labour has been strong in the six months to 31 March 1994.

PARA.TAB: Mr Salmon, who is on the BCA board and who is also the Managing Director of AMP, said in today's Australian Financial Review that `business in Australia expects economic recovery to accelerate without the threat of a resurgence of high inflation'. Taken together with the national account figures for the March quarter, the survey suggests that the 1994-95 Commonwealth budget framework and its forecasts are attainable. So increased investment will expand the economy's productive capacity and help sustain strong economic growth, which in turn will support employment growth. Improved productivity flowing from workplace reforms also improves the economy's effective capacity to produce goods and services.

All of that is of a piece with what the last set of national accounts showed, but what we have flowing through here is a higher quality recovery, even though the way in which the bureau collects its statistics always makes it likely that it is going to underestimate, or not necessarily identify, the early stages of a business investment surge. But what it did correctly identify was that the increased investment and the very good growth figures were taking place against the background of a maintenance of low inflation—indeed, declining inflation—and against the background of very substantial improvements in productivity.

The combination of those two elements, low inflation and the very substantial improvements in productivity, is what will ensure that the climate for business, including the interest rate regime, is going to be acceptable for the foreseeable future. That is what gives businesses confidence to invest. The business community, as we would expect, takes absolutely no notice of the ingenues opposite when it comes to commentary on economic management. Thankfully, the Australian work force, which is relying on those improvements for a better standard of living, can take very great comfort in the forecasts of those who at least know what they are talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Is she aware that there has been significant criticism of the proposed $16.4 million national breast cancer centre announced in the budget? Will the minister admit that all she is doing is setting up a clearing house for research already done? Will she do as Professor John Forbes suggested when he gave evidence to the public inquiry into the management and treatment of breast cancer: either await the findings of that committee or, at the very least, change the terms of reference so that research becomes a function of that centre?

—It needs to be clearly outlined that there is always dissent about these questions in the medical community. I defy anyone over any period of time to find agreement on every question. The breast cancer centre was welcomed widely, for example by the Cancer Society of Victoria, and has received support from a great many quarters, particularly from people who are dealing with the daily problems faced by women and their families.

PARA.TAB: It was made clear in the budget and subsequently that there are three elements to the government's response to the very serious problem of breast cancer. The first element was a continuing provision and expansion of screening programs so that we have full saturation by 1995-96 of all women over 50; a capacity for women between 40 and 50 to receive free service; and, under the Medicare benefits schedule, for all women to have diagnostic mammography if necessary.

The second element was the establishment of a breast cancer foundation to provide for research by way of $3 million directly in the way of seeding funds and then up to a further $3 million on the basis of private sector donations, but arms length from government and provided with the best peer review of all applications for research funding. In addition, there are clearly additional funds through the National Health and Medical Research Council since it has given breast cancer research priority.

The third element—and perhaps there is some misunderstanding on the part of Professor Forbes because this has been endorsed by a great many people—is the breast cancer centre which deals with best practice in treatment and disseminates information, yes, to all members of the medical community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't do any research, though.

—No, it is not intended to do research and never was. The terms of reference clearly said that it is intended to inform the medical community and to provide best practice guidelines. There are separate provisions made for research into breast cancer, but I am sure the work of the committee of which the honourable member is a member will tell her that a great concern of women in Australia is that they are, in some cases, receiving inferior treatment—treatment which has not been properly researched and which, in some cases, is outmoded.

PARA.TAB: This breast cancer centre is designed to make sure that all of our medical practitioners—doctors, nurses, psychologists and others—involved in the treatment of women are informed about best practice, that the education system reflects that best practice, and that women and their families have a point of reference. This is about ensuring that all of our medical profession, paramedicals and associated professions understand what needs to be done so that the work of people like Professor Forbes, if it comes to fruition, will be incorporated into the practices of our medical profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Answer the question.

—I have answered the question. There are three elements to the breast cancer program covering screening, research and best practice. We look forward to an institution, or institutions, putting forward a proposal which will see the very rapid establishment of a breast cancer centre for the benefit of those many women in Australia who are currently suffering from ill-informed and ill-advised treatment.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Will the minister inform the House of her response to the report in the Medical Journal of Australia of Australia's first reported case of HIV/AIDS transmission in prison?

—Like many people, I was concerned to see what appears to be a second report of the transmission of AIDS within the prison system. There was one earlier report in Queensland. The one that has been given some currency as of today and yesterday occurred in New South Wales and appeared to occur in 1989.

PARA.TAB: I urge all members of this House to use whatever influence they can with their parliamentary colleagues in state and territory governments to ensure, as the intergovernmental committee on AIDS has agreed, that there should be the same level of care and protection extended to people in correctional institutions as in the wider community. That is something that has enjoyed bipartisan support but sadly has not been implemented in the governments that we have talked about. For instance, education on prevention and the provision of condoms has so far been resisted and we are now seeing cases—plural—of transmission within our correctional institutions.

I ask all members, governments and correctional institutions to change their practices in this respect and ensure that prisoners are not placed at any greater risk than the rest of the community. Even if there are those who would want to punish prisoners further by withdrawing medical services from them, it needs to be remembered that these people do return to the community and will then be placing the rest of the community at greater risk.

I urge the opposition to get behind this push. I would be grateful for some clarification of whom I should be urging; whether it is the honourable member for Chisholm or the honourable member for Mackellar. It seems that the opposition cannot decide who is responsible for this very important area of HIV/AIDS.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that true? Tell the truth.

—I am asked by the Leader of the Opposition whether it is true or not. I draw his attention to two separate gay newspapers, both of which interviewed the honourable member for Mackellar. In these articles, she made it very clear, as the newspapers did in interviews with me, that she was the spokesperson.
—You are playing politics with AIDS.
—No, I am not playing politics with AIDS. I want the opposition to be clear about who is responsible.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145, which relates to relevance. This question is one which deserves the utmost seriousness of this chamber. It is one which goes to the very life of a number of people, particularly prisoners in Australian gaols, and it is unacceptable and irrelevant for the member to be debating this matter in this way.
—Order! Now you are debating the issue. Resume your seat. The minister will conclude her answer.

—I think it needs to be drawn to the attention of this House that I am not politicising this question, but seeking to clarify a very important issue. The honourable member for Mackellar said in interviews with newspapers around this country that she was `the one who would make this an important priority'. She said that on Thursday of last week. Over the weekend, the Leader of the Opposition said that she is not responsible. She said that, although she had responsibility, she had not done an amazing amount of evaluation, and that presumably led her to suggest that funds should be slashed in this area.

PARA.TAB: I have raised this matter here because it was politicised by the honourable member for Mackellar. Quite clearly, the honourable member for Mackellar believed that she was responsible. The Leader of the Opposition claimed that she never was. At the very least, you did not communicate with the honourable member for Mackellar; at the very worst, you mislead the people of Australia.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I once again remind ministers to address their remarks through the chair.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. What is the current status of the ship control management monitoring system for the Collins submarine project? What are the nature and extent of the ongoing software problems? To what extent will these problems delay the introduction of the Collins class submarines into operational service?

—I thank the honourable member for his question and acknowledge his legitimate and longstanding interest in defence matters and, indeed, his career. It has been acknowledged for some time that there have been significant delays in the delivery of the combat data systems software for the submarines. It is, to provide the House with somewhat of an understatement, an extremely complex task.

PARA.TAB: The subcontractors, Rockwell Systems Australia and Computer Sciences Corporation of Australia, have assured the Department of Defence that every effort is being made to overcome the current problems and dedicate the appropriate resources to the remainder of the work. While the software is the principal cause of the delay, there has been a six-week strike by sandblasters and painters employed by a subcontractor, which has now been resolved.

The latest advice that I have is that Collins will go back into the water at the end of July and will commence limited sea trials in October. Full-scale sea trials which are dependent on achievement of an acceptable level of combat system functionality will commence early in 1995. To answer the honourable member's question, delivery of Collins is now expected at the end of 1995, some 11 months late. The flow-on effect on the delivery of the remaining submarines is being examined. For the record, I am advised further that the delays will not increase the cost of the project to the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Will the minister provide the House with details of how the government plans to expand the range of choices available to the unemployed? Importantly, how will this help them into jobs?

—I thank the honourable member for Scullin for his question. As the honourable member points out, the government is concerned to maximise the scope for unemployed people to make their own choices and to take their own decisions in seeking options to maximise their chances of getting back into work. This goal is perceived by the government as being integral to the white paper measures—not just the social security measures but also the job compact which, as honourable members would be aware, provides scope for unemployed people to make their own choices as to who is going to case manage them so as not to be strictly confined to the CES.

PARA.TAB: I intend to speak mainly about some changes in the social security income support system for unemployed people which also further this goal of maximising the capacity of unemployed people to control their own futures, to make their own decisions and choices. A number of specific measures were taken in pursuit of that objective.

Firstly, the range of activities that the long-term unemployed and those at risk of long-term unemployment can undertake while in receipt of benefit will be significantly expanded. This expansion will cover self-employment initiatives, participation in community based cooperatives for up to 12 months, training options, voluntary work and cultural activities. A considerably broader range of activities will now be permissible under the activity agreements that unemployed people will enter into. They will, of course, have to be subject to agreement by the person's individual case manager, so it is not an absolute free-for-all, but there is a considerable broadening of the scope and range of activities that are permissible.

Secondly, those people who have been unemployed for more than three months will have the option of receiving a capitalisation or lump sum payment advance on their allowance of up to $500. The long-term unemployed and those at risk of long-term unemployment will be able to get an advance of up to $1,000 for an approved purpose to help their labour market prospects. No interest will be charged on these advances which will be repaid in a manner akin to normal social security overpayments. The purpose there is to start to give unemployed people entitled to an allowance some capacity to shape and manipulate the form in which they take that allowance so that they are in control to a greater extent and able to utilise that entitlement more effectively to maximise their job search activities.

The third point is that, in the broad overarching restructuring of income support, we have moved to eliminate poverty traps which, to a considerable extent, constrain the capacity of unemployed people to take up workshop options or to maximise their casual work. This point about poverty traps is very important. There seems to be minimal understanding by the opposition of what a poverty trap is. It is clear from comments by the Leader of the National Party that he would not know a poverty trap from a bar of soap. For the information of the Leader of the National Party, a poverty trap is something like this—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. This is just wasting time. The answer is so long that everybody has forgotten what the question is, and the minister ought to be brought to an end.
—Order! There is no point of order. The minister is coming to a conclusion.

—The fourth point is that the parenting allowance will give people facing the prospect of low paid full-time work the more realistic option of having one partner stay at home caring for the kids. Fifthly, as I said, an integral element of the job compact is this broadening of choices for unemployed people in the selection of their case managers. So in a whole range of areas we are taking steps to say to people who are unemployed, `We will support you while you are in that condition. We will provide you with assistance, labour market program assistance, job compact assistance and income support. But we will provide you with a much greater capacity than hitherto to use that assistance in ways which you decide and which suit your particular individual, customised requirements.'

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is quite right. Some recently released statistics indicate a very low level of industrial disputation in Australia. There are three different sets of statistics, all of which prove pretty much the same. In 1993 Australia recorded its lowest number of industrial disputes since 1942, according to the ABS figures last year. The number of working days lost due to disputes in 1993 was 32 per cent below the level for 1992 and the lowest number for a calendar year since 1963. On another measure, the figure of 108 working days lost per 1,000 employees is the lowest calendar year figure since this measure was introduced in the ABS in 1967. But my own department records in unpublished figures that this is the lowest figure since 1933—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—The depression!

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the group, the honourable member for Bennelong included, who like to make a connection between the level of unemployment and the level of dispute. But the fact is that the level of disputes in Australia has continuously fallen for the last decade and is now at its lowest point for 60 years. PARA.TAB: Mr Richard Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Cowan!

—per thousand employees, compared to the figure of 108 for Australia as a whole. So Victoria's performance has made the national statistics slightly worse than they might have been. —What the Premier suggests—and I will quote his advertisement taken out nationally today to criticise the Commonwealth's Industrial Relations Reform Act—is:

ANSWER.PARA: You should be free to negotiate with your employer, job conditions that best suit the both of you. . .

The fact is that, under Commonwealth law, you are, but you are not entitled to be taken for a ride by the state legislation in Victoria. You are not entitled to be left alone without the protection of certain laws which ensure that you are not left at the behest and the power of the employer.

PARA.TAB: So, in Victoria at the moment, there are 20,000 or more individual contracts forced upon individuals on pain of getting the sack. There are no agreements per se but, under the federal system, 48 per cent of those eligible to be covered under a federal award are covered by an agreement. So Mr Kennett, who dislikes our act, dislikes it for good reason: he cannot force his work force into the position in which he would like to force it, a position that would force productivity out of workers by dint of contracts which are unpublished, unknown and cannot be revealed to the public because—again by law—you are unable to reveal the private contract that you write between an individual and the Victorian government.

The fact is that the level of industrial dispute in Australia is low for good reason. It is because we have good, negotiated arrangements between employers and individual workers in the Australian work force. That patently is not true in Victoria, where they have chosen another situation.

—I will tell you what has happened in New Zealand, which is your favourite case. Disputes in New Zealand are on the rise, in contrast with the Commonwealth, because New Zealand chooses not to use a negotiated and sensible proposition.

—My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister and Minister for Housing and Regional Development. As 1994 is the International Year of the Family, could the minister inform the House of the direct benefits the government's family policies have delivered to Australian families on low incomes?
—Mr Speaker—
—How come you know this question without notice?

—I suppose that the area of family policy is an area that I, like the opposition, take an interest in. It is important that both government and opposition should take a very keen interest in family policy. That is why the question, no doubt, is of universal interest to the parliament. We are all concerned about families. This year the government is investing something like $7 billion into assistance for families. Our approach to families is based on a social policy which we have reconciled with economic policy by ensuring that our policy is well targeted, that it is adequate and that it contains within it, as the Minister for Social Security said, the right work incentives.

PARA.TAB: The system of family support we have in this country is certainly as good as any in the OECD and one of the best in the world. Since we came to office in 1983, the government has dramatically increased the value of family payments to low income families with young children by 80 per cent and to families with teenagers by 150 per cent. What does it actually mean? It means an increase for low income families of the order of $20 a week and an increase for families with teenagers of $33 a week per child.

This government has indexed all family payments for the first time in Australian history. We extended rent assistance to low income families for the first time in 1987. We funded more than 220,000 child-care places with a fivefold increase. We have given the poorest 10 per cent of households of low income people across health and community services the value of $67 per household per week. This is largely due to Medicare, and we remember that the opposition had very grave doubts about Medicare and wanted to dismantle it at the last election. We introduced the child-care rebate and the home child-care allowance—election promises we met. We introduced in the white paper the parenting allowance, and we will develop a new maternity allowance as part of the landmark wage deal struck with the ACTU last week.

From time to time there will be debates in this parliament about the questions of relative income distribution, poverty and inequality. Clearly those questions are not easy; they are complex. But I commend to the opposition a paper released a couple of weeks ago by Professor Ann Harding, Director of the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling. Dr Harding reports that since January 1990 measures such as the 33 per cent increase in additional family payments for young children and the 72 per cent increase in assistance for those with three or more children have had a very great impact. Poverty rates for sole parents appear to have fallen sharply since 1990, four years ago, by 20 to 30 percentage points. These are due to improvements in social security payments and the child support scheme.

I itemise those changes because together they represent a very significant, if not radical, change in family policy. They were achieved, including those quite massive increases in child payments, within an economic policy and in times of very great economic restraint. They result in a commitment to families which has meant that the government has provided the greatest support and assistance to the poorest and the most disadvantaged. They have been achieved to provide the right incentive structure. They have been directed to reduce poverty and unemployment, as far as sole parents are concerned, in what everyone agrees is the most needy group—the group that requires the greatest assistance and support. Against that, the opposition has talked about families. It has talked about a direct—

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Day
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

PETITION.PARA: The Anzacs at the Gallipoli landing on 25 April 1915 were instrumental in forging a new identity for Australia. That landing was a lifetime ago but the deeds of those Anzacs of 1915-18 still speak a message of selfless service and sacrifice that will last forever.

Anzac Day is a day to remember those who left their homes with a strong desire to return but did not, as well as those who did return, but in so doing carried for the remainder of their lives the scars of these experiences.

It is a day to contemplate the spirit that moves men and women to serve, to suffer discomforts, dangers and fears and to risk their lives in defence of their country and in the pursuit of peace, justice and freedom.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House urge the Government to declare Anzac day as Australia's National Day of Commemoration and that it be held on 25 April in each year, and on no other day.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House enact the following changes:

PARA.TAB: 1. That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request the House to approve the necessary expenditure to enable SBS Television to telecast its programs into the Mackay/Pioneer region.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows
That the majority of Australians clearly stand united in satisfaction with their existing Australian National Flag which reflects their values, history and heritage,
And that they condemn unwarranted attacks on their historic Australia Flag, whenever or wherever made by any Australian citizens.

So therefore we call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that the Australian National Flag, as publicly acclaimed in 1901 and confirmed under the Flags Act (1953), is not changed, replaced or diminished at any time, or in any manner whatsoever, without such a proposal being first voted upon and approved by a majority of Australian citizens in a national referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: The Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

PARA.TAB: World-wide, people are concerned that vital natural resources, such as trees, soil, pure air, clean water, and our earth's protective ozone layer—all essential for sustaining life—have been dangerously depleted.

PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned endorse the Earth Repair Charter, and pray that the Australian Parliament will:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to implement the charter's objectives to help end humanity's environmental, social and economic imbalances, so that Australia can lead the way globally, towards achieving just, sustainable and cooperative local and national communities.

PETITION.PARA: The objectives of the Earth Repair Charter are to:

PARA.TAB: Unite nations in earth repair action
Protect natural heritage and biodiversity
Respect indigenous peoples of the world
Acknowledge earth and life as sacred
Resolve conflict by peaceful mediation
Use permaculture to end world hunger
Practise composting to restore soils
Acquire health and immunity efficiency
Promote sustainable living by example
Join with others in a common purpose

PETITION.TITLE: Alternative Medicine
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows that a large percentage of Australian citizens elect to use some form of alternative medicine—for example, homoeopathy, naturopathy and chiropractic—in preference to the general practice provision, and that these citizens are unable to claim benefits from their compulsory government Medicare scheme.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and implement legislation to rectify this discrimination.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Support Agency
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Denison draws to the attention of the House:

PARA.TAB: That the cost of maintenance in its present formula administered by the Child Support Agency is causing severe hardship for the Australian wage earner and creating unemployment in some cases.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House review legislation and administration of Child Support Agency.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia showeth:
The need for the Government to recognise that our flag represents history, heritage and culture and should not be changed without a full referendum of the people.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives call upon the Government to retain our existing Australian Flag and to give Australians the opportunity to express that wish through a referendum.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS: Wide Bay
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain electors in the Division of Wide Bay points out to the House that the Wide Bay was originally scheduled to receive transmission of the Special Broadcasting Service in a submission to the Government in 1985 but was subsequently dropped.
Since then the Wide Bay has experienced one of the biggest population growth rates in Australia and there is now a demand in the community for the service to be provided in the Wide Bay.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to put in motion the procedure for the transmission of the Special Broadcasting Service into the Wide Bay region as soon as possible.
