TALK.START.PARA: —As I have recently changed portfolio in the new opposition arrangements, I would like to take the opportunity afforded by the debate today to offer some reflections on the role of science and technology, my former portfolio responsibility, for the future of Australia. In particular, given my new portfolio responsibilities, I want to draw the attention of the House to the consequences for employment and Australia's families of the government's abject failure to develop any clear, long-term strategic approach to science and technology in this country.

PARA.TAB: Science and technology expresses a key element of the vision that the coalition has for Australia's future. This vision is of an Australia which builds on its outstanding capacity in science and technology and on the highly enterprising national character that Australians have to reassert its role as major player in the expansion of trade and industry and investment in the Asia-Pacific region.

Science and technology must be a driving force of change in this generation if we are to set ourselves the goal of once more becoming one of the top 10 nations of the world in terms of GDP per capita. Achieving this is crucial to dealing effectively with Australia's unacceptable levels of unemployment and underemployment. Science and technology is relevant to all our industry sectors including service industries, the fastest growing sector of world trade. Increasingly, the competitive edge in service industries is determined by technology, particularly information and communications technology.

Although now the shadow minister for employment, training and family services, I had responsibility for science and technology for the last 13 months, a period punctuated by instability in government policy, broken promises and little or no action by the government on the significant problems which are holding back the national effort in this critical area.

Put simply, science and technology just does not rate in the view of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Prime Minister, who is not known for his interest in this area, is more concerned about a new constitution for his republic and about changing the flag than he is about developing Australia as a scientifically and technologically advanced nation. As a result, Australia is falling behind the rest of the world in an area that is becoming increasingly vital in terms of national competitive advantage. A recent UNESCO study found that the science and technology effort of countries such as Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan now surpasses that of Australia. A decade ago the Australian industry effort in research and development ranked 17th out of 24 OECD nations. Despite all the government's rhetoric, this remains the case.

In relation to the universities, the government has deliberately ignored the recommendations of the Boston research group and the National Board of Employment, Education and Training to substantially increase resources for declining research infrastructure. This is one of the most serious issues facing Australian science today, and it threatens the world-class quality of Australia's fundamental research.

Perhaps the most disheartening aspect of the past year has been the government's treatment of the nation's premier research organisation, the CSIRO. As I said at the National Science Forum earlier this month, the decisions taken in the budget in relation to science agencies are the culmination of one of the most disgraceful episodes in the history of science policy.

The last year saw a minister criticised by leading science organisations and scientists alike, and now discredited. His scheme to break up the CSIRO and establish a new national marine science institute demoralised the organisation and severely affected the national research effort. It saw a complete rejection of proper processes of consultation, broken election promises, a breakdown in the system of triennial funding and—the final ignominy—a cut of some $20 million in funding to the CSIRO when compared with the last triennium. All this comes from a government which stated just prior to the last election, `Significant changes and disruption to the way the CSIRO is structured and funded are not on the agenda.'

One of my achievements of which I am most proud during my time in the shadow portfolio was the fact that by our firmness of resolve we in the coalition were able to save the CSIRO from the minister's attacks and stop the organisation being broken up on ministerial whim. As a result of the vigorous opposition we were able to mount in this parliament and in the wider community, the Prime Minister was ultimately forced to remove the former minister for science, Senator Schacht, from his portfolio. The many letters and calls I received from scientists around the country thanking me for the coalition's key role in defending science during this period were greatly appreciated and are a source of particular pride.

Not all the time I spent as the shadow minister for science, technology and export development was spent in protecting Australia's science base, although we did as much as we could to protect it from the depradations of Senator Schacht and his colleagues. The past 13 months have been a very positive and constructive period in the relations between the coalition and the science community. In particular, I was moved at the recent industry policy workshop by the acknowledgment from Sir Gustav Nossal, as the incoming President of the Australian Academy of Science, of the high profile the coalition was giving to science policy since the election.

I also want to acknowledge the excellent work of the coalition policy committee on industry, technology and consumer affairs. In particular, I acknowledge the work of the chairman of the committee, Senator Grant Chapman, and the secretary, Senator Brian Gibson. Above all, I want to acknowledge the genuine and full interest in the portfolio from the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who firmly re-established in the science community the priority the coalition has traditionally given to science and technology policy.

During my time in the portfolio, I was fortunate to have the opportunity to view at first-hand the excellent research being conducted by the CSIRO in many of its divisions. In addition, I make special mention of the work being conducted by the Australian Institute of Marine Science in areas such as reef conservation and the development of our mariculture industry, and also by the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation in medical and environmental research.

Most important, however, are the people themselves—the dedicated scientists, technologists and engineers who have made a disproportionate contribution to world science and whose work has improved the quality of life of all Australians. I have been fortunate enough to meet many of Australia's scientists and would like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to them all. In particular, I would like to thank Professor Adrienne Clarke, Chairman of the CSIRO; Dr John Stocker, the Chief Executive of the CSIRO; Professor David Craig, the immediate past President of the Australian Academy of Science; Sir Gustav Nossal, the current President of the Australian Academy of Science; Sir Rupert Myers, the President of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering; and Professor Ralph Slatyer, Australia's former chief scientist. These people are worthy leaders of the nation's scientific research

SPEECH.PARA: effort, and as a country we are fortunate indeed.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to pay tribute to the chief executives of the all too few small and medium sized enterprises who have seized the technology challenge and are successfully leading the private sector through their competitiveness into export markets. I am also pleased to note that, with the responsibility transferred to my colleague Senator Hill, science and technology continues as a senior cabinet level post in the opposition. This indicates the top level priority we in the coalition continue to give to science and technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to address the issue of the recent Northern Territory election. I want to do so to highlight a number of important issues which I think are relevant to public debate in this country.

PARA.TAB: At the weekend the people of the Northern Territory made a judgment in terms of their political masters for the next four years. They chose to support the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory, as is their right and, in this instance, as is their wont—notwithstanding the fact that there was a swing towards the Labor Party.

The issue that I want to confront—and that I think the opposition ought to confront—is the way in which the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party government, led by Chief Minister Marshall Perron, waged a very divisive and quite racist campaign. I know there are members in the opposition who are afraid to confront the unpleasant reality of the way in which this campaign was waged, but I suggest that for successive elections over 20 years the CLP has fostered a mythology over a number of areas which ought to be relevant to the opposition. The CLP says, firstly, that the territory's lifestyle can be safeguarded only by the incumbent government; secondly, that southern influence is the greatest threat to territory lifestyle and that the Commonwealth—for that, read `the Labor government'—in Canberra is the greatest impediment to Northern Territory development; and, thirdly, that Labor governments favour the NT Aboriginal community over other territorians and have an agenda to give Aboriginals control of the territory.

Nothing could be further from the truth. This mythology has been at the heart of every CLP election campaign since self-government, and the campaign just concluded was no exception. The real tragedy of these themes is their basic divisiveness: they set the territory against other parts of Australia and one group of territorians against another.
Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —When these themes are used as a basis for an election campaign, as the CLP has used them in election after election, it is inevitable that such campaigns will operate on the lowest common denominator—and this was no exception.

PARA.TAB: Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I will very briefly address the issue that southern influence is the greatest threat to the territory's lifestyle and that the territory's lifestyle can be protected only by the incumbent CLP government. The most obvious point to be made, even to the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), is that 80 per cent of the Northern Territory government's budget revenue comes from taxpayers in Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia, Queensland, New South Wales, the ACT and Tasmania. The fact is that territorians benefit as a result of the fact that the Commonwealth sees fit to provide it with 80 per cent of its revenue, which the territory government claims carriage over and then seeks to spend it as it normally does and to claim within the budget context that those expenditures are its own.

PARA.TAB: The first and most obvious example of this is the claim on electoral material used by the CLP that it has given massive expenditure for Aboriginal housing. I will give the answer. This year's CLP budget has an item which lists $19 million for Aboriginal housing. The Commonwealth budget papers show the $19 million as a specific purpose grant under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. It is a Commonwealth program; it is not a program of the Northern Territory government.

This argument that the CLP government is the protector of this lifestyle is absolutely false. The protector of this very important lifestyle is the Labor government in Canberra. The Labor government in Canberra funds the programs which the Northern Territory government runs. The Labor government in Canberra is responsible for providing both directly and indirectly for the employment of all public servants in the Northern Territory. The Labor government in Canberra is responsible for funding most of the construction activity in Darwin and its environs. The Labor government in Canberra is responsible for funding the Northern Territory University. The Labor government in Canberra is responsible for providing most of the capital works funding which takes place in the Northern Territory.

I heard my colleague from the Northern Territory the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), this afternoon, in answer to a question in the Senate about the impact of this expenditure, say that, if the defence expenditure which comes from the Commonwealth for the Northern Territory economy were withdrawn, unemployment in the Northern Territory would increase seven times. That is just a basic point. So the lifestyle which is being so-called protected by the CLP is being protected to the extent that the CLP spends money given to it by this Labor government. It uses its discretion about components of that budget. What does it do? The CLP uses it to underwrite its own debt. We might record that it has the highest per capita debt level in Australia.

The major purpose of my making this address this afternoon is to raise the issue of the way in which the CLP plays the politics of racial division. Most thinking Australians realise that the only real division in the territory is very simply based on poverty—the haves versus the have-nots.

The reality is that one-quarter of the territory's population is Aboriginal and primarily has Third World living conditions. Aboriginal people have the highest unemployment rate, the highest infant mortality rate and the highest morbidity rates in Australia; in fact, Aborigines have the lowest income levels of any group of people in Australia. The same territory government then argues that the Northern Territory CLP government does not and cannot support any concept of social justice or equity.

I have in front of me a copy of the headlines from the Australian newspaper of 18 May. They make it clear that what this election was all about was not lost on those who are commentators in the political scene. One headline reads `The politics of race key to victory'. Another headline states `NT poll opens with race row'.

Let us not walk away from it. The Northern Territory CLP government, at every election—be they local elections in the Northern Territory or federal elections—for the 20 years that it has been in power has tried to divide the community on the basis of race. This time has been no exception. In a letter addressed to his constituents, the Northern Territory Chief Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Labor policy on Law and Order states that our Police will be directed to treat Aboriginal offenders more leniently than other people.
Perron's letter went on to claim that the Northern Territory Labor Party also proposed that courts `be more flexible in sentencing Aborigines'. Perron then stated:
The CLP absolutely rejects this concept.
Why did the CLP government in the Northern Territory accord support for the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody?

PARA.TAB: I will quote a number of those recommendations. Recommendation 86A, which is supported by the Northern Territory government—the CLP—states that offensive behaviour during police approaches is not to be the basis of a charge. Recommendation 92 refers to using legislation regarding prison as a last resort. Recommendation 117 deals with legislation regarding automatic imprisonment and not following the breach of community service order. It goes on.

The fact is that the CLP was seeking to divide the community—to pit territorians against each other. I have further examples. On another occasion I would seek to table this document, which is a copy of a direct mail letter from the Northern Territory Chief Minister to his constituents. He makes it very clear that the purpose of the CLP's campaign is to divide non-Aboriginal territorians against Aboriginal territorians. I will quote from a television advertisement which was put on by the CLP:

SPEECH.PARA: But the Labor Party wants to bring in different rules for different people. That is not fair. That is racism. We have a system that works. Why change it?

I do not apologise for the fact that I support social justice initiatives for Aboriginal territorians. I do not apologise for the fact that we should be addressing the issue of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I do not apologise for wanting to address the health issues confronting Aboriginal territorians. I do not apologise for any of these things. I ask members of the opposition to think about the precedent here. Instead of advocating reconciliation in the Northern Territory community, the CLP sought to divide Aboriginal territorians against non-Aboriginal territorians and vice versa, and territorians against the rest of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill 1994 has a long history. The report which we were requested to do into this bill poses more questions than it answers. PARA.TAB: The coalition is apprehensive about the legislation, which is written in the vaguest of terms. Clause 65VE(2) represents the main function of the bill. Goods may be labelled `Produce of Australia' or `Product of Australia' if Australia is the place of origin of each major ingredient. I refer to the question of seasonal supply fluctuations. The committee addressed this question and came up with a recommendation which appears on page 6 of the report. It describes options that are available under the legislation for producers of goods who may be unable to source a major ingredient locally due to seasonal supply fluctuations. Once again, the term `major ingredient' is used in the bill.

In the event that this proposal is successful and passes both houses of parliament, I think it is necessary to refer to the third recommendation of the committee's report. Our third recommendation addresses the question of the implementation of this legislation, should it be successful. We believe that a 12-month phase-in period, which was initially proposed in the bill, is insufficient time for manufacturers to make the necessary adjustments to their equipment and machinery. We have suggested that, in order to meet those commitments of origin labelling, the term for the phase-in period should be extended to 18 months. Furthermore, we have suggested that flexibility be introduced so that, where the costs associated with the changes are considered prohibitively expensive, producers will be allowed to seek exemption for a further 12 months after that. That was done in an effort to meet a lot of concerns put forward to the committee by organisations such as the Grocery Manufacturers of Australia and the National Farmers Federation.

The state and regional references were also addressed by the committee. As is noted on page 7, paragraph 33 of the report, the committee believes that the producers should be able to use a state or regional reference on their label if they believe that this will give them a marketing advantage over other products. As I said, the coalition is far from satisfied with the total contents of the report. We will reserve judgment on the transition between here and the other place.

At this juncture, I would like to thank the staff of the industry, science and technology committee for their help and perseverance. It has been a most difficult task for the committee to try to address at very short notice and in a very short space of time what is an extremely complex issue. But members of the public of Australia are looking for a clear and precise definition of products that are produced in Australia and for products that carry a true representation on the label of where that product is sourced from. I compliment the secretary of the committee, Mr Paul McMahon, and his assistants for their fine work in assisting us with this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I obviously support the overview given by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid). I would just like to add a couple of other points. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) raised an important point: this is the third time in the history of the House of Representatives that a bill has been referred by the parliament to a House of Representatives standing committee. PARA.TAB: This is a complex matter and it deals with two major issues which need to be resolved. The minister has come up with a working party, which I have to say, is a confab, a great big meeting, of the bureaucracies. It is not an industry committee or a committee of people from industry, business or even consumer groups which put together this bill; it has come from and is of the bureaucracy.

It essentially gives us in Australia the unique position of having a two-stage labelling requirement. One is `Product of Australia' or `Produce of Australia', being a higher quality identifier of goods which are Australian. Basically those are almost all Australian goods. `Made in Australia' has the same meaning and connotation as found by the High Court in examining those cases where people have been brought to trial under the Trade Practices Act and have been found wanting. PARA.TAB: On page 3.110 of budget paper No. 1, a brief explanation is given of `disaster relief payment'. It is equivalent to two weeks pension plus AFP and rent assistance at the maximum rate appropriate to the claimant's family circumstances and it disregards income and assets testing.

In January 1994, the government varied the rate of the disaster relief payment for individuals and families affected by the New South Wales bushfires. Victims and voluntary firefighters who lost income for seven days or more were paid the disaster relief payment and were also provided with additional special assistance equal to twice the normal payment. So, in effect, they were provided with three times the normal payment. Under the natural disaster relief arrangements, funding was also provided to the New South Wales government to cover the cost of bushfires. On page 3.252 of budget paper No. 1, further information is given about natural disaster relief. Figures are given to show that, in the year 1993-94, estimated expenditure was $315.7 million and, in the year 1994-95, estimated expenditure was $432.5 million.

I support strongly the additional payment—an increase of virtually 200 per cent—given by the Prime Minister to the New South Wales bushfire victims following those disastrous bushfires. However, I want to raise a matter of grave concern. On 3 October last year, Victoria had the most serious major flood it has had in the last hundred years. The whole idea of funding a republic advisory committee to the tune of $600,000 is as unfair and biased as if the government had appointed a monarchy advisory committee and put Michael Kirby at the head of it, put Lloyd Waddy on it and paid them $600,000 to go around the countryside spruiking a particular point of view. So there is an extraordinary bias in this. It is very poor that the DAS allocation was so badly misused.

PARA.TAB: The Department of Administrative Services is responsible for the provision of our beautiful Australian flag. So many Australians on this 6 June are appalled that the Prime Minister of this country (Mr Keating) is not in full support of our beautiful Australian flag. As Dr Evatt, that former Labor leader, said, it is quite simply the most beautiful flag in the world. So many good members of the Labor Party are embarrassed and ashamed that the Prime Minister of this country is not prepared to give his wholehearted endorsement to the Australian flag.

But the flag is not the only thing that the Prime Minister does not like. The Prime Minister does not like the Queen of Australia, either, whose portraits the Department of Administrative Services is responsible for providing. He is a great man, our Prime Minister. He does not like the flag; he does not like the Queen; he does not like the footy; he does not like the quarter-acre block—

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't understand the footy.
—He does not understand anything at all. The Prime Minister does not even like the servants in the Lodge.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I know that debates on the Department of Administrative Services and other departments are wide-ranging, but you have allowed the honourable member to refer to all sorts of matters in relation to the Prime Minister's views which are irrelevant to the issue of administrative services. If he wants to have a debate about his ridiculous views on the monarchy he should bring it on in this House. We will take him on any time.

While he might have taken a bit of licence, I think he was directing his attention to services that are provided to the Department of Administrative Services, including the flag and photographs of the Queen. But the honourable member will come back to the matter at hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. Here we have the Department of Administrative Services producing photographs of Her Majesty the Queen—the Queen whom the Prime Minister whilst in this country so dislikes. But it seems that he cannot wait to be in her presence as soon as he gets out of this country. Where is the Prime Minister today? He is hobnobbing it with the rich and famous. Where? On board the royal yacht, Britannia. I certainly hope he is enjoying Her Majesty's hospitality because she is a most gracious lady. But it is interesting, is it not? —I follow on from some of the observations made by my most illustrious colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott). The Department of Administrative Services is, of course, responsible for national symbols. Any nation worth its salt has national symbols, and Australia is no exception. Our national symbols, which have been developed gradually since the turn of the last century based upon our constitution, the flag, our flora and fauna, the animal life of this nation, go back to the very earliest form of flag—which the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Dr Theophanous) will find in Old Parliament House, if he bothers to go there and have a look—which dates back to somewhere around 1815. These are all symbols of a nation, of a young people who were seeking to find a degree of unity in this vast land—a vast land inhabited at that stage by a small group of European colonists based around the seaboard, with the indigenous population in the inland and very little understanding of what the nation as a whole had to offer. But those people over the next 50 to 100 years built up a degree of strength of belief in their own capacity which has led this country forward ever since.

PARA.TAB: In many respects, of course, it first came to be seen in an international sense at the landing at Gallipoli. The history of Gallipoli is well known to the parliamentary secretary; he knows the detail of that. But the important thing was that that young nation, represented by its young men, wanted to show the world what Australians could do when they worked together.

That is why national symbols are so important: they are meant to unify a nation not divide it; they are meant to identify the historical process which achieved the Australia that we know today and which, hopefully, will lead us to greatness in the future. It is not something that one is ashamed of; it is not something one locks away in the back cupboard and hopes everybody will forget. We are not talking about a George Orwellian 1984 type situation of books being banned and `thoughtspeak' being applied across the land—although there is a degree of thoughtspeak in Australia today: we are not supposed to be interested in the past unless it is a version of history of which the Labor Party approves.

There are plenty of historians in this country who have different versions of Australian history. That is one of the realities of the historical process, as the parliamentary secretary would be well aware. Each one of half a dozen historians will give us subtly different views on what we see as the facts or the interpretation of the facts of history. Nevertheless, when we talk about national symbols, that is what we are talking about: where Australia came from, and how we want to use those symbols to hold us all together. I would like to go a step further on this, and on this point I will agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need our own symbols.

—We do have our own symbols. These symbols were chosen by Australians. They were not chosen by anyone else. We freely chose them ourselves. I would go a step further and put a new initiative into this debate.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! It would be appropriate if the honourable member directed his comments through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. I think the time has come when we need also to consider a national symbol which incorporates the Aboriginal element of our history and present civilisation. For example—and I do not make a judgment on this—we have the rainbow serpent which, as I understand it, certainly in the Aboriginal tribal communities of Central Australia, is a symbol of enormous historical, cultural and religious significance. Perhaps we should consider that the rainbow serpent should become one of the national symbols, along with the other national symbols we have in Australia, to achieve the point I made earlier: unity of the nation so that its various constituent parts can see, in those symbolic elements which interpret the past, the capacity to build a common future—a common future where, irrespective of where people come from, regardless of their nationality and in terms of the past, their one common element is that together they share the future of Australia. Whether we are Aboriginal Australians, Chinese Australians, European Australians or Indian Australians or anyone else is irrelevant.
—That's why we need to change the flag.

—It is not necessary to change the flag to achieve that objective, because the flag is a demonstration of the past linked in with the future and the present. That is what the symbolic substance of all those things is all about.
—Do you know that 40 per cent of Australian people don't identify with the Union Jack?

—That is because nobody in the educational process has bothered to explain to them what they should identify with. I believe that the Department of Administrative Services has a very important role to play through the parliament in achieving that. (Time expired)

—I am very pleased to join this debate on the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services whilst considering in detail Appropriation Bill (No. 1). Like many other Australians and, indeed, every member on this side of the chamber—and I suspect a few of those opposite—I have been concerned at the government's commitment to dump national symbols, national pride, our constitution, our national structures and, particularly, at the abuse of taxpayers' money which is emanating towards the achievement of the government's aims. There have been reports that $50 million worth of taxpayers' money will be used with a view to changing the national flag. That is one of the matters that this parliament has to consider: whether or not that is an appropriate use of taxpayers' money.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker—
—There's 50 million bucks in the budget for it.
—We do not have 50 million bucks in the budget for it.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! Is that the point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of order is that, as the honourable member knows, no such moneys have been put aside. This is simply a red herring.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—It is very sad that, when people here endeavour to raise matters of vital national concern, we find there is an attempt from those opposite to gag us, to stop us from speaking. Only last Thursday in the parliament, I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) a very serious question. He completely refused to answer and the government used its numbers to gag me and toss me out of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, we have a system in this nation that works well. The honourable member opposite has claimed, quite correctly, that a number of people in this country come from non-traditional sources or what some would call non-traditional sources. Those people came here because of what we are as a nation. Those people came here because of our standards, our constitution, our stability, our freedom—not because of what some would have us become.

The essential nature of our constitution is one of a constitutional monarchy. The conventions surrounding that constitutional monarchy are the guarantee of independence and freedom that we have as a nation. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Dr Theophanous) said that $50 million has not been set aside for a campaign to change the flag. The truth of the matter is that taxpayers' money is being used by this government over and over again with a view to achieving its aims of gutting our constitution. Some people would say that its aims are sacking the Queen and scrapping the flag.

We saw an amount of money allocated for the so-called Republican Advisory Committee. Was a similar amount of money given to the Australians for Constitutional Monarchy? No. That is an example of the government's uneven and biased approach. We find, undoubtedly, every time we open a newspaper that government spokesmen are talking about changing the national flag. I think it is appropriate just to mention what that national flag means.

We have the Union Jack which is symbolic of the Christian heritage of this nation: the three Christian crosses of St George, St Andrew and St Patrick superimposed one upon the other to form the Union Jack. That also indicates our inheritance of Westminster traditions and those of democracy and freedom. We have the Southern Cross on our flag which is symbolic of our geographic position in the world. We can ask any schoolboy or schoolgirl in Australia what the Southern Cross is; everyone knows. We only see it over Australia and other nations in the Southern Hemisphere.

The federal star has seven points, representing one point for each of the six states of Australia and the seventh point representing the Australian federal territories. Our national flag represents our national heritage, traditions, federal system of government and geographic position in the world. I think it is absolutely disgusting when the Department of Administrative Services or any other department moves in the direction of using taxpayers' money to undermine such vital national symbols, particularly on the day when the Prime Minister is at Normandy supposedly joining in the commemoration of the landing 50 years ago. The Prime Minister is a hypocrite. The people of Australia and the people opposite know it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker—
—The member opposite should sit down because he is a hypocrite.

—I raise a point of order. I take exception to that comment and I ask you to withdraw. I also take exception to the comment in relation to the Prime Minister. You ought to be ashamed of yourself. You do not deserve to be in this place.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to withdraw that remark.
—Which remark? The Prime Minister was a hypocrite? Shall we say that he is a person who does not seem to have an honest, even-handed approach—
—Order! I asked you to withdraw.

—I wish to make a few remarks in response to this debate about allocations within the Department of Administrative Services, the issues of the flag and the republic and in response to the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). It is a strange sense of nationhood when one takes, as one of the important national symbols, another country's flag and puts it in our flag. It is a strange sense of nationhood when one takes constitutional arrangements from another nation and tries to supplant them upon an independent nation such as Australia.

PARA.TAB: This is very much an issue of generational change in Australia as one of the great divisions in Australian politics is between younger and older people. Any political party that wants to stay relevant and any government that hopes to be relevant to the electorate must be aware of the way in which Australian values and attitudes are changing. In my electorate there is a high proportion of young people. In speaking to them, I have found that they have no bonds to or memories of Britain. They have no affection or emotion about the Union Jack. Indeed, they wonder why Australia, an independent nation approaching its centenary of Federation, needs to keep another nation's flag as part of its national symbol. So this government should do anything it can to further that debate and to further the views of younger Australians.

The outlays in this department are entirely appropriate as are any efforts on the part of this government to provoke a debate about constitutional arrangements. Again, any party that hopes to remain relevant and effective in Australia needs to have regard to younger Australians and new arrivals in Australia . My electorate of Werriwa has a high proportion of migrant and ethnic populations. They hold no affection and no values for the British constitutional arrangements. They regard it as quite unusual that Australia would carry the British sovereign as its head of state. My own experience with this goes to the time when, as mayor of Liverpool, I issued the oath and affirmation of allegiance for citizenship ceremonies. People who have come from nations that may have been at war with Britain in years gone by or nations that have no affinity with Britain could only wonder why they needed to take any amount of allegiance to the Queen.

Those things are all about relevance. The shellback opinions that honourable members opposite hold on those subjects are fading away in Australia and the opinions of younger people are becoming the dominant set of opinions and values in Australia. I would have thought that an opposition would bring in new people with relevant values and attitudes, but the Liberal party has not. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said, it is bringing in the old fogies and the young fogies.

That is a great problem for the Liberal Party. It is not maintaining relevance to the way in which the majority of younger Australians look at their country. They are proud of Australia and they are proud of Australian independence. They want that independence reflected in all fashions. They want it reflected in our flag; they do not want to carry the symbol of another nation in our national symbol. They want that feeling of Australian independence and nationhood reflected in all aspects of our constitution. That means they want an Australian and not the resident or sovereign of another nation as our head of state, which I would regard as the ultimate reflection of Australian independence.

If the Liberal and National parties had any regard for nationhood, they would agree. How can a nation be independent in the proper sense of nationhood unless it has a head of state who is an Australian citizen determined in some democratic fashion either by the Australian people or the Australian parliament? We cannot be an independent nation expressing the full values of nationhood unless we have independence in all our national symbols and all our constitutional arrangements.

I am very confident that as this debate proceeds across time it is inevitable, as Premier Fahey, Nick Greiner and Peter Collins in my own state acknowledge, that the values of younger Australians will take greater hold in referendum questions and elections in years to come and the republic and changes to the flag will come about. The main thing with which we can console ourselves on this side is that the Liberal Party represents the views and values of older Australians and they will fade away over time. On this side of the chamber maintaining relevance and upholding the true importance of Australian independence and nationhood means that we represent the majority of Australians. I am sure that this is what is being reflected in the departmental appropriation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thing which is so depressing about what we have heard from honourable members opposite is their constant running down of this nation. Why can they not get behind our symbols? Why can they not get behind our constitution? Why can they not build this country up instead of undermining it and trying to engage in acts of constitutional vandalism? The arguments opposite are a slander on Australia and Australians.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members opposite are saying that we are not completely independent today and we are not fully mature as a nation. What an outrage! What an outrage for them to suggest that in some way the pioneers were not doing it for Australia, that in some way the Anzacs were Poms with funny accents. That is not true. They were proud Australians who were proud of the symbols of this country. I suggest to honourable members opposite that they get behind those symbols like us because that is the voice of Australia.

These symbols are not the symbols of another country; they are the symbols of Australia. If the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), says that just because Her Majesty the Queen is resident for most of the year somewhere else, just because she is a great international citizen and just because she speaks Australian with a strange accent she cannot be a part of our constitution, what does that say about all the millions of good Australians who carry other passports and speak with different accents? Can they not be good Australians? This republican push is a dagger aimed at the heart of the principles of multiculturalism, which the parliamentary secretary and the government claim to hold dear.

The longer this debate goes on, the more people are rejecting the government's viewpoint. The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) claimed that young people were overwhelmingly republican. That is not true. The irony of this debate is that the only people who are significantly republican are middle aged people like the parliamentary secretary. Old people have the wisdom of experience. They appreciate the strengths in our constitution. Young people have the idealism of youth and they want to get behind the symbols which are part of this nation.

This is not in any way about links with Britain. This is about building a better Australia. This is about building on our strengths and making our system work. Honourable members opposite know that we do not have any constitutional problems. We just have political problems in this country. We do not need to change our constitution. We just need to change a few policies and politicians, and we can start by changing the parliamentary secretary and some of his colleagues. The longer this debate goes on, the more people are swinging behind the constitution that we have.

The opinion polls are a terrible disappointment to the republicans. The more the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Mr Turnbull talk, the less people like what they hear. We have had this debate now for over 18 months. We know everything possible about our constitution. We know everything possible about the republican option. I say to the government that if it is serious about this change it should make it now. It should have the courage of its convictions and come to a referendum now, and not engage in this vandalism.

The total estimated expenditure for the new Industrial Relations Court is $5,641,000. It is being set up at very great expense so that unions and their mates can get special deals. Union bosses know that the ordinary law will not apply in what could very well become a kangaroo court. Members of the House would have heard in debates the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) pointing out the very great danger of having special courts for special people. The Industrial Relations Court of Australia was part of the disastrous Industrial Relations Reform Bill, which will have to be amended and which the minister has admitted must be amended if jobs are to be created and not lost.

I get very suspicious when I find that the ordinary courts of the land are shut out from some sphere of human activity. We need to get as many matters as possible back into the ordinary courts of the land—the real courts, the courts where the ordinary law applies, the courts where people have confidence that there are not going to be special deals for special people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member for Warringah for his supportive interjection. The Industrial Relations Court will undoubtedly be a kangaroo court; it will undoubtedly be a court which will not see the sort of industrial law imposed in this nation that most Australians want. The Federal Court should be the court to administer the secondary boycott provisions, but the government has given the responsibility for that part of the law to the new Industrial Relations Court. The government knows that the Industrial Relations Court will be much more supportive and sympathetic to unions than the real courts, including the Federal Court, have been in the past.

PARA.TAB: The government's administration of industrial relations has been an unmitigated disaster. Look at the current situation. Last year's budget promised jobs, jobs, jobs. We saw no jobs—just a green paper and then a white paper, and now we have one million people out of work and possibly another one million people unable to find adequate work. After 11 sordid years of Labor in office, we find that we now have a permanent underclass. We have the highest level of income disparity of any OECD nation and the highest welfare dependency seen in decades. Instead of spending money to help people find real jobs, to give people and families in this International Year of the Family some chance of having a future, this government finds millions of dollars to set up what could become a kangaroo court to appease its unions mates.

This year's budget is a disaster. It is a wasteful budget with rubbery estimates, with shonky figures and with unrealistic sale prices placed on assets. Obviously, the financing of this budget is dominated by electoral strategy. The government wants to keep the union bosses on side. It wants to buy the votes of minority lobby groups and to gamble with Australia's future. Never mind Australia's atrocious international reputation in terms of income disparity, never mind the fact that entire communities of Australia's indigenous people are living in squalor in regional Australia; this government sets up what it perceives to be a vote-winning body, a politically correct body, and seeks to use taxpayers' money to fund its own special ideological activities. That is a great tragedy.

We also have the so-called National Native Title Tribunal being set up, on which the government is going to spend $8.3 million or thereabouts in its first year. The opposition has always been totally opposed to the National Native Title Tribunal and remains so. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the appropriations for the Attorney-General's Department. I refer to an entry from statement 3 of budget paper No. 1 under the heading `Law, order and public safety' on page 3.203:

SPEECH.PARA: .Outlays on Law, Order and Public Safety in 1994-95 are estimated to increase by $25.5m or 3.0% . . .
On the following page, under the main reasons for the increase in outlays in 1994-95, it says:
-funding for a number of Access to Justice initiatives;

In the measures table found on that same page, for the financial year 1994-95 outlays for access to justice initiatives are said to be $6.4 million, increasing to $6.8 million by the 1997-98 financial year. PARA.TAB: It is worth drawing the attention of the House to the terms of reference of that advisory committee, which was chaired by Mr Sackville QC. I will quote only an extract from the terms of reference:

SPEECH.PARA: The Access to Justice Advisory Committee will be appointed by the Attorney-General . . . to make recommendations for reform of the administration of the Commonwealth justice and legal system in order to enhance access to justice and render the system fairer, more efficient and more effective.
Some very precise indications were given to the committee for it to pay close attention to—and some are worthy of drawing express attention to now. They included:
.the creation of an integrated national legal profession . . . ;
.the establishment of a suitable mechanism to hear complaints from consumers . . . ;
.the functioning of the Federal Costs Advisory Committee and the method of determination of fee scales . . . ;
.the removal of anti-competitive restrictions upon practice by lawyers. . . ;
.sanctions in cases of deliberate delay in federal courts; and
.the use of contingency fees . . .
As well as those legislative aspects of the terms of reference, the committee was asked to look at some administrative measures which might assist in making the system fairer, and these included:
.best methods of facilitating pre-trial settlement of matters;
.the most effective way of promoting best practice in case management; and
.the most effective way of revising court procedures to streamline all unnecessary or ineffective rules of procedure.
Importantly, so far as competition policy is concerned, the advisory committee was expressly asked to consider:
.the extension of the Trade Practices Act to the legal profession . . .

PARA.TAB: The report which was the result of those terms of reference was published in May of this year. It is a weighty tome, but it is well worth a read. It is entitled Access to justice: an action plan. I was particularly pleased to see the Attorney-General on the release of that report outlining his plan of action to ensure that Access to justice is considered seriously and methodically by the government. In his press release on the release of the report, the Attorney-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Government recognises that the majority of Australians do not believe the justice system is either accessible or affordable to them.

The program outlined by the Attorney-General included the establishment of a specialist access to justice unit within the Attorney-General's Department and a program of national forums and community consultation. I was particularly pleased to see the Attorney-General in the House in question time last week make an optimistic comment. He said:
Unlike reports in the past, I think there is now some ground for optimism that what is needed—and that is a sense of consensus in terms of achieving reform—is within grasp.

He then called upon the states and the legal profession to take part in this vital reform process of access to justice. It is essential that that call be taken up to ensure we see a fairer, more efficient and more effective justice and legal system. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to note the $264,000 allocated to the Constitutional Centenary Foundation and the $5 million or so allocated to the Office of General Counsel. I rise in particular to contrast the approach to citizenship education which is coming from both of these sections of the bureaucracy, or which this money is generating. I might say how much I have enjoyed the exchanges of the last half hour or so and how pleased I am to see this House talking about some of these important issues. I only wish they were matters we talked about more at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, but it seems our betters have other things to discuss.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the Constitutional Centenary Foundation, which is fundamentally a government funded organisation, is adopting the correct approach to this matter. It is balanced, it is non-partisan and it includes on its board people of all sorts of different persuasions on the great constitutional questions before us. The Office of the General Counsel—this is not the General Counsel's fault—by contrast is forced to adopt the government line. Of course, the government line is that education for citizenship is not so much explaining the rights and duties of Australian citizens but it is more trying to change the attitudes of future Australian citizens by bringing constitutional education into our schools. This is something that we have to be extremely worried about.

This variant of education for citizenship is not so much citizenship as it has been understood, but is rather re-education for politically correct citizenship. I refer in particular to a paper prepared by Professor Donald Horne, Education for citizenship, under the auspices of the ideas for Australia program. Professor Horne's paper talks about the sorts of things young Australians need to know in order to be better citizens. He talks about things like the history of the arbitration commission and the conciliation court. Specific absences from the list of priorities in Professor Horne's Education for citizenship paper are matters like the Anzacs and the pioneers. It would be an absolute tragedy if this was ever downplayed in the cause of political correctness.

If we want to have a better educated citizenry in this country, if we wish to have Australians who have a better sense of self, the answer is not politically correct education in schools or warmed over, pre-digested, officially approved citizenship. The best way to give our young Australians a better sense of themselves is simply to teach Australian history. This is the approach of the Constitutional Centenary Foundation, which has $264,000, and not the approach of the government and the Attorney-General's Department, which has so many millions.

If we were to adopt a proper approach to education for citizenship and if we were to adopt a proper approach to constitutional education, we would be telling our school children that the Australian constitution has evolved marvellously over the last 94 years and that the Crown has evolved marvellously over the last 94 years. Whereas 94 years ago we were under the British Crown and our Governor-General was an Englishman representing the British government, today we are under the Australian Crown and our Governor-General is always a distinguished Australian representing the Australian people in the Queen's name. This is the kind of history and the kind of evolution that we should be proud of, not critical of.

Any form of constitutional education should focus on the virtues of our existing system and it should make people aware that our existing system is like a marvellously complicated clock. One thing is changed and everything else is affected. We cannot just pull out one element, the Crown, and pretend that everything else will go on as if nothing has changed. There are a lot of lawyers in this parliament. The lawyers in this parliament know that if a comma in a legal document is changed the whole effect can be changed. People are trying to pretend that we can take a couple of terms, the Crown and the Governor-General, out of our constitution and not change anything else. Of course it is nonsense, of course the government knows it and any form of constitutional education should acknowledge it, too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In listening to this debate one can pick one of the golden rules of the Liberal Party in the 1990s. Even though it talks about the rights of the individual in its rhetoric, in practice it is opposed to constitutional rights for Australians; that is, constitutional independence and the republic. It is opposed to land rights for Australian Aborigines and it is opposed to human rights for certain parts of our society.

PARA.TAB: I support entirely the outlays that have been provided for the Attorney-General's Department to proceed with certain human rights legislation and action in this parliament. The first of those relates to the announcement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 28 May to introduce racial vilification laws to dissuade those who seek to incite violence and hatred against particular groups defined by ethnic origin; that is, the government will be reintroducing those provisions of the Racial Discrimination Legislation Amendment Bill first introduced by the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) during his period as Attorney-General in December 1992.

This reflects the great Australian tradition and history of social tolerance. It also reflects the great Australian success story in the 1970s and 1980s of the development of a multicultural society that is the envy of other parts of the world. I note with interest the lukewarm reception that the opposition has given this particular provision to outlaw racial vilification. It seems to place more importance on states rights than human rights. The point is, though, that we need national laws.

In 1989, to his great credit the then premier of New South Wales, Nick Greiner, a supporter of the constitutional republic, introduced racial vilification laws in New South Wales. This was also done by a Labor government in Western Australia in 1990 and a Labor government in Queensland in 1991. The point is, though, that we should not have racial vilification laws defined just by state boundaries because racial vilification, particularly in the electronic media, obviously spans state boundaries and can affect all parts of the country. We need national laws that are an effective deterrent. I fully support the way in which the Prime Minister has moved decisively on this issue and we will see the legislation coming before the parliament.

I should say as an addendum that there is no free speech in this country that incites racial hatred and violence. One of the points made by the opposition has been that this would be an infringement on the freedom of speech. There is no speech that is free that incites people to racial hatred and violence in a multicultural society such as ours.

My second point of support for human rights concerns the action the parliament needs to take regarding the Tasmanian criminal laws which outlaw `sexual intercourse against the course of nature'. It is another instance where the parliamentary Liberal Party has put states rights ahead of human rights. If one does not fit the Liberal Party's stereotype of the family, one does not rate in its thoughts or policies. It is a party very much out of touch with Australian thought and values in the 1990s.

The relevant convention, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, was ratified by the Fraser government—a Liberal government—to its credit, in 1980. In 1991 the Hawke government adopted a protocol to the convention under which complaints can be made—and were made—to the United Nations Human Rights Committee. Earlier this year the committee found against Tasmanian criminal laws which `outlaw sexual intercourse against the course of nature'. That was a breach of the covenant. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has declared his intention to act and for the parliament to receive appropriate legislation.

It is interesting to note that the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), decreed that the opposition was opposed to the Tasmanian law but would take no action in this parliament. That has been reflected by the attitude of the new Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). In the Weekend Australian just past he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . "The Coalition is not in the business of telling people how to live their lives. Questions of personal morality are not properly the domain of a political party."

He further said that, even if the coalition does not agree with certain positions the Tasmanian government chooses to adopt, he would not take action about the Tasmanian laws or support this government's initiative. He is not going to support what the Fraser government did in 1980 by giving this parliament the power to take action, and he is not going to support the ideal that people are Australians before they are Tasmanians. In this parliament, if we have the power, we have the responsibility to legislate for all Australian citizens, especially those that are discriminated against. I point out that this is not just a law about homosexuals; it is also a law about heterosexual men engaging in what the Tasmanian government—the bedroom police—would define as an unnatural act. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks to the budget of the Attorney-General's Department relating to the provision of grants to marriage education and counselling organisations. Much time has been expended this year on debate about the parameters of family and the objects of family policy. I am reminded at the onset of winter that Ogden Nash once suggested `a family is a unit composed not only of children, but of men, women, an occasional animal and the common cold'. Whether we can agree on a definition of family or not, most would probably agree with Winston Churchill that a family usually starts `with a young man falling in love with a young woman'.

PARA.TAB: While the latest ABS statistics indicate that many couples then live together, the majority later marry and most live the conventional family lives that we all recognise. Regrettably, a third of couples will separate over a lifetime, leading to suggestions from time to time that we should make divorce more difficult. It is true that many people later regret their divorce. For others divorce can also be relief from a destructive relationship. It would have been better if these relationships had not resulted in marriage in the first place. This reflection leads me to this year's budget.

I note with despair in this International Year of the Family, despite all the rhetoric about the economic and emotional trauma of family breakdown, that the government has only marginally increased the obviously inadequate grants to these organisations. While it has increased funding for family mediation, preventive services still struggle to receive any real recognition. During 1992-93, 109,000 persons attended approved marriage counselling agencies. Yet couples experiencing difficulties in their relationships were told today that they must wait anywhere between eight and 12 weeks to attend a counselling session. As we all know, personal problems cannot wait eight to 12 weeks. How many marriages—at what cost to the individuals, their children and the community—dissolve because of inadequate funding?

Despite findings from the Australian Institute of Family Studies that every dollar spent on counselling saved the Commonwealth $7 elsewhere, this funding remains totally inadequate. Similarly, the funding of marriage education is almost non-existent—a miserly $1.2 million, or about $10 per marriage—when separation and divorce cost this nation some $3,000 million annually. Despite an Australian study two years ago which found that five per cent of couples either postponed or cancelled their wedding after attending marriage education programs, only 10 to 15 per cent of couples undertake any form of marriage preparation. It is easier to get married in Australia than it is to obtain a dog licence.

Instead of asking `Is getting divorced too easy?', perhaps we should be asking `Is getting married too easy?' A number of suggestions could be made to tackle this problem. Firstly, the government could adequately fund marriage and relationship education programs—something it does not do at present. Secondly, civil celebrants, who today officiate at the weddings of almost half of all couples, should be required to encourage couples to undertake some preparation for marriage. It is unacceptable for civil celebrants, some of whom earn up to $90,000 a year, to reject all obligation to the readiness of couples for marriage.

Thirdly, the notification period for marriage could be extended from the present period to a minimum of, say, 12 months. Obviously, some provision to waive this requirement would be necessary in appropriate circumstances, but usually couples have to book reception rooms, celebrants—whether civil or religious—and churches more than 12 months, in some cases 18 months to two years, before the wedding.

Finally, there is an also argument for making marriage education compulsory, as it is in some parts of the world. John Stuart Mill's famous essay On Liberty is frequently quoted in arguments against compulsion. However, Mill, the great defender of individual liberty, condoned the interference with others in upholding the best interests for children in compulsory schooling—a form of compulsory education. Why should we not also require marriage education, given the enormous consequences for the individuals concerned, for their children and for society generally when marriages fail and that breakdown occurs? Regrettably, this budget does nothing to improve one of the most difficult areas in family life today.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite ridiculous that members have been given five minutes to address portfolios and sums of money of these dimensions. Therefore, tonight, I want to confine my comments to the aviation section of the transport portfolio and raise a couple of issues. In doing so, I would like some answers from the government as to exactly what it intends to do in terms of a couple of its major policy announcements.

PARA.TAB: The first issue I will raise is that of the airport privatisation program, which in principle is supported by the opposition. We have all been aware that certain rating companies have put the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) on notice that the Federal Airports Corporation may face some difficulties in terms of its credit ratings if some of the government's statements come to fruition. In particular, the minister was chipped by one of the major rating companies regarding his statement that Melbourne airport could be sold off separately from the rest of the Federal Airports Corporation.

It would appear that already there may be some difficulties within the Federal Airports Corporation. A major international air terminal is under construction in my home state of Brisbane. That has been quite controversial in terms of the decision by the government not to go ahead with the full development of that terminal. It has come to our notice that the work on the eighth gate—which was put in after there was a realisation that the growth of international aviation in and out of Brisbane was going to be greater than first estimated—has now been stopped. If that is true, I wonder whether that is as a result of some of the problems that the Federal Airports Corporation could well have.

I am glad to see that the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) is in here. I hope that he takes up the issue of the continued development of Badgerys Creek, which is a most vital airport development that the Australian infrastructure needs very much as a matter of urgency. We need definitive statements from the government as to whether it will guarantee the Federal Airports Corporation funding once the privatisation process comes about and whether the privatisation is to follow the line of the individual sale of airports.

The second issue I would like to raise is what is happening with the free aviation agreement between Australia and New Zealand. In the One Nation statement some years ago, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that we would be moving towards an open aviation market between Australia and New Zealand. In fact, an agreement was reached between the then minister, Senator Collins, and New Zealand Minister Storey that this would proceed. We have seen some steps along the road to freeing up that market.

But the reality is that it is all supposed to be in place by the end of November this year. In fact, in answer to a question on notice I asked recently, the minister advised me that the internal arrangements of the situation would be completed by November this year. But that is not an indication that we will have a totally free market.

What is happening in the development of tourism and air rights into Australia is really quite interesting. One of the first moves that were made by the government, and quite rightly, was the agreement to give Air New Zealand beyond rights into Asia over Australia and for Qantas to pick up its beyond rights over New Zealand to places like Tahiti and Los Angeles.

Some figures issued recently by the Queensland government were quite substantial. The net increase to the Queensland tourism product through four New Zealand services a week last year was 25,000 passengers, worth something like $25 million and translated into 1,500 jobs. Quite frankly, if we are going to continue with the growth of tourism into Australia, the last thing we need in this country is to divert to some sort of two-airline policy in an international sense and go back to the old system of protectionism.

A free market between Australia and New Zealand has enormous potential in terms of developing Australian tourism. The reality, especially out of those Asian markets, is that people want more than a one-country destination. The Australian Tourist Commission is coming around to that line of thinking at the moment. The promotion of the destination of the south-west Pacific has some tremendous ramifications for the growth of inbound tourism.

If we stop this process, we could well find ourselves quite embarrassed that visitors will turn themselves away from Australia. That would really be quite stupid. There are also problems with the arrangements with the Koreans about access over the Tasman sea. If we can get that arrangement in place as soon as possible, we have the possibility of having one of the most efficient and competitive international airline systems in the world. The word `tourism' is all about inbound tourism. It is not about outbound Australians any more. We have to maximise that effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to address my remarks mainly to the transport portfolio. Before doing so, I indicate that this is the first chance I have had to speak on the appropriation bills. I regret that we are dealing with this portfolio. Whilst in overall terms I think that what was announced in the budget is mostly good, this is a portfolio area where I have a number of concerns.

PARA.TAB: My first concern is one of omission. The omission that is repeated from last year's budget is the government's inability to resurrect the black spot program. I say that for two reasons: firstly, the black spot program was a very successful road safety measure; and, secondly, as was proven by bringing forward the expenditure in the One Nation statement, it had employment consequences. I hope that on both those grounds—as an infrastructure provision program and an employment provision program—we might see a return to the program.

Tim Colebatch, writing in the Age in August last year, said that the best illustration of the 1993-94 budget's lack of imagination was the black spot program getting the chop. Ministers praised it to the public as a life saving program which had high benefit cost ratios and which created jobs. Because the allocation was brought forward, there was no money for it in that budget and there is no money for it in this budget.

The other aspect of the transport portfolio that I want to discuss relates to the sale of public assets. Two of the principal measures of the budget in the run-up to the ALP's national conference in September are the sale of airports and the future of ANL. It would come as no surprise to a lot of members of this House that my starting position in all these debates is that we should retain in public ownership government business enterprises such as the ones I have mentioned. I have consistently had that as a starting point.

I am quite happy to enter into the proper and appropriate debate that is available to me within the party forums. I hope that a genuine debate will go on and forward into the national conference in September. A lot of the questions that the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) raised are questions that will need answers if we are to see a proper consideration in the particular case of the disposal of the airports.

I listened with interest during the second reading debate to people such as the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who talked about the Badgerys Creek airport. I know that this issue is dear to the heart of the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), who will be speaking during the consideration in detail stage. I understand the great importance, for the proper management of aviation in Sydney, of those government announcements about the future of Badgerys Creek going forward. I am confident that they can go forward under the present system of public ownership. I believe that we need to really give it a chance.

If we look at the transport portfolio overall, we see many opportunities for the government to do things that have great economic benefit. We should not lose our chance, through public ownership, to have control over those projects. If we look at our land transport policies and our road provision policies, we see that clearly in those aspects we have an advantage through public sector intervention in provision. If the public sector is not to provide in those areas, it should look at mechanisms through which it can go into partnership with the private sector to ensure that there is appropriate provision that has not only the physical infrastructure outcomes but, nearly as importantly, the social outcomes that are required.

My great fear is that, as we divest government ownership of a number of these enterprises, we divest the power to have those influences that are additional to the actual enterprise itself and are important in the way that government business enterprises interface with people and in the provision of services over and above the strict commercial and economic ones. I hope that as a party we are able to have a mature debate and that we do not get hung up on ideological bents but are able to look at it in the context of what is in the long-term best interests of Australia.
