TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to talk, in the five minutes available to me, about a range of issues surrounding the transport portfolio. The first is waterfront reform, in which this government has trumpeted its success over the last few years. I take this opportunity to put the performance of the Australian waterfront in the context of those nations that we have to compete with in the real world of commercial trade in the overseas markets.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that one of the major shipping companies does an analysis of the relative performances of the 44 ports that it visits in the course of its business activities in any particular year. Out of the 44 ports that it analysed, Sydney—which this government claims is one of the outstanding results of its waterfront reform policies—came in 43rd. In other words, 42 out of 44 ports around the world were able to perform better than the port of Sydney. The port of Auckland ranks around 16th. That port was reformed under a Labour government in New Zealand that went about the business of waterfront reform properly, not in the half-hearted manner in which this government went about it in the period from 1989 to 1990. Melbourne comes in 38th.

So, out of 44 ports analysed, the two main ports in Australia came in 42nd and 38th. That is hardly anything for any government or any country to be proud of. Despite the fact that this government has spent $430 million of our money over that three-year period paying off waterside workers in order to get these improvements, whilst at the same time giving those who remain a 23 per cent increase in their pay, out of all of that money and all of that effort we have some of the worst performing ports.

According to this company's analysis, in the first quarter of 1994 Sydney moved 19.93 containers per hour. Melbourne slipped backwards, from a high point that this company assessed in the first part of 1993 of 25.6 containers per hour to 14.05 containers per hour in the first quarter of 1994. In other words, the Sydney and Melbourne ports had a deteriorating performance over the last 12 months. It is worth making the point that, when these figures for comparison were started in 1989, both those ports began from the lowest productivity points imaginable. In the period running up to waterfront reform, in order to get relatively good improvements in productivity, the unions ensured that from the time productivity was being measured in 1989 they ran productivity down to very low levels so that when they got back to normal levels they could boast a significant increase in productivity.

I now turn to shipping. It was pleasing to see in the budget that the government had taken note of the complaints of people such as me and members on this side of the House—and, to be fair, people such as the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis)—about the ridiculous increase, in effect a doubling, in the shipping industry, which was taking away all of the benefits of shipping reform that had been achieved by the industry over the previous 12 months. That is a good thing.

It is sad to see, however, that the government is playing ducks and drakes on the issue of ANL, which the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) raised. It is quite clear that the government has decided that it will sell ANL to any bidder, foreign or domestic, but it is going through this charade of putting the whole process through the Labor Party annual conference in September of this year, trying to trick the unions into believing that it is concerned with their views. It is not. It is going to sell it.

The only trouble is that, in the process, it is creating mayhem with ANL's creditors—and with its customers, who are leaving in droves. Those who are concerned about the future of ANL, such as I and, obviously, the honourable member for Scullin, note that this business of playing ducks and drakes with it is causing that company to experience serious commercial problems which will leave it with virtually no value by the time the ALP conference comes around in September this year, where we are told a decision will be made. We already know the decision has been made. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) in raising the issue of airport privatisation, which I endorse for a range of reasons. The first is to work out what is the core business of government. There was a fashion after World War II for parties on the left to think that policy needed to be geared to grabbing control of the commanding heights of the economy. This was the genesis of big public enterprise policy and big nationalisation policy in many of the social democratic parties of the world.

PARA.TAB: It turned out that, far from grabbing the commanding heights of the economy in the public interest, all that happened was the establishment of a number of centralised public bureaucracies that had very little to do with the public interest. Anyone who has followed the debate about airports in Sydney, both at Mascot and at Badgerys Creek, would understand that policy has been geared to the needs of a rather self-serving centralised bureaucracy instead of the public interest.

For many years we have had a lack of competition policy. At least out of privatisation there will be more active competition between those two airport sites in Sydney, Kingsford Smith and Sydney west international airport. Competition is important. So too is the revenue government can raise from this measure. There is absolutely no evidence that private sector organisations cannot build and operate airports effectively. The argument should be that airports are not part of the core responsibility of governments as long as the private sector can demonstrate that it can build airports and contribute the investment that would otherwise be a drain on the government and taxpayers' funds and that it can run those airports with regard to the public interest. If the government establishes a regulatory authority then we can be assured that the public interest will be defended.

A number of issues have been raised in the debate, both inside and outside the parliament. The first of those concerns pricing policy. The Prices Surveillance Authority in its report some months ago was highly critical of the FAC for its pricing policies and investment criteria. Large capital outlays on aeronautical projects, such as terminal expansions, are driven more by engineering and service standards than by full economic evaluation. That is a problem, as too has been the FAC's absurd suggestion, based on a credit rating from Standard and Poors, that full privatisation to a single buyer is preferable to breaking up its assets into competing airports.

There has been a suggestion that competing airports that are privatised will not be able to survive financially. The honourable member for Fadden raised the issue of their credit ratings. Anyone reading that PSA report would understand that the FAC has applied a uniform pricing structure across the nation for each of its airports, irrespective of local demand and cost factors.

Under a policy of competition and privatisation, provincial airports that are making a loss will need to change their pricing structure to reflect full costs so they can at the very least break even. Around the place there has been an argument, couched in equity terms, that increasing prices at airports via charges and fees will be a problem in terms of affordability for provincial areas. The truth is that airport fees and charges account for just three per cent of the price of airline tickets, so we are not talking about a large movement in price.

Even more importantly, we are not talking about a social justice issue in terms of the beneficiaries of the current policy of cross-subsidisation. The untenable situation at the moment is that the cross-subsidies are hidden. They are not exposed in these budget papers or the annual report of the FAC. No government can base quality decisions on anything but quality information. But on these cross-subsidies we do not have the material. It is hidden away in the cross-subsidisation documents held by the FAC.

Commonsense tells us that the beneficiaries of the cross-subsidies at provincial airports are, by and large, not low or even middle income earners. It is the higher income earners in this country who use Australian airports. For that reason, we are not talking about a big social justice issue. If prices go up in provincial airports and the subsidies are diminished, then the people who are paying the extra price are not low to middle income earners; they are, by and large, higher income earners.

This is not something that will disadvantage, in social justice terms, needy and disadvantaged communities in Australia. Privatisation will involve a very small movement in price and the elimination of hidden cross-subsidies, the current beneficiaries of which are those in our community who least need them. So, in equity terms, this policy is totally justified. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use the few minutes available to me in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) to talk about only one subject. I refer to the disgraceful cuts in road funding which are incorporated in this budget. At the same time as the government has raised revenue from fuel excise to record levels—it is getting close to $10 billion—it has slashed a further $200 million off road funding. It is now a mere $820 million. That means road funding has been slashed by 50 per cent in two years and the amount spent on roads this year will be lower than the $1,200 million spent when Labor first came to office. That is an appalling indictment of this government's attitude to roads. At a time when fuel excise receipts will be close to $10 billion, only 8.4 per cent of that revenue coming from motorists will go to roads.

PARA.TAB: I have heard government members seeking to defend that situation by saying that the government is spending a lot of money on the effects of road trauma. Are they trying to say to us that they would prefer to spend taxpayers' money on picking up the damage after road accidents rather than seeking to do something about road trauma in the first place, namely, improving Australia's roads and therefore reducing the number of fatalities?

The government's own figures suggest that each road fatality costs Australia about $630,000. That means that we are spending over $6 billion each year on road trauma. That is really quite an appalling state of affairs, yet the government would prefer to spend money on this rather than on repairing our road network. The former minister for land transport, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), noted that the black spot program was one of the most outstanding programs for road safety that has ever been adopted by any government in Australia. That is the flamboyant language that is somewhat typical of this government. But this government has now moved to abolish the black spot program altogether. It has so little interest in the effects of poor roads on Australian motorists.

Motorists travelling along the Bruce Highway near Federal, a small rural community in my electorate, receive a very poignant reminder of the effect on the motorists of Australia of poor roads. About 16 white crosses have been installed by the local community under the leadership of the Federal Hall Committee. Each one of these crosses represents the life of a motorist which has been lost in that particular area over recent years. In fact, one of the activists in this particular program, Mr Alf Malezer, says that about 29 people have died on this short

SPEECH.PARA: stretch of road between Six Mile Creek at Cooroy and Coles Creek Road at Skyring Creek in the past 10 years.

PARA.TAB: If it costs $630,000 for each of those people, it would have cost Australian taxpayers $18 million on this particular piece of road alone. Why on earth cannot the government spend some of that $18 million to fix the road? Here is a clear case: 29 fatalities over a short distance of road. It is an ideal area for the black spot program to be targeted. But the black spot program has been abolished. A paltry road program was announced a few days ago. The government will spend $120 million on new projects. This seems to offer no hope that anything will be done on this horror stretch of road. All that will happen on the Bruce Highway will be a couple of extra passing lanes. There will be no fundamental assault on what is clearly a dangerous piece of road. The reason nothing will be done is that this government continues to slash road funding to the lowest real levels in Australian history.

That has an enormous impact not only with respect to the convenience of motorists, the cost of transport in this country and the level of pollution in our cities, but also on the number of fatalities and injuries that will occur not just on this section of road but on the whole national road system. Much of the blame for that can be attributed directly to this government's persistent and consistent cutbacks in road funding. It needs to rethink its attitude to roads. It needs to return to Australian motorists some of the tax revenue that is taken from them. It should help do something to restore a proper and decent national road system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to continue my remarks on airport privatisation. The privatisation program initiated by the government in this budget can be supported on equity grounds and on the basis of the core business of government. There is absolutely no evidence that private sector organisations cannot effectively construct and operate airports. It is also apparent that private sector ownership can play a very dynamic role in regional economic development strategies.

PARA.TAB: The recent McKinsey study on business investment and regional prosperity reported on the important role of Cairns as the only major airport in Australia not owned by the FAC. Through the port authority, a dynamic marketing strategy was put in place at Cairns in order to attract people to the airport. Dynamic links with the business community were also established. That is very important. It is in the vested interests of a private sector operator of an airport to make sure that the land surrounding the airport site is well used by manufacturing and tourism enterprises and is well supported and developed. That means that more users will come through the airport for freight and tourism purposes. It is important to get the vested interests right. While the FAC has not done that sort of planning in the past, we can look forward to privately owned airports undertaking that role and playing a very dynamic role in regional economic development.

I cite the case of western Sydney and the slow development of Badgerys Creek under FAC policy. This has now been reversed by the actions in this budget. The privatisation program will fund the initial stage of Badgerys Creek in order to develop the international length runway and in the year 2000 it will be handed over to private sector operation, ownership and management. That is the strategic way in which to place airport investment. The funds out of privatisation will be used in the initial stage, which is the stage that the private sector will not fund itself, to develop important parts of the national transport infrastructure, as was acknowledged by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull).

The past practice at Badgerys Creek has been unfavourable to the interests of the FAC. The FAC runs Kingsford Smith airport as it is its most profitable airport, sustaining 55 per cent of its nationwide profits of $89 million in 1992-93. The development of Badgerys Creek and the attraction of modern airport technology and curfew-free operations would bring substantial competition to the aviation market in Sydney and it would cut into the profits of Kingsford Smith. Competition and privatisation linked together are essential to break up this public sector monopoly and produce much more dynamic regional economic development strategies.

The FAC's monopoly has also been used to shelter the airline industry from competition. Restrictive trade practices at airport terminals contributed significantly to the demise of Compass. In Sydney, the Chief Executive of Ansett, Graeme McMahon, has admitted, `It is about time that Ansett Airlines confessed that the lack of a second international airport is the problem. TALK.START.PARA: —Today the House took a minute of its time to remember the D-day landings on 6 June 1944. I would like to take a few moments to add to that by giving some details. I would have thought we would have had an opportunity to debate those today. It has been said in many places that today, Monday, 6 June, is the 50th anniversary of D-day—the day the liberation of Europe began. The invasion began at dawn on this day. The allied invasion was known as Operation Overlord and it involved 155,000 troops, 12,000 aircraft, 6,500 naval transport craft in 75 convoys and over 1,200 tanks. It was the greatest armada ever formed. It was an event without military precedent and one I doubt and hope we will ever see exceeded.

PARA.TAB: It was a colossal feat of organisation and was the product of years of exhaustive planning and basic hard work which commenced in 1943. Operation Overlord was under the supreme command of General Dwight D. Eisenhower. Included in this force were approximately 2,500 Australian defence personnel, mainly in the air force. There were 2,000 personnel in the air force, 400 in the navy and 100 in the army.

D-day allied casualties—those killed and wounded—are estimated at some 6,000 people. By the time Hitler's Atlantic wall had been breached, total allied casualties amounted to 12,500, including 2,500 killed. This did not compare with the first day of the terrible Battle of the Somme in World War I. In the first three months following D-day, 200,000 Germans are estimated to have been killed and wounded. In addition, over the same period some 200,000 German prisoners of war were taken.

The invasion consisted of troops from the United States, Britain and Canada landing at five points on the Normandy coastline. The five landings were codenamed Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword. The allied forces were confronted by some 50,000 German troops, 319 operational aircraft, 21 ships and 127 tanks. The reason for the success of this operation was due to a massive deception operation codenamed Fortitude carried out by the allied command.

Finding it impossible to hide the massive build-up of troops and equipment in the south of England, the deception assumed even greater importance in the overall plan. Mythical armies and phantom groups with dummy camps and equipment were created. Their main objective was to make the Germans believe that the Normandy landing was a feint and merely an overture to main landings elsewhere on the French coast.

Other deception plans codenamed Tractable, Glimmer and Quicksilver were all of importance in this overall plan. By the end of D-day, 6 June 1944, the allies had achieved their main aim, although not capturing all their objectives laid down in the original plan. This day we commemorate the courage, commitment and gallantry of these people. Their bravery and determination to free the world from Nazi German occupation was a major contributor to the democracy that we now enjoy.

I do not need to say anything about the courage of those people and how important it was that Australia continued to be involved, notwithstanding its own responsibilities to the people of Australia in the Pacific, from where many of our troops had been withdrawn. Australians were involved in Europe because democracy as we know it was under threat from a totalitarian and very vicious regime.

D-day is a very important day. This will not be the last day on which we celebrate the efforts to bring peace. It has taken a long time to achieve peace. Unfortunately, as we speak, there are parts of the world where war and death are still major problems. Nevertheless, this parliament and this country will be looking forward to the victory days next year, in May and August, when we will be remembering the end of the war in Europe and the Pacific. I sincerely trust that on those days this parliament will be prepared to allocate sufficient time to properly discuss those matters and put on record the great thanks to the soldiers of all those wars who protected our democratic system.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Conservation and Land Management: Western Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last full week of May the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts visited Western Australia as part of its inquiry into employment and the environment. We were there to examine the site reclamation projects and the forest industry. We were shown over the Alcoa bauxite mine in the jarrah forest country, the karri forest projects in the south-west corner of Western Australia, a quarry where the land is being reclaimed and various other projects. We were impressed by the work that Alcoa is doing in the reclamation of land where bauxite has been mined.

PARA.TAB: While being briefed by Alcoa, I asked the senior staff person from the Department of Conservation and Land Management from Western Australia, commonly known as CALM, how many people were employed by the department in that region. She said, `It depends which week you ask. If you had asked two weeks ago the answer would have been 13 and if you ask this week the answer is eight.' Absolutely astonished by this reduction in staffing, we explored this matter further. We were told that the Western Australian government is reducing the staff of the Department of Conservation and Land Management from 1,200 at present to 1,000 people. This reduces the number of staff available from 13 to eight for tree planting, forest management, park ranging and guiding tourists around the area.

When we explored this matter still further we found that this was the second wave of staff reductions. About three years ago there were 1,400 staff. The government is now in the process of reducing that number to 1,000. This is at a time when the majority of Australians say they are more concerned about the environment than economic growth.

There is not a part of Australia which is not aware of the importance of careful management of our forests. We all know that about half of our forests have been cut down. It is crucial for the survival of ecosystems in Australia that our forests be protected and that those that are going to be cut down, or in this case removed because of bauxite mining, be replanted as quickly as possible. In other words, effective management is absolutely essential.

The Western Australian state government is in the process of nearly halving the number of people employed on this vital project. This is extraordinarily inconsistent with any serious conservation or employment goals of government. The Commonwealth government announced in its white paper a series of employment programs to give work experience and training to the long-term unemployed. Some of the most attractive and appropriate projects in this regard announced by the Commonwealth government involve landcare, forest management and tree planting, yet permanent jobs in that area are being decimated by the Western Australian government.

That is a terrible reflection on its priorities. It is being completely irresponsible about caring for the environment. It seems very important to put pressure on the Western Australian government to change its priorities so that the very limited forests in Western Australia will be much more carefully managed. It is true that the Commonwealth's funding of the states has been reduced and that makes it more difficult for the states; nevertheless, it is still a reflection of the state government's own priorities that this is being allowed to happen. I make this public protest about that and draw attention to it to put pressure on the Western Australian government to change its policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no need for me to dwell on the fact that the armed forces of Britain and the United States and their allies saved the world from the scourge of fascism by defeating Germany, and later Japan, in 1945. That the D-day invasion on 6 June 1944 turned the tide is undisputed and well documented in the hundreds of print and film documentaries we have all seen in the last week or so.

PARA.TAB: I wish to refer to an Australian unsung hero who survived not only D-day but also the end of the war, and who is commemorating the 50th anniversary today. I refer to a personal friend, Keith Stevens, who was born in Hampton Park in Victoria. He volunteered for the RAAF in 1939, was sent to Canada for aircrew training in 1940, and subsequently to Britain to join 57 Squadron, 5 Group, of the RAF Bomber Command. Prior to D-day, he had been involved in the lead-up to the dambuster raids in Germany and had regularly carried out bombing raids on targets in Germany. He attained the rank of pilot officer and, later, flight lieutenant.

Keith's role began on D-day minus one when his squadron was sent to bomb German coastal batteries to ensure a safe landing for allied troops. He says that, on the way home, he saw below him part of the enormous armada on its way to the Normandy beaches. Soon afterwards, on 8 July, Keith had to bail out over northern France when his plane was shot down while on a raid to destroy caves at St Leu D'Esseront where thousands of V1 and V2 rockets were housed. The raid had been ordered by General Eisenhower and its success probably saved London from attacks by a further 4,000 rockets.

Nursing a broken shoulder and injured back, and after having been captured by and escaping from the Gestapo, Keith was finally found by a French farmer who introduced him to the local resistance group. He lived precariously, disguised as a local, for three months despite speaking only a few words of French and German. This ended when the Americans broke through the Falaise Gap and liberated Clairemont, where he was staying.

He returned to Britain in September 1994 and then came home to Australia. He was decorated three times, receiving the Distinguished Flying Medal from Britain, the Cross of Valour from Poland and the Bronze Medal of Merit from France. Keith is the Australian convenor of the Escape Society, which was formed after the war by Lord Portal and Sir Basil Embry to include only servicemen who had escaped from the Germans in World War II.

The story ended happily for Keith. He married a Scottish girl, Anita, whom he met while in Britain. They live in Rosebud in my state of Victoria. Despite back and shoulder injuries which still cause him trouble, Keith was one of the lucky ones.

I am reminded of an anecdote from the book Not as a Duty Only by Jo Gullett, another Australian—a remarkable man—who was fighting on D-day. Incidentally, he later became a member of this House for the seat of Henty in Victoria. Jo Gullett recalled that, after being wounded, he was sent to England to recuperate. He met `a young Australian pilot' who had `a tremendous air of happiness and wellbeing. He was well built and very good looking.' Jo went with the young man, John Rutter, to meet an English girl. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: She was English and in the Royal Air Force too . . . I watched them go off, smiling and happy, and thought that with any luck, with his wonderful vitality, fitness, experience and strength, he should survive. He was killed very soon after.

We are fortunate that not all such fine men were lost. I count it as a privilege to know Keith Stevens. As a footnote, considering there were 15,000 Australian troops serving in Britain at the time of D-day—mention has also been made today of the 2,600 involved in the D-day exercise itself—it is surprising that there is no mention of D-day in the Australian Encyclopaedia. Let us hope that that is an omission that might be corrected in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 19 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article entitled `Australia free traders who can't sell a sausage' in the Australian Financial Review of 11 October 1993.
(2) Is it a fact that Australia is missing many opportunities for food exports to the European Community.
(3) What steps is the Government able to take to ensure that the missing of these opportunities is minimised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes

(2) The European market for processed foods is the largest in the world and Australia, with the reputation it enjoys for high quality, environmentally sound food production, has a very significant potential to exploit this market. Australian food exporters have had less success in this regard than might have been expected.

There are no doubt a number of reasons for this, prime amongst them being the European Union's (EU) Common Agriculture policy that serves to severely restrict non EU countries' access to the EU market for commodities. This is a major barrier preventing Australian companies from reaping the benefits of their considerable comparative advantage in this area. For example, for sheep meat, Australia is restricted to a quota of 17,500 tonnes per annum; similar restrictions apply to beef, 6,000 tonnes per annum and, for cheese, 3,000 tonnes per annum; over and above these quotas exorbitant levies apply. The Uruguay Round settlement of the GATT, while it is welcomed for the positive impact its provisions should have by introducing disciplines on domestic and export subsidies and in reigning in excess agricultural production, has offered only very modest prospects for increases in Australian exports of these commodities to EU markets.

Another factor which operates to hinder free access for Australian agricultural products to the EU market is the propensity for the European Commission and some EU Member States to impose unilateral provisions for veterinary checking of imported food products. While Australia respects the right of other countries to impose high health standards for imported food, we have expressed concern where such provisions are either introduced without adequate consultation or where they give the appearance of serving to protect local industries from outside competition or of being used to extract some reciprocal benefit from Australia.

The difficulty of increasing agricultural commodity exports to the EU highlights the need for the Australian food exporters to concentrate their efforts in the processed food area which is generally not subject to quantitative restrictions and where tariffs are low.

It is true that food exporters are often inhibited by the high freight rates to Europe for fresh, chilled or frozen products. In some cases intra-company export franchising arrangements may also be a constraint.

It is also true that the opportunity cost of exporting to the European Union is high, when Asian markets are both easier to service and achieving much higher growth rates than elsewhere. In 1992/3 six out of Australia's ten largest export markets for processed food and beverages were in Asia. Thailand and Malaysia rank 13 and 14 respectively. Annual growth 1988-92 of highly processed food exports to seven Asian markets grew by more than 10% per annum with Thailand, Malaysia, Taiwan and Indonesia being around 20%. This has led the Agri-food Council to target the Asean region for increased food exports.
Nevertheless, processed food exports to the European Union remains an area with significant potential for improvement.

(3) The Government will continue to develop its multilateral and bilateral relationships to ensure that more opportunities are available to Australian exporters. This will include efforts in the GATT, the UN and the OECD, as well as our ongoing contact with individual nations within the EU. Australia will continue to press for further reforms of the EU's Common Agricultural Policy.

Its export facilitation body, Austrade, has an extensive program to assist companies export to Europe. This includes a network of offices in Europe, participation in food trade fairs, active seeking out of Australian capacity to compete in Europe by its domestic network in Australia, undertaking market research for companies and working with key clients to pursue specific opportunities. For example, Austrade has a contract from a major client to identify key food buying contacts from European supermarkets and similar organisations to invite to Australia to increase their awareness of Australian food and beverage capability and quality.

Austrade is organising Australian participation at SIAL 94 in Paris (23-27 Oct 1994)—Europe's second largest food trade exhibition. It is also organising Australian participation at important events such as Gastro Nord in Sweden and Vinitaly in Milan 1994.

Apart from the many trade offices in Europe, Austrade also has six specialist offices devoted to increasing investment, including in Australian food processing and beverage industry. While the main attraction is to employ Australia as a base to export manufactured product into Asia, it can also include Europe.

Australia's participation at ANUGA `93—the world's largest food fair—in September/October 1993 produced good results. As on previous occasions, Austrade organised Australian participation involving 20 exhibitors representing over 40 Australian food exporters. Preliminary reports indicate Australian firms made actual sales of $11.9m during the fair and project sales of $90.5m over the next 12 months.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's wine exports continue to go from strength to strength in Europe. Europe accounts for 54% of world wine consumption and takes over 60% of Australia's exports. Austrade and the Australian Wine and Brandy Council are actively involved in the promotion of Australian wines in Europe. Australia is about to sign a Wine Agreement with the EU which will foster further growth in this trade.

Other Government initiatives include the United Kingdom/Australia Trade and Investment Conference in January 1994, sponsored jointly by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Austrade. Bringing together, as it did, over 500 business leaders from the two countries, this conference was judged an outstanding success and should help to improve two-way trade and investment flows.
So, while the Government is doing its bit to facilitate exports to Europe, it is also up to the relevant industries to find opportunities and develop them.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does her Department provide funding to the National AIDS Council; if so, does the Department have any influence on how the funds it provides are spent.
(2) Were funds provided by the Commonwealth used to pay for the production of a National AIDS Council brochure featuring two males kissing.
(3) Did her Department approve the brochure before it was released.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) I am not aware of an organisation called the National AIDS Council. The brochure the honourable member has referred to was produced by the Victorian AIDS Council (VAC) in September 1990 as a component of their range of activities which provide safe sex messages for young gay men. The brochure in question did not receive any Commonwealth funding and the project was produced with funds raised by VAC from alternative non-government sources.

However, in the absence of a cure or vaccine for HIV, the Commonwealth Government believes that education and behaviour change are the only means of prevention. Because some messages may offend sections of the community, the Commonwealth Government always aims to ensure that such messages are targeted very carefully so that they reach the intended audience only.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) For each State and Territory how many students (a) in total, (b) male and (c) female, leave school at (i) Grade 6 Primary, (ii) Year 7, (iii) Year 8, (iv) Year 9, (v) Year 10 and (vi) Year 11.
(2) Has his Department conducted any surveys which might point to the extent of the problem of early school leavers; if not, why not; if so, what is the extent of the problem.
(3) What action has been taken at a national level to address the problem of early school leavers.
(4) Is the problem of early school leavers from Grade 6 to Year 9 being addressed in the Employment, Industry and Regional Development White Paper; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are no official data on school leavers but these can be derived reasonably accurately from enrolment information. The number of school leavers shown below has been calculated to be the number of students enrolled in each year level in 1992 less the number of students enrolled in the next highest year level in 1993. Note that using this approach it is possible to have negative numbers of school leavers in a State because of migration effects, interstate transfer of students and the effect of some students repeating or skipping a year.

ANSWER.PARA: Year 6 Year 7 Year 8 Year 9 Year 10 Year 11 Year 12

PARA.TAB: Conclusions based on comparisons using the above figures should be treated cautiously as they may be misleading in many cases due to variations in the numbers of young people eligible for each year level, from year to year, and population differences between the States.

(2) The Department of Employment, Education and Training conducts a longitudinal survey of young people (known as the Australian Youth Survey—AYS) which focuses on participation in school and post-school education, and in the labour market. It began in 1989, and in 1993 survey information was obtained from just over 8,000 respondents aged 16 to 23, by means of face to face interviews. The AYS, therefore, provides information on the extent of the problem of early school leavers.

Two recent publications based on the AYS data, Youth Profile 1 and 2, have examined the extent to which young people leave school before year 12 and then do not undertake any post-school study. For convenience they are referred to as `early leavers'.

About twenty three percent of young people are `early leavers'. This figure is based on data collected from those respondents to the AYS who were aged 19 in 1989, 1990 or 1991. Early leavers are more likely to:
come from a sole parent family;
come from a lower socio-economic status background;
have a disability;
have neither parent with post school education.
The impact of leaving education early includes:
more likelihood of being unemployed, and for longer periods;
for those with a job
—less likely to be in one which provides formal job training, and
—more likely to have an unskilled job;
having shorter term jobs;
more likelihood of being out of the labour force altogether.

(3) Decisions to leave school early can be related to many factors in the school and community environment. Access to family and student income support can be relevant in some situations. Program support for young people at risk can also be important, including literacy training, support in English as a second language (ESL), attention to the special needs of Aboriginal students, and programs for people with disabilities. Commonwealth programs are available in all of these areas.

The Students at Risk (STAR) component of the National Equity Program for Schools caters directly for the needs of this group. STAR commenced in 1990 in the Government school sector as part of the Youth Social Justice Strategy. It was extended to the non-Government school sector as part of the 1992 National Employment and Training Plan. STAR identifies and assists those students most at risk of not completing secondary school.

Under arrangements for STAR, responsibility for administering the program rests with Government and non-Government education authorities in the States and Territories. In some States/Territories Commonwealth-funded STAR activities are coordinated with State-level initiatives to assist students at risk of not completing school.

The funds provided nationally under STAR were $7 million for 1993 and $7.25 million for 1994. In the 1993/94 Budget STAR was extended to 1996 with funding of $13.6 million over the program years 1995 and 1996.

(4) "Working Nation" concentrated on ensuring that young people stay on to Year 12 or remain in education and training. Recognising that some students may prefer a more vocational orientation in their last years of secondary schooling, the Government decided to establish an additional way for young people to acquire recognised workforce skills with the creation of the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation. This will help students for whom mainstream schooling is inappropriate to combine their studies with work-based learning and off-the-job training.

The Youth Training Initiative will provide training programs for those leaving school early who have not secured an employment or training place. It also sends a strong signal to young people under the age of 18 that they should participate in education or training instead of joining the unemployed in the search for low skilled employment.

"Working Nation" announced an allocation of $3.2 million over the next three years to conduct a national survey of students aged 7,9 and 13 to obtain a snapshot of literacy skills. This is in response to recent concerns that there are no reliable data on literacy levels in Australian schools. The data are expected to be available by the end of 1996.

The budget provides an additional grant of just under $9 million in 1995 to target the literacy and numeracy needs of children in kindergarten to Year 3, with special emphasis on those from disadvantaged backgrounds. This initiative recognises the importance of tackling literacy problems as early as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 May, Dr Hewson asked the Treasurer a question without notice concerning the estimate of revenue to be raised from companies in 1994-95 as a result of the compliance enhancement measures announced in the Treasurer's statement on tax policy of September 1992. Dr Hewson also wanted to know on what basis this estimate was prepared. The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: In the then Treasurer's September 1992 Statement on Tax Policy it was estimated that an extra $750 million of revenue would be collected in 1994-95 through these compliance enhancement measures; it was estimated that $335 million of this $750 million would be collected from companies.

The estimate for company collections through these measures was based on ATO research and experience that indicated the extra revenue could be raised by allocating additional resources to the following activities:
Large/Medium project which includes:
acceleration of large case audit through greater availability of high level technical advice;
expansion of rulings and determinations;
increased focus on international issues and contemporary commercial practices;
expansion of business audit;
expanded information reporting; and
increased record keeping audits.
It was estimated that the Large/Medium project would account for $250 million of the $335 million in 1994-95. This estimate was arrived at having regard to the following factors:

In their evaluation of the large case Audit program, Boston Consulting Group concluded that compliance would improve if taxpayers were made more aware of their tax obligations. It was conservatively estimated that the Large/Medium project would increase compliance by 2-3% by 1994-95, resulting in additional revenue of $200 million. This estimate was arrived at after consideration of the indirect effects obtained in other areas from compliance activity (eg improved compliance from the announcement of TFN), and judgments based on the dollar value of the strategic issues which would be covered by the tax rulings and determinations.
In addition, the extra resources used in direct audit activity were estimated, based on past results, to yield an additional $50 million.
On the basis of past results it was estimated that the additional resources allocated to the expansion of business audit activities would yield an additional $25 million of revenue in 1994-95.

ANSWER.PARA: Record Keeping and Expanded Information Reporting

PARA.TAB: It was estimated that the record keeping and expanded information reporting component of the strategy would account for $60 million of the $335 million in 1994-95. This estimate was based on estimates of improved compliance due to better record keeping by business, and reduced opportunity for misreporting of income in industries subject to the expanded reporting arrangements.
